message.content:
Validate all guide content files in `src/data/guides/` are complete and SaaS-ready. Check:

1. **Required Guide Fields**:
   - Every guide has: id, slug, title, subtitle, description, icon, humorLevel, estimatedReadTime, order, tags, relatedGuides, productIds, forumCategory
   - All guides have heroMedia with valid URLs
   - All sections have: id, title, humorLevel, content

2. **Content Completeness**:
   - No empty productIds arrays (should have relevant products)
   - No placeholder or TODO content in descriptions
   - All guides have at least 3 sections

3. **Cross-References**:
   - relatedGuides reference valid guide IDs
   - forumCategory matches valid forum categories

4. **Media Assets**:
   - All heroMedia URLs are valid (https://)
   - Section media has proper alt text and captions

List all guide files checked and any issues found with specific details.

    30â†’  AMAZON_REGIONS.forEach(region => {
    31â†’    const asin = asins[region] || asins.us; // Fallback to US ASIN
    32â†’    if (asin) {
    33â†’      links[region] = buildAmazonUrl(asin, region);
    34â†’    }
    35â†’  });
    36â†’
    37â†’  // Asia uses US ASIN on amzn.asia domain
    38â†’  if (asins.us) {
    39â†’    links['asia'] = buildAmazonUrl(asins.us, 'asia');
    40â†’  }
    41â†’
    42â†’  return links;
    43â†’}

  1299â†’// ============================================
  1300â†’// HELPER FUNCTIONS
  1301â†’// ============================================
  1302â†’
  1303â†’/**
  1304â†’ * Product ID aliases for backwards compatibility
  1305â†’ * Maps shorthand IDs to full product IDs
  1306â†’ */
  1307â†’const PRODUCT_ID_ALIASES: Record<string, string> = {
  1308â†’  // Supplements
  1309â†’  ashwagandha: 'ashwagandha_ksm66',
  1310â†’  creatine: 'creatine_mono',
  1311â†’  omega_3: 'omega3_fish_oil',
  1312â†’  zinc: 'zinc_picolinate',
  1313â†’  // Add more as needed
  1314â†’};
  1315â†’
  1316â†’/**
  1317â†’ * Get product by ID (supports aliases)
  1318â†’ */
  1319â†’export function getGuideProductById(id: string): GuideProduct | undefined {
  1320â†’  // Resolve alias if it exists
  1321â†’  const resolvedId = PRODUCT_ID_ALIASES[id] || id;
  1322â†’  return GUIDE_PRODUCTS.find(p => p.id === resolvedId);
  1323â†’}
  1324â†’
  1325â†’/**
  1326â†’ * Get all products in a category
  1327â†’ */
  1328â†’export function getGuideProductsByCategory(category: ProductCategory): GuideProduct[] {
  1329â†’  return GUIDE_PRODUCTS
  1330â†’    .filter(p => p.category === category)
  1331â†’    .sort((a, b) => a.priority - b.priority);
  1332â†’}
  1333â†’
  1334â†’/**
  1335â†’ * Get all base stack products (essentials for everyone)
  1336â†’ */
  1337â†’export function getBaseStackProducts(): GuideProduct[] {
  1338â†’  return GUIDE_PRODUCTS
  1339â†’    .filter(p => p.isBaseStack)
  1340â†’    .sort((a, b) => a.priority - b.priority);
  1341â†’}
  1342â†’
  1343â†’/**
  1344â†’ * Get products by priority level
  1345â†’ */
  1346â†’export function getGuideProductsByPriority(priority: number): GuideProduct[] {
  1347â†’  return GUIDE_PRODUCTS.filter(p => p.priority === priority);
  1348â†’}
  1349â†’
  1350â†’/**
  1351â†’ * Get all unique categories with product counts
  1352â†’ */
  1353â†’export function getProductCategories(): Array<{ category: ProductCategory; count: number }> {
  1354â†’  const categories: ProductCategory[] = [
  1355â†’    'hygiene',
  1356â†’    'grooming',
  1357â†’    'skincare',
  1358â†’    'miscellaneous',
  1359â†’    'supplements',
  1360â†’    'hair',
  1361â†’    'beard',
  1362â†’    'teeth',
  1363â†’    'kbeauty',
  1364â†’    'hormonal',
  1365â†’    'surgery',
  1366â†’  ];
  1367â†’
  1368â†’  return categories.map(category => ({
  1369â†’    category,
  1370â†’    count: GUIDE_PRODUCTS.filter(p => p.category === category).length,
  1371â†’  }));
  1372â†’}
  1373â†’
  1374â†’/**
  1375â†’ * Get products by array of IDs (preserves order)
  1376â†’ */
  1377â†’export function getGuideProductsByIds(ids: string[]): GuideProduct[] {
  1378â†’  return ids
  1379â†’    .map(id => getGuideProductById(id))
  1380â†’    .filter((p): p is GuideProduct => p !== undefined);
  1381â†’}
  1382â†’
  1383â†’/**
  1384â†’ * Search products by name or description
  1385â†’ */
  1386â†’export function searchGuideProducts(query: string): GuideProduct[] {
  1387â†’  const lowered = query.toLowerCase();
  1388â†’  return GUIDE_PRODUCTS.filter(p =>
  1389â†’    p.name.toLowerCase().includes(lowered) ||
  1390â†’    p.description.toLowerCase().includes(lowered) ||
  1391â†’    p.tagline.toLowerCase().includes(lowered) ||
  1392â†’    (p.brand && p.brand.toLowerCase().includes(lowered))
  1393â†’  );
  1394â†’}
  1395â†’
  1396â†’/**
  1397â†’ * Get total product count
  1398â†’ */
  1399â†’export function getTotalProductCount(): number {
  1400â†’  return GUIDE_PRODUCTS.length;
  1401â†’}
  1402â†’
  1403â†’/**
  1404â†’ * Get category display info
  1405â†’ */
  1406â†’export function getCategoryDisplayInfo(category: ProductCategory): {
  1407â†’  name: string;
  1408â†’  icon: string;
  1409â†’  description: string;
  1410â†’} {
  1411â†’  const info: Record<ProductCategory, { name: string; icon: string; description: string }> = {
  1412â†’    hygiene: {
  1413â†’      name: 'Hygiene',
  1414â†’      icon: 'Sparkles',
  1415â†’      description: 'Fundamentals of not repelling people',
  1416â†’    },
  1417â†’    grooming: {
  1418â†’      name: 'Grooming',
  1419â†’      icon: 'Scissors',
  1420â†’      description: 'Tools for precision face maintenance',
  1421â†’    },
  1422â†’    skincare: {
  1423â†’      name: 'Skincare',
  1424â†’      icon: 'Droplet',

/**
 * Product Registry for Guides System
 * 73 products with multi-region affiliate links and Ross-style taglines
 * Categories: hygiene, grooming, skincare, miscellaneous, supplements, hair, beard, teeth, kbeauty, hormonal, surgery
 */

import { GuideProduct, ProductCategory } from '@/types/guides';
import { buildAmazonUrl } from '@/lib/region';

// ============================================
// AMAZON ASIN MAPPING BY REGION
// ============================================

interface ProductASINs {
  us?: string;
  uk?: string;
  de?: string;
  fr?: string;
  au?: string;
}

// Regions that have Amazon stores with ASINs
type AmazonRegion = 'us' | 'uk' | 'de' | 'fr' | 'au';
const AMAZON_REGIONS: AmazonRegion[] = ['us', 'uk', 'de', 'fr', 'au'];

// Helper to build region links from ASINs
function buildRegionLinks(asins: ProductASINs): Record<string, string> {
  const links: Record<string, string> = {};

  AMAZON_REGIONS.forEach(region => {
    const asin = asins[region] || asins.us; // Fallback to US ASIN
    if (asin) {
      links[region] = buildAmazonUrl(asin, region);
    }
  });

  // Asia uses US ASIN on amzn.asia domain
  if (asins.us) {
    links['asia'] = buildAmazonUrl(asins.us, 'asia');
  }

  return links;
}

// ============================================
// HELPER FUNCTIONS
// ============================================

/**
 * Product ID aliases for backwards compatibility
 * Maps shorthand IDs to full product IDs
 */
const PRODUCT_ID_ALIASES: Record<string, string> = {
  // Supplements
  ashwagandha: 'ashwagandha_ksm66',
  creatine: 'creatine_mono',
  omega_3: 'omega3_fish_oil',
  zinc: 'zinc_picolinate',
  // Add more as needed
};

/**
 * Get product by ID (supports aliases)
 */
export function getGuideProductById(id: string): GuideProduct | undefined {
  // Resolve alias if it exists
  const resolvedId = PRODUCT_ID_ALIASES[id] || id;
  return GUIDE_PRODUCTS.find(p => p.id === resolvedId);
}

/**
 * Get all products in a category
 */
export function getGuideProductsByCategory(category: ProductCategory): GuideProduct[] {
  return GUIDE_PRODUCTS
    .filter(p => p.category === category)
    .sort((a, b) => a.priority - b.priority);
}

/**
 * Get all base stack products (essentials for everyone)
 */
export function getBaseStackProducts(): GuideProduct[] {
  return GUIDE_PRODUCTS
    .filter(p => p.isBaseStack)
    .sort((a, b) => a.priority - b.priority);
}

/**
 * Get products by priority level
 */
export function getGuideProductsByPriority(priority: number): GuideProduct[] {
  return GUIDE_PRODUCTS.filter(p => p.priority === priority);
}

/**
 * Get all unique categories with product counts
 */
export function getProductCategories(): Array<{ category: ProductCategory; count: number }> {
  const categories: ProductCategory[] = [
    'hygiene',
    'grooming',
    'skincare',
    'miscellaneous',
    'supplements',
    'hair',
    'beard',
    'teeth',
    'kbeauty',
    'hormonal',
    'surgery',
  ];

  return categories.map(category => ({
    category,
    count: GUIDE_PRODUCTS.filter(p => p.category === category).length,
  }));
}

/**
 * Get products by array of IDs (preserves order)
 */
export function getGuideProductsByIds(ids: string[]): GuideProduct[] {
  return ids
    .map(id => getGuideProductById(id))
    .filter((p): p is GuideProduct => p !== undefined);
}

/**
 * Search products by name or description
 */
export function searchGuideProducts(query: string): GuideProduct[] {
  const lowered = query.toLowerCase();
  return GUIDE_PRODUCTS.filter(p =>
    p.name.toLowerCase().includes(lowered) ||
    p.description.toLowerCase().includes(lowered) ||
    p.tagline.toLowerCase().includes(lowered) ||
    (p.brand && p.brand.toLowerCase().includes(lowered))
  );
}

/**
 * Get total product count
 */
export function getTotalProductCount(): number {
  return GUIDE_PRODUCTS.length;
}

/**
 * Get category display info
 */
export function getCategoryDisplayInfo(category: ProductCategory): {
  name: string;
  icon: string;
  description: string;
} {
  const info: Record<ProductCategory, { name: string; icon: string; description: string }> = {
    hygiene: {
      name: 'Hygiene',
      icon: 'Sparkles',
      description: 'Fundamentals of not repelling people',
    },
    grooming: {
      name: 'Grooming',
      icon: 'Scissors',
      description: 'Tools for precision face maintenance',
    },
    skincare: {
      name: 'Skincare',
      icon: 'Droplet',
      description: 'Your skin is your face. Treat it right.',
    },
    miscellaneous: {
      name: 'Miscellaneous',
      icon: 'Package',
      description: 'The supporting cast of your glow-up',
    },
    supplements: {
      name: 'Supplements',
      icon: 'Pill',
      description: 'Fill the gaps your diet is missing',
    },
    hair: {
      name: 'Hair',
      icon: 'Wind',
      description: 'The Big 3 and beyondâ€”save what you have',
    },
    beard: {
      name: 'Beard',
      icon: 'User',
      description: 'Grow it, groom it, own it',
    },
    teeth: {
      name: 'Teeth',
      icon: 'Smile',
      description: 'Your smile is worth more than you think',
    },
    kbeauty: {
      name: 'K-Beauty',
      icon: 'Sparkle',
      description: 'Glass skin protocols from Seoul',
    },
    hormonal: {
      name: 'Hormonal',
      icon: 'Heart',
      description: 'PCOS, hormonal acne, and balance',
    },
    surgery: {
      name: 'Surgery',
      icon: 'Stethoscope',
      description: 'Post-op recovery essentials',
    },
  };

  return info[category];
}

content.text: Now I have the context. Let me read all the guide files to validate them. I'll read them in batches:

1â†’/**
     2â†’ * Mindset & Beginner Mistakes Guide

     4â†’ */
     5â†’
     6â†’import { Guide } from '@/types/guides';
     7â†’
     8â†’export const mindsetGuide: Guide = {
     9â†’  id: 'mindset',
    10â†’  slug: 'mindset-mistakes',
    11â†’  title: 'Mindset & Beginner Mistakes',
    12â†’  subtitle: "The cope stops here",
    13â†’  description: "Before you spend a dime, fix the mental game. Most guys sabotage themselves before they even start.",
    14â†’  icon: 'Brain',
    15â†’  humorLevel: 'high',
    16â†’  estimatedReadTime: 8,
    17â†’  order: 1,
    18â†’  tags: ['mindset', 'beginners', 'fundamentals'],
    19â†’  relatedGuides: ['maintenance', 'body-fat'],
    20â†’  productIds: [],
    21â†’  forumCategory: 'anxiety',
    22â†’  heroMedia: {
    23â†’    id: 'mindset-hero',
    24â†’    type: 'image',
    25â†’    url: 'https://images.unsplash.com/photo-1507003211169-0a1dd7228f2d?w=1200&q=80',
    26â†’    alt: 'Focused mindset and determination',
    27â†’    placement: 'hero',
    28â†’  },
    29â†’  sections: [
    30â†’    {
    31â†’      id: 'intro',
    32â†’      title: 'The Real Talk',
    33â†’      humorLevel: 'high',
    34â†’      content: `You're here because you want to look better. Good. That's the first step.
    35â†’
    36â†’But here's what nobody tells you: **most guys fail not because they don't know what to do, but because their mindset is cooked from day one.**
    37â†’
    38â†’They're either:
    39â†’- Paralyzed by analysis (reading guides instead of taking action)
    40â†’- Expecting overnight results (then quitting after 2 weeks)
    41â†’- Comparing themselves to genetic outliers (and feeling defeated)
    42â†’- Looking for shortcuts (spoiler: there aren't any)
    43â†’
    44â†’This guide is about fixing that before you waste months spinning your wheels.`,
    45â†’      media: [
    46â†’        {
    47â†’          id: 'mindset-intro',
    48â†’          type: 'image',
    49â†’          url: 'https://images.unsplash.com/photo-1552674605-db6ffd4facb5?w=800&q=80',
    50â†’          alt: 'Man focused on goals',
    51â†’          caption: 'The mindset game starts before everything else',
    52â†’          placement: 'inline',
    53â†’        },
    54â†’        {
    55â†’          id: 'level-up-gif',
    56â†’          type: 'gif',
    57â†’          url: 'https://media.giphy.com/media/H9l0FtwC2hA3V7Bj5H/giphy.gif',
    58â†’          alt: 'Level Up pixel animation',
    59â†’          caption: 'Time to level up',
    60â†’          placement: 'inline',
    61â†’        },
    62â†’      ],
    63â†’    },
    64â†’    {

   143â†’      content: `There are no shortcuts. There are no hacks. There is no "one weird trick."

   164â†’      content: `You miss one gym session and think "welp, the whole week is ruined."

   185â†’      content: `You're researching jaw implants but you're at 22% body fat.

   209â†’      content: `Here's what the successful guys do:

/**
 * Mindset & Beginner Mistakes Guide
 * Humor Level: High (30%)
 */

import { Guide } from '@/types/guides';

export const mindsetGuide: Guide = {
  id: 'mindset',
  slug: 'mindset-mistakes',
  title: 'Mindset & Beginner Mistakes',
  subtitle: "The cope stops here",
  description: "Before you spend a dime, fix the mental game. Most guys sabotage themselves before they even start.",
  icon: 'Brain',
  humorLevel: 'high',
  estimatedReadTime: 8,
  order: 1,
  tags: ['mindset', 'beginners', 'fundamentals'],
  relatedGuides: ['maintenance', 'body-fat'],
  productIds: [],
  forumCategory: 'anxiety',
  heroMedia: {
    id: 'mindset-hero',
    type: 'image',
    url: 'https://images.unsplash.com/photo-1507003211169-0a1dd7228f2d?w=1200&q=80',
    alt: 'Focused mindset and determination',
    placement: 'hero',
  },
  sections: [
    {
      id: 'intro',
      title: 'The Real Talk',
      humorLevel: 'high',
      content: `You're here because you want to look better. Good. That's the first step.

But here's what nobody tells you: **most guys fail not because they don't know what to do, but because their mindset is cooked from day one.**

They're either:
- Paralyzed by analysis (reading guides instead of taking action)
- Expecting overnight results (then quitting after 2 weeks)
- Comparing themselves to genetic outliers (and feeling defeated)
- Looking for shortcuts (spoiler: there aren't any)

This guide is about fixing that before you waste months spinning your wheels.`,
      media: [
        {
          id: 'mindset-intro',
          type: 'image',
          url: 'https://images.unsplash.com/photo-1552674605-db6ffd4facb5?w=800&q=80',
          alt: 'Man focused on goals',
          caption: 'The mindset game starts before everything else',
          placement: 'inline',
        },
        {
          id: 'level-up-gif',
          type: 'gif',
          url: 'https://media.giphy.com/media/H9l0FtwC2hA3V7Bj5H/giphy.gif',
          alt: 'Level Up pixel animation',
          caption: 'Time to level up',
          placement: 'inline',
        },
      ],
    },
    {
      id: 'mistake-1-perfectionism',
      title: 'Mistake #1: Waiting for the "Perfect" Plan',
      humorLevel: 'high',
      content: `You've bookmarked 47 articles. You've saved 200 Instagram posts. You've downloaded 12 PDFs. You've done exactly **zero** actual work.

**This ain't it, chief.**

The perfect routine doesn't exist. There's no secret combination of products and exercises that will unlock chad-tier genetics. There's just consistent effort over time.

Here's the brutal truth: a mediocre plan executed consistently beats a perfect plan you never start.

**Action Step:** Pick ONE thing from this app to improve. Just one. Do it for 30 days before adding anything else.`,
      tips: [
        'Done is better than perfect',
        'Consistency beats intensity every single time',
        'Start before you feel ready'
      ],
      media: [
        {
          id: 'perfectionism-trap',
          type: 'image',
          url: 'https://images.unsplash.com/photo-1484480974693-6ca0a78fb36b?w=800&q=80',
          alt: 'Planning and action',
          caption: 'Stop planning, start doing',
          placement: 'inline',
        },
      ],
    },
    {
      id: 'mistake-2-timeline',
      title: 'Mistake #2: Expecting Fast Results',
      humorLevel: 'medium-high',
      content: `You started mewing yesterday and you're checking your jawline in the mirror this morning. Bro.

Real change takes **months to years**, depending on what you're working on:

| Change | Timeline |
|--------|----------|
| Better skin (routine) | 6-12 weeks |
| Body recomposition | 3-6 months |
| Posture improvement | 3-6 months |
| Hair regrowth (minox) | 6-12 months |
| Mewing (adults) | 1-2+ years |

**The guys who win are the ones who forget about results and just lock in on the process.**

Think about it: if you had started 6 months ago, you'd already be there. You didn't. So start now and stop checking daily.`,
      warnings: [
        'Taking progress photos daily will drive you insane',
        'Monthly or bi-monthly comparison photos are enough'
      ],
    },
    {
      id: 'mistake-3-comparison',
      title: 'Mistake #3: Comparing to Genetic Outliers',
      humorLevel: 'high',
      content: `You're comparing yourself to guys who:
- Won the genetic lottery
- Have professional lighting in every photo
- Are on gear and won't admit it
- Use filters/editing
- Got surgery and claim "just mewing bro"

**This is NPC behavior.**

Here's a better frame: you're not trying to become someone else. You're trying to mog your past self. That's it.

Your only competition is the guy you were 6 months ago. If he'd be jealous of where you are now, you're winning.`,
      tips: [
        'Mog your past self, not strangers on the internet',
        'Unfollow accounts that make you feel like garbage',
        'Follow for information, not comparison'
      ],
    },
    {
      id: 'mistake-4-shortcuts',
      title: 'Mistake #4: Looking for Shortcuts',
      humorLevel: 'medium-high',
      content: `There are no shortcuts. There are no hacks. There is no "one weird trick."

The internet is full of people trying to sell you things you don't need:
- Miracle supplements that do nothing
- Expensive gadgets that collect dust
- "Secret" techniques that are just repackaged basics

**Here's what actually works:**
1. Sleep 7-9 hours
2. Eat enough protein
3. Lift weights
4. Use sunscreen
5. Stay lean
6. Groom yourself

That's 90% of it. Everything else is optimization on top of this foundation. If you're not doing these six things consistently, nothing else matters.`,
    },
    {
      id: 'mistake-5-all-or-nothing',
      title: 'Mistake #5: All-or-Nothing Thinking',
      humorLevel: 'medium',
      content: `You miss one gym session and think "welp, the whole week is ruined."
You eat one bad meal and say "might as well order pizza for the rest of the week."
You skip your skincare once and abandon the routine entirely.

**This is self-sabotage with extra steps.**

Progress isn't linear. Life happens. The goal isn't perfectionâ€”it's **consistency over time**.

Missing one day means nothing. Missing one day, then letting it spiral into one week, then one month? That's the killer.

**The rule:** If you miss, just get back on track the next opportunity. No guilt, no drama. Just reset and continue.`,
      tips: [
        'One bad day is noise. One bad month is a pattern.',
        "Never miss twice in a rowâ€”that's the real rule",
        'Lower the bar if needed, but show up'
      ],
    },
    {
      id: 'mistake-6-money-before-basics',
      title: 'Mistake #6: Spending Money Before Basics',
      humorLevel: 'high',
      content: `You're researching jaw implants but you're at 22% body fat.
You want Botox but you've never worn sunscreen.
You're considering hair transplants but you sleep 5 hours a night.

**You're skipping chapters, my guy.**

Here's the priority order:
1. **Free tier:** Sleep, hydration, basic hygiene, mewing, posture
2. **Low cost ($20-50/mo):** Gym, skincare basics, grooming tools
3. **Medium cost ($50-200/mo):** Supplements, better products, minoxidil
4. **High cost ($500+):** Treatments, procedures, surgery

Don't level skip. The expensive stuff doesn't work if the foundation is garbage.

Surgery on a 25% body fat face is like putting a spoiler on a Honda Civic. Fix the car first.`,
      warnings: [
        "Surgery doesn't fix lifestyle problems",
        'Get to 12% body fat before considering facial procedures'
      ],
    },
    {
      id: 'the-real-strategy',
      title: 'The Actual Strategy That Works',
      humorLevel: 'medium',
      content: `Here's what the successful guys do:

**1. Accept the timeline**
You're playing a 1-2 year game minimum. Accept that now or quit.

**2. Build systems, not goals**
"I want a better jawline" is a goal. "I chew mastic gum for 20 minutes after every meal" is a system. Systems win.

**3. Track ruthlessly**
Take monthly photos. Same lighting, same angle, same expression. This is the only objective measure.

**4. Iterate slowly**
Add one new thing every 4-6 weeks. Not five things at once. You need to know what's actually working.

**5. Focus on the 80/20**
20% of actions produce 80% of results. For most guys:
- Getting lean (diet + exercise)
- Skincare (cleanser, moisturizer, sunscreen)
- Grooming (hair, brows, facial hair)

**Nail these before anything else.**`,
      tips: [
        'Progress compounds over time',
        'Small daily actions beat occasional big efforts',
        'Document everything so you can see the change'
      ],
      media: [
        {
          id: 'strategy-visual',
          type: 'image',
          url: 'https://images.unsplash.com/photo-1434596922112-19c563067271?w=800&q=80',
          alt: 'Progress and tracking',
          caption: 'Track ruthlessly, iterate slowly',
          placement: 'inline',
        },
      ],
    },
    {
      id: 'closing',
      title: 'Lock In',
      humorLevel: 'high',
      content: `The cope stops here. No more excuses. No more "I'll start Monday." No more blaming genetics.

You have all the information you need. This app, this guide, these toolsâ€”they're more than enough.

The only question is whether you're actually going to do the work or just read about it and go back to whatever you were doing before.

**Your move.**

Mog your past self. That's the whole game.`,
    },
  ],
};

1â†’/**

    41â†’      humorLevel: 'high',
    42â†’      content: `Here's something that might hurt: most guys walking around have absolutely no idea how many basic maintenance things they're neglecting.

    53â†’      id: 'daily-oral',
    54â†’      title: 'Daily: Oral Hygiene',
    55â†’      humorLevel: 'high',
    56â†’      content: `Your breath is out here committing war crimes and you don't even know it.
    57â†’
    58â†’**The Protocol:**
    59â†’1. **Brush 2x daily** â€” Electric toothbrush, 2 minutes minimum. If you're using a manual toothbrush in 2024, that's NPC behavior.
    60â†’2. **Floss daily** â€” Yes, actually. The stuff between your teeth is rotting. Get string floss or a water flosser.
    61â†’3. **Tongue scrape** â€” This is the secret weapon. 70% of bad breath comes from bacteria on your tongue. Takes 10 seconds, changes everything.
    62â†’
    63â†’**The Reality Check:**
    64â†’- You can't smell your own breath
    65â†’- Everyone's too polite to tell you

    67â†’- Fix it now`,

    72â†’        'Mouthwash is optional but flossing is mandatory'
    73â†’      ],
    74â†’      media: [
    75â†’        {
    76â†’          id: 'tongue-scraping',
    77â†’          type: 'image',
    78â†’          url: 'https://images.unsplash.com/photo-1606107557195-0e29a4b5b4aa?w=800&q=80',
    79â†’          alt: 'Oral hygiene and dental care products',
    80â†’          caption: 'Oral hygiene: brush, floss, scrape',
    81â†’          placement: 'inline',
    82â†’        },
    83â†’      ],
    84â†’    },
    85â†’    {
    86â†’      id: 'daily-lips',
    87â†’      title: 'Daily: Lip Care',
    88â†’      humorLevel: 'medium-high',
    89â†’      content: `Crusty, chapped lips are sabotaging your entire face. The fix costs $5.
    90â†’
    91â†’**Why This Matters:**
    92â†’Your lips are one of the first things people notice. Dry, cracked lips read as "doesn't take care of himself" instantly.
    93â†’
    94â†’**The Fix:**
    95â†’- Apply lip balm or Aquaphor morning and night
    96â†’- Reapply after eating or drinking
    97â†’- At night, use a heavier occlusive (Aquaphor > chapstick)
    98â†’
    99â†’**Common Mistakes:**
   100â†’- Licking your lips (makes it worse)
   101â†’- Flavored lip balms (you'll lick them)
   102â†’- Forgetting entirely (check your lips right now)
   103â†’
   104â†’**Pro tip:** Keep one by your bed, one in your pocket, one at your desk. The best lip balm is the one you actually use.`,
   105â†’      products: ['aquaphor_lip'],
   106â†’    },
   107â†’    {
   108â†’      id: 'weekly-nose-ear',

      id: 'beard-maintenance',
      title: 'Beard Maintenance & Growth',
      humorLevel: 'medium-high',
      content: `Whether you're trying to grow a beard or maintain one, here's what actually matters:

**If You Can Grow One:**

**Stubble (1-5mm):**
- Trim every 2-3 days
- This is often the most attractive option for most faces
- Clean neckline 2 fingers above Adam's apple
- Edge cheek line naturally

**Short Beard (5-10mm):**
- Trim weekly with guard
- Use beard oil after showering
- Keep edges sharp

**Full Beard (10mm+):**
- Wash with beard shampoo
- Apply beard oil or balm daily
- Comb/brush to train direction
- Trim every 1-2 weeks for shape
- Consider a barber for initial shaping

**If You CAN'T Grow One (Yet):**

The Minoxidil beard protocol works for many guys:
1. Apply minoxidil 5% to cheeks 2x daily
2. Wait 6-24 months (yes, it takes time)
3. Vellus hairs â†’ Terminal hairs
4. Once terminal, effects are permanent
5. Add dermarolling 0.5mm weekly for better absorption

**Important:** This is off-label use. Results vary. Most guys see significant improvement, but genetics still matter.

**Patchy Beard Solutions:**
- Let it grow longerâ€”length hides patches
- Strategic trimming to balance density
- Focus on stubble length if very patchy
- Some patches fill in over time (give it 3-6 months)

We'll have a full beard growth guide with protocols coming soon.`,
      tips: [

**This is the baseline.** This is what separates "that guy takes care of himself" from "what's that smell?"

Lock in.`,

    33â†’      humorLevel: 'high',
    34â†’      content: `At 18% body fat, you're hoping good lighting saves you. At 11%, you ARE the good lighting.
    35â†’
    36â†’Here's the brutal truth: you can have god-tier bone structure, but if it's buried under a layer of subcutaneous fat, you're frauding yourself out of your own genetics.
    37â†’
    38â†’---
    39â†’
    40â†’## Lean is life. Your jawline knows it.
    41â†’
    42â†’This isn't about being skinny. It's about being lean enough that your facial features actually show:
    43â†’
    44â†’- **Jawline definition** â€” The #1 facial aesthetic improvement
    45â†’- **Cheekbone projection** â€” Creates that hollow, chiseled look

    69â†’| **20%+** | Soft everywhere, no definition | Buried jaw, soft cheeks, possible double chin |
    70â†’| **17-20%** | Some definition in good lighting | Jaw visible but soft, face holds water |
    71â†’| **14-17%** | Visible abs in good lighting | Decent definition, not optimal |
    72â†’| **12-14%** | Abs visible standing | Good facial definition, jaw pops |
    73â†’| **10-12%** | Clear 6-pack, veins showing | Excellent definition, cheekbones visible |
    74â†’| **8-10%** | Shredded, stage-ready | Maximum facial definition |
    75â†’| **<8%** | Competition lean | Hard to maintain, not realistic long-term |
    76â†’
    77â†’---
    78â†’
    79â†’## The Sweet Spot: 10-14%
    80â†’
    81â†’This is where you're lean enough for facial definition but not so lean that you're constantly hungry, weak, and irritable.

   103â†’      id: 'where-fat-stores',
   104â†’      title: 'Where Fat Stores (And Why Your Face Suffers)',
   105â†’      humorLevel: 'medium-high',
   106â†’      content: `Fat distribution is genetic, but there's a general pattern:
   107â†’
   108â†’---
   109â†’
   110â†’## First to Store (Last to Lose)
   111â†’
   112â†’These are the stubborn areas:
   113â†’
   114â†’- Lower belly
   115â†’- Love handles
   116â†’- Lower back
   117â†’- **Face (buccal area, under chin)**
   118â†’
   119â†’## Last to Store (First to Lose)
   120â†’
   121â†’These lean out quickly:
   122â†’
   123â†’- Arms
   124â†’- Upper chest
   125â†’- Calves
   126â†’
   127â†’---
   128â†’
   129â†’## What This Means
   130â†’
   131â†’Your face is often one of the **LAST** places to lean out.
   132â†’
   133â†’This is why guys at 18% think *"I'm not even that fat"* while their jaw is still buried.
   134â†’
   135â†’## The Face Tax
   136â†’
   137â†’If you carry fat in your face (many people do), you might need to get leaner than average to see facial definition.
   138â†’
   139â†’Someone might have a visible 6-pack at 14%, but their face doesn't pop until 11%.
   140â†’
   141â†’It's not fair. It's genetics. Work with it.`,

   156â†’      humorLevel: 'medium',
   157â†’      content: `Most methods are garbage. Here's the hierarchy:
   158â†’
   159â†’---
   160â†’
   161â†’## Tier 1: DEXA Scan (Most Accurate)
   162â†’
   163â†’- $50-150 at clinics
   164â†’- Tells you exactly where fat is distributed
   165â†’- Worth getting once to establish baseline
   166â†’
   167â†’## Tier 2: Calipers (Decent If Done Right)
   168â†’
   169â†’- $15 for calipers
   170â†’- 7-site measurement protocol
   171â†’- Requires practice and consistency
   172â†’- Â±3% error margin

   174â†’## Tier 3: Navy Method (Free, Okay)
   175â†’

   177â†’- Formula-based estimate
   178â†’- Better than nothing
   179â†’
   180â†’## Tier 4: Bioelectrical Impedance (Mostly Useless)
   181â†’
   182â†’- Those scales and gym machines
   183â†’- Varies wildly based on hydration
   184â†’- Can be off by 5-10%
   185â†’- Only useful for tracking trends, not absolute numbers
   186â†’

   188â†’
   189â†’- Compare to reference photos at known body fat %
   190â†’- Track progress over time
   191â†’- Lighting consistent, same time of day
   192â†’

   195â†’**Recommendation:** Get a DEXA scan once, then track via photos and waist measurement.`,

   198â†’    {
   199â†’      id: 'the-math',
   200â†’      title: 'The Fat Loss Equation',
   201â†’      humorLevel: 'medium',
   202â†’      content: `This is simple math. Not easy, but simple.
   203â†’
   204â†’---
   205â†’
   206â†’## The Formula
   207â†’
   208â†’> **Calories In < Calories Out = Fat Loss**
   209â†’
   210â†’That's it. There's no metabolic magic. No foods that "burn fat." No supplements that override physics.
   211â†’
   212â†’---
   213â†’
   214â†’## Setting Your Deficit
   215â†’
   216â†’1. Calculate maintenance calories (TDEE)
   217â†’2. Subtract 300-500 calories
   218â†’3. Adjust based on results
   219â†’
   220â†’## Rate of Loss
   221â†’
   222â†’| Goal | Rate | Weekly Deficit |
   223â†’|------|------|----------------|
   224â†’| **Sustainable** | 0.5-1% of bodyweight/week | 300-500 cal/day |
   225â†’| **Aggressive** | 1-1.5% of bodyweight/week | 500-750 cal/day |
   226â†’| **Too Fast** | >1.5% of bodyweight/week | Muscle loss risk |
   227â†’
   228â†’---
   229â†’
   230â†’## For a 180lb guy:
   231â†’
   232â†’- **Target:** 0.9-1.8 lbs per week
   233â†’- **Deficit:** 450-900 calories daily
   234â†’- **Timeline:** 10 lbs of fat takes 5-10 weeks minimum
   235â†’
   236â†’**The Reality:** Most guys try to cut too fast, lose muscle, feel like death, and rebound. Don't be that guy.`,
   237â†’      tips: [

   239â†’        'Weigh daily, average weekly (weight fluctuates)',
   240â†’        "If you're not losing, you're eating more than you think",
   241â†’      ],
   242â†’    },
   243â†’    {
   244â†’      id: 'protein-priority',
   245â†’      title: 'Protein: The Non-Negotiable',
   246â†’      humorLevel: 'medium-high',
   247â†’      content: `When cutting, protein is king. Everything else is secondary.
   248â†’
   249â†’---
   250â†’
   251â†’## Why Protein Matters
   252â†’
   253â†’- **Preserves muscle mass** during deficit
   254â†’- **Most satiating** macronutrient (keeps you full)
   255â†’- **Highest thermic effect** (burns calories to digest)
   256â†’- **Prevents** the "skinny fat" look
   257â†’
   258â†’## How Much
   259â†’
   260â†’| Bodyweight | Daily Protein Target |
   261â†’|------------|---------------------|
   262â†’| 150 lbs | 120-150g |
   263â†’| 180 lbs | 144-180g |
   264â†’| 200 lbs | 160-200g |
   265â†’| 220 lbs | 176-220g |
   266â†’
   267â†’Yes, this seems like a lot. Yes, it's necessary.
   268â†’
   269â†’---
   270â†’
   271â†’## Example Day (180g protein)
   272â†’
   273â†’| Meal | Foods | Protein |
   274â†’|------|-------|---------|
   275â†’| **Breakfast** | 4 eggs + greek yogurt | 40g |
   276â†’| **Lunch** | 8oz chicken breast + cottage cheese | 60g |
   277â†’| **Dinner** | 8oz salmon + protein shake | 60g |
   278â†’| **Snack** | Protein bar | 20g |
   279â†’| **TOTAL** | | **180g** |
   280â†’
   281â†’If you're consistently under on protein, you're going to lose muscle and end up looking worse at the same weight.`,
   282â†’      products: ['creatine_mono'],
   283â†’    },
   284â†’    {
   285â†’      id: 'water-and-bloat',
   286â†’      title: 'Water Weight and Facial Bloat',
   287â†’      humorLevel: 'high',
   288â†’      content: `You're not drinking enough water. Yes, you.
   289â†’
   290â†’Your face is literally retaining fluid to compensate.
   291â†’
   292â†’---
   293â†’
   294â†’## The Paradox
   295â†’
   296â†’> Drink **MORE** water to hold **LESS** water.
   297â†’
   298â†’Your body retains fluid when dehydrated.
   299â†’
   300â†’## The Protocol
   301â†’
   302â†’| Bodyweight | Daily Water Target |
   303â†’|------------|-------------------|
   304â†’| 150 lbs | 75 oz (2.2L) |
   305â†’| 180 lbs | 90 oz (2.7L) |
   306â†’| 200 lbs | 100 oz (3L) |
   307â†’| 220 lbs | 110 oz (3.3L) |
   308â†’
   309â†’Add more if training or sweating.
   310â†’
   311â†’---
   312â†’
   313â†’## What Causes Facial Bloat
   314â†’
   315â†’| Cause | Effect | Fix |
   316â†’|-------|--------|-----|
   317â†’| **Sodium** | High salt = water retention | Keep moderate, not zero |
   318â†’| **Alcohol** | Dehydrates, then overcompensates | Limit or eliminate |
   319â†’| **Carbs** | Each gram stores 3-4g of water | Expected, not bad |
   320â†’| **Sleep deprivation** | Cortisol = water retention | Get 7-8 hours |
   321â†’| **Dehydration** | Counter-intuitive but true | Drink more water |
   322â†’
   323â†’---
   324â†’
   325â†’## The Morning Difference
   326â†’
   327â†’Ever notice you look leaner in the morning?
   328â†’
   329â†’You're slightly dehydrated after 8 hours without water. This is why fighters cut water weightâ€”it makes a visible difference.
   330â†’
   331â†’For consistent leanness, stay consistently hydrated and keep sodium moderate.`,
   332â†’      products: ['water_jug'],
   333â†’      tips: [
   334â†’        'Drink a full glass of water immediately upon waking',
   335â†’        'Cut sodium 24-48 hours before photos for temporary tightness',
   336â†’        "Alcohol is the worst for next-day face bloat",
   337â†’      ],
   338â†’      media: [
   339â†’        {
   340â†’          id: 'bloat-comparison',
   341â†’          type: 'image',
   342â†’          url: 'https://images.unsplash.com/photo-1548690312-e3b507d8c110?w=800&q=80',

   349â†’    {
   350â†’      id: 'timeline',
   351â†’      title: 'Realistic Cutting Timeline',
   352â†’      humorLevel: 'medium',
   353â†’      content: `Let's set realistic expectations:
   354â†’
   355â†’---
   356â†’
   357â†’## Starting Point: 20% Body Fat (180lb guy)
   358â†’
   359â†’- **Goal:** 12% body fat
   360â†’- **Fat to lose:** ~15 lbs
   361â†’- **Timeline:** 10-15 weeks (doing it right)
   362â†’
   363â†’---
   364â†’
   365â†’## Week by Week Progress
   366â†’
   367â†’| Weeks | What Happens | What You See |
   368â†’|-------|--------------|--------------|
   369â†’| **1-2** | Water weight drops | Scale moves fast, exciting |
   370â†’| **3-6** | Steady fat loss | Starting to see changes |
   371â†’| **7-10** | Face starts tightening | Jaw appearing, cheekbones hint |
   372â†’| **11-15** | Final stubborn fat burns | Face pops, transformation complete |
   373â†’
   374â†’---
   375â†’
   376â†’## The Trap
   377â†’
   378â†’Weeks 6-10 are where most guys quit.
   379â†’
   380â†’Scale slows, you don't see daily changes, and pizza sounds really good.
   381â†’
   382â†’## The Reality
   383â†’
   384â†’> Fat loss in the face often happens in the **final phase**.
   385â†’
   386â†’You might look the same for weeks, then suddenly *"damn, there's my jawline."*
   387â†’
   388â†’Be patient. Trust the deficit. Don't quit in the middle of the transformation.`,
   389â†’      warnings: [
   390â†’        "Don't cut harder because the scale slowedâ€”you'll lose muscle",
   391â†’        'Take weekly photos in the same conditions for accurate comparison',
   392â†’      ],

   402â†’      ],
   403â†’    },
   404â†’    {
   405â†’      id: 'maintaining',
   406â†’      title: 'Maintaining Lean (The Hard Part)',
   407â†’      humorLevel: 'medium',
   408â†’      content: `Getting lean is one thing. Staying lean is another.
   409â†’
   410â†’---
   411â†’
   412â†’## Why Maintenance Is Hard
   413â†’
   414â†’- Hunger hormones increase after cutting
   415â†’- Metabolism adapts (slightly) to lower calories
   416â†’- One vacation can undo weeks of progress
   417â†’- Life happens
   418â†’
   419â†’## The Strategy
   420â†’
   421â†’1. **Reverse diet** â€” Slowly increase calories after cutting
   422â†’2. **Stay active** â€” NEAT (daily movement) matters as much as gym
   423â†’3. **Keep tracking** â€” At least loosely, forever
   424â†’4. **Set a ceiling** â€” "I never go above 15%" as a rule
   425â†’
   426â†’---
   427â†’
   428â†’## The Buffer Zone
   429â†’
   430â†’Cutting to 11% then maintaining at 13% is easier than trying to stay at 11% year-round.
   431â†’
   432â†’Give yourself a 2-3% buffer for life fluctuations.
   433â†’
   434â†’## The Long Game
   435â†’
   436â†’> Most guys yo-yo because they treat cutting as temporary.
   437â†’
   438â†’Make leanness part of your identity, not a phase.`,
   439â†’    },
   440â†’    {
   441â†’      id: 'face-fat-timeline',
   442â†’      title: 'Face Fat Timeline by Body Fat %',
   443â†’      humorLevel: 'medium-high',
   444â†’      content: `When does the face actually lean out? Here's the brutal truth by body fat percentage:
   445â†’
   446â†’**The Face Fat Timeline:**
   447â†’
   448â†’| Body Fat % | Face Status | What You See |
   449â†’|------------|-------------|--------------|
   450â†’| **25%+** | Maximum bloat | Round face, double chin likely, jaw completely hidden |
   451â†’| **22-25%** | Soft face | Face is round, no definition, chipmunk mode |
   452â†’| **18-22%** | Still soft | Jaw exists but is soft, some face fat visible |
   453â†’| **15-18%** | Improving | Jaw becoming defined, some cheek fat remaining |
   454â†’| **12-15%** | Good definition | Jaw pops, cheekbones starting to show, face leaning out |
   455â†’| **10-12%** | Excellent | Hollow cheeks appearing, strong jaw, model tier face |
   456â†’| **8-10%** | Maximum definition | Chiseled, veins in face possible, not sustainable |
   457â†’
   458â†’**The Critical Threshold:**
   459â†’For most men, facial definition really kicks in between **12-15%**. If you're 18% and wondering why your face still looks soft despite visible abs in good lightingâ€”this is why.
   460â†’
   461â†’**Why Your Face Is Last:**
   462â†’Your body prioritizes fat storage in the face and midsection for protection and hormone regulation. These are the "safe" areas to store reserves. When cutting, your body pulls from "easy" areas first (arms, calves) and face fat last.
   463â†’
   464â†’**The Individual Factor:**
   465â†’Some guys have lean faces at 16%. Others need to hit 11% before the jaw pops. This is geneticsâ€”work with what you have, not against it.
   466â†’
   467â†’**The Math:**
   468â†’If your face doesn't lean out until 12%, and you're currently 20%, that's roughly **16 weeks of cutting** at 0.5% body fat loss per week. Set your expectations accordingly.`,
   469â†’      media: [
   470â†’        {
   471â†’          id: 'bf-face-progression',

   474â†’          alt: 'Lean face definition example',
   475â†’          caption: 'The same bone structure reveals itself at lower body fat',
   476â†’          placement: 'inline',
   477â†’        },
   478â†’      ],
   479â†’    },
   480â†’    {
   481â†’      id: 'fat-loss-order',
   482â†’      title: 'Where Fat Disappears First (Gender Differences)',
   483â†’      humorLevel: 'medium',
   484â†’      content: `Fat loss order is largely genetic, but there are predictable patterns by gender:
   485â†’
   486â†’**Men's Fat Loss Order:**
   487â†’
   488â†’| Order | Area | When It Goes |
   489â†’|-------|------|--------------|

   491â†’| 2nd | Upper back | Early cut |
   492â†’| 3rd | Chest | Mid cut |
   493â†’| 4th | Upper abdomen | Mid-late cut |
   494â†’| 5th | Lower abdomen | Late cut |
   495â†’| 6th | Love handles | Very late |
   496â†’| 7th | **Face, chin** | Often LAST |
   497â†’
   498â†’Men typically store fat in the midsection (visceral) and face. The lower belly and face are usually the final bastions.
   499â†’

   501â†’

   504â†’| 1st | Upper body, arms | Early |
   505â†’| 2nd | Back | Early-mid |
   506â†’| 3rd | Face | Often earlier than men |
   507â†’| 4th | Upper legs | Mid cut |
   508â†’| 5th | Hips, butt | Late |
   509â†’| 6th | Lower belly | Very late |
   510â†’| 7th | Inner thighs | Often LAST |
   511â†’
   512â†’Women store fat in hips, thighs, and butt for reproductive reasons. These areas are hormonally protected and go last.
   513â†’
   514â†’**The Implications:**
   515â†’- **Men:** Your face may stay soft until you're quite lean overall. Keep going.
   516â†’- **Women:** Your face often leans out faster, but lower body holds on longer.
   517â†’
   518â†’**Stubborn Fat Science:**
   519â†’"Stubborn" fat areas have more alpha-2 receptors, which resist fat release. These areas also have poor blood flow. This is why targeted fat loss ("spot reduction") doesn't workâ€”you can't force fat cells to release based on where you exercise.
   520â†’
   521â†’The only solution is overall fat loss until you reach your stubborn areas.`,
   522â†’    },
   523â†’    {
   524â†’      id: 'stubborn-fat-solutions',
   525â†’      title: 'Stubborn Fat Solutions (When Diet Isn\'t Enough)',
   526â†’      humorLevel: 'medium',
   527â†’      content: `What if you're lean everywhere except one problem area? Here are the options:
   528â†’
   529â†’**First: Are You Actually Lean?**
   530â†’Be honest. Most people who think they have "stubborn fat" are just not lean enough yet. Get to 10-12% body fat (men) or 18-20% (women) before considering other options.
   531â†’
   532â†’**If You're Genuinely Lean but Have Stubborn Areas:**
   533â†’
   534â†’**Option 1: Fasted Cardio + Yohimbine (Budget)**
   535â†’- Fasted morning cardio can preferentially target stubborn fat
   536â†’- Yohimbine HCL blocks alpha-2 receptors
   537â†’- Take 0.2mg/kg bodyweight before fasted cardio
   538â†’- Must be in a fasted state (no insulin present)
   539â†’- Stimulantâ€”not for everyone
   540â†’
   541â†’**Option 2: CoolSculpting / Cryolipolysis ($$$)**
   542â†’- Freezes and kills fat cells
   543â†’- 20-25% fat reduction per session
   544â†’- Multiple sessions needed
   545â†’- Cost: $600-1,200 per area
   546â†’- Results in 2-3 months
   547â†’- Non-invasive
   548â†’
   549â†’**Option 3: Kybella (Chin Fat Specifically) ($$)**
   550â†’- Injectable for submental fat (double chin)
   551â†’- Dissolves fat cells permanently
   552â†’- 2-4 sessions needed
   553â†’- Cost: $600-1,200 per session
   554â†’- Swelling for 1-2 weeks post-treatment
   555â†’
   556â†’**Option 4: Liposuction (Permanent, $$$$)**
   557â†’
   558â†’The nuclear option for stubborn fat. Here's what you need to know:
   559â†’
   560â†’| Factor | Details |
   561â†’|--------|---------|
   562â†’| **Best For** | Localized fat deposits that don't respond to diet |
   563â†’| **Common Areas** | Chin, love handles, lower abs, inner thighs |
   564â†’| **Cost** | $3,000-$10,000+ per area (USA) |
   565â†’| **Recovery** | 1-2 weeks off work, 4-6 weeks to see results |
   566â†’| **Results** | Permanent fat cell removal (cells can't return) |
   567â†’| **Caveat** | You can still gain fat in remaining cells |
   568â†’
   569â†’**Types of Liposuction:**
   570â†’- **Traditional:** Suction through cannula
   571â†’- **VASER:** Ultrasound-assisted, less bruising
   572â†’- **SmartLipo:** Laser-assisted, tighter skin
   573â†’- **AirSculpt:** Minimal downtime, premium cost
   574â†’
   575â†’**Critical Point:**
   576â†’Liposuction is NOT a weight loss procedure. It's for body contouring when you're already lean. If you're 20%+ body fat, diet first.
   577â†’
   578â†’**Medical Tourism:**
   579â†’Many people get lipo abroad at 30-60% lower cost. Popular destinations: Mexico, Turkey, Colombia. Research your surgeon thoroughly.`,
   580â†’      warnings: [
   581â†’        'Liposuction at high body fat % leads to uneven results',
   582â†’        'Fat can redistribute to other areas if you gain weight post-lipo',
   583â†’        'Always verify surgeon credentials and see real before/afters'
   584â†’      ],
   585â†’    },
   586â†’    {
   587â†’      id: 'common-mistakes',
   588â†’      title: 'Common Cutting Mistakes',
   589â†’      humorLevel: 'high',
   590â†’      content: `Don't be this guy:
   591â†’
   592â†’---
   593â†’
   594â†’## Mistake 1: Cutting Too Fast
   595â†’
   596â†’*"I'll just eat 1200 calories and do 2 hours of cardio."*
   597â†’
   598â†’**Result:** Lose muscle, crash metabolism, binge, end up fatter than before.
   599â†’
   600â†’---
   601â†’
   602â†’## Mistake 2: Ignoring Protein
   603â†’
   604â†’*"I'm just not going to eat much."*
   605â†’
   606â†’**Result:** Skinny-fat physique, lost the muscle, kept the face fat.
   607â†’
   608â†’---
   609â†’
   610â†’## Mistake 3: Weekend Cheats
   611â†’
   612â†’*"I was good all week!"*
   613â†’
   614â†’**Result:** 3500 calorie surplus Saturday-Sunday wipes out the weekly deficit.
   615â†’
   616â†’---
   617â†’
   618â†’## Mistake 4: Drinking Calories
   619â†’
   620â†’*"But it's just juice/beer/coffee drinks."*
   621â†’
   622â†’**Result:** 500+ invisible calories daily, no satiety, confused why scale won't move.
   623â†’
   624â†’---
   625â†’
   626â†’## Mistake 5: No Resistance Training
   627â†’
   628â†’*"I just need to do cardio to lose weight."*
   629â†’
   630â†’**Result:** Lost 20 lbsâ€”15 of muscle. Now you're a smaller, softer version of yourself.
   631â†’
   632â†’---
   633â†’
   634â†’## Mistake 6: Obsessing Over the Scale
   635â†’
   636â†’*"I gained 2 lbs overnight, I'm done!"*
   637â†’
   638â†’**Result:** Water fluctuation caused a mental breakdown. Real progress lost in the noise.
   639â†’
   640â†’---
   641â†’
   642â†’Avoid these and you're ahead of 90% of people trying to cut.`,
   643â†’    },
   644â†’    {
   645â†’      id: 'action-plan',
   646â†’      title: 'Your Action Plan',
   647â†’      humorLevel: 'medium',
   648â†’      content: `Here's exactly what to do:
   649â†’
   650â†’---
   651â†’
   652â†’## Step 1: Establish Baseline
   653â†’
   654â†’- Get a DEXA scan or estimate body fat from photos
   655â†’- Calculate TDEE (plenty of calculators online)
   656â†’- Take photos in consistent lighting
   657â†’
   658â†’## Step 2: Set Up Tracking
   659â†’
   660â†’- Download a calorie tracking app
   661â†’- Get a food scale (non-negotiable for accuracy)
   662â†’- Set protein and calorie targets
   663â†’
   664â†’## Step 3: Start the Cut
   665â†’
   666â†’- 300-500 calorie deficit
   667â†’- Hit protein daily (0.8-1g/lb)
   668â†’- Lift weights 3-4x per week (don't just do cardio)
   669â†’
   670â†’## Step 4: Monitor and Adjust
   671â†’
   672â†’- Weigh daily, average weekly
   673â†’- If not losing after 2 weeks, reduce by 100-200 calories
   674â†’- Take weekly photos in same conditions
   675â†’
   676â†’## Step 5: Be Patient
   677â†’
   678â†’- Expect 10-15 weeks for a significant cut
   679â†’- Facial changes come lastâ€”don't quit early
   680â†’- Adjust timeline based on actual progress
   681â†’
   682â†’---
   683â†’
   684â†’## Your face will thank you. Lock in.`,
   685â†’      products: ['food_scale'],
   686â†’    },
   687â†’  ],
   688â†’};
   689â†’

/**
 * Body Fat Mastery Guide

 */

import { Guide } from '@/types/guides';

export const bodyFatGuide: Guide = {
  id: 'body-fat',
  slug: 'body-fat-mastery',
  title: 'Body Fat Mastery',
  subtitle: "Your jawline is in there somewhereâ€”go find it",
  description: "The single biggest lever for facial aesthetics. Going from 18% to 12% body fat transforms your face.",
  icon: 'TrendingDown',
  humorLevel: 'medium-high',
  estimatedReadTime: 12,
  order: 3,
  tags: ['body-fat', 'cutting', 'diet', 'facial-aesthetics'],
  relatedGuides: ['diet', 'v-taper', 'training'],
  productIds: ['food_scale', 'creatine_mono'],
  forumCategory: 'face-fat',
  heroMedia: {
    id: 'bodyfat-hero',
    type: 'image',
    url: 'https://images.unsplash.com/photo-1571019613454-1cb2f99b2d8b?w=1200&q=80',
    alt: 'Body fat transformation showing facial definition improvement',
    placement: 'hero',
  },
  sections: [
    {
      id: 'intro',
      title: 'The Truth About Body Fat and Your Face',
      humorLevel: 'high',
      content: `At 18% body fat, you're hoping good lighting saves you. At 11%, you ARE the good lighting.

Here's the brutal truth: you can have god-tier bone structure, but if it's buried under a layer of subcutaneous fat, you're frauding yourself out of your own genetics.

---

## Lean is life. Your jawline knows it.

This isn't about being skinny. It's about being lean enough that your facial features actually show:

- **Jawline definition** â€” The #1 facial aesthetic improvement
- **Cheekbone projection** â€” Creates that hollow, chiseled look
- **Under-eye area** â€” No puffy fat pads
- **Neck/chin separation** â€” Clean, sharp profile

Most guys have never seen their own bone structure because they've never been lean enough.`,
      media: [
        {
          id: 'face-fat-comparison',
          type: 'image',
          url: 'https://images.unsplash.com/photo-1583454110551-21f2fa2afe61?w=800&q=80',
          alt: 'Lean athletic physique showing definition',
          caption: 'The same bone structure at 18% vs 12% body fat',
          placement: 'inline',
        },
      ],
    },
    {
      id: 'bf-ranges',
      title: 'Body Fat Percentage Breakdown',
      humorLevel: 'medium',
      content: `Let's be honest about what each range actually looks like:

| Body Fat % | What You See | Face Impact |
|------------|--------------|-------------|
| **20%+** | Soft everywhere, no definition | Buried jaw, soft cheeks, possible double chin |
| **17-20%** | Some definition in good lighting | Jaw visible but soft, face holds water |
| **14-17%** | Visible abs in good lighting | Decent definition, not optimal |
| **12-14%** | Abs visible standing | Good facial definition, jaw pops |
| **10-12%** | Clear 6-pack, veins showing | Excellent definition, cheekbones visible |
| **8-10%** | Shredded, stage-ready | Maximum facial definition |
| **<8%** | Competition lean | Hard to maintain, not realistic long-term |

---

## The Sweet Spot: 10-14%

This is where you're lean enough for facial definition but not so lean that you're constantly hungry, weak, and irritable.

Most guys should aim for this range.

Below 10% is diminishing returns unless you're competing or doing a photoshoot.`,
      tips: [
        'Take photos in neutral lighting to assessâ€”bathroom mirror lighting lies',
        'Measure waist circumference as a simple tracking metric',
        'DEXA scans are the gold standard for accuracy',
      ],
      media: [
        {
          id: 'bf-visual-guide',
          type: 'image',
          url: 'https://www.builtlean.com/wp-content/uploads/2012/09/body-fat-percentage-men-759x1024.jpg',
          alt: 'Male body fat percentage visual comparison chart',
          caption: 'Visual guide: What each body fat percentage actually looks like',
          placement: 'inline',
        },
      ],
    },
    {
      id: 'where-fat-stores',
      title: 'Where Fat Stores (And Why Your Face Suffers)',
      humorLevel: 'medium-high',
      content: `Fat distribution is genetic, but there's a general pattern:

---

## First to Store (Last to Lose)

These are the stubborn areas:

- Lower belly
- Love handles
- Lower back
- **Face (buccal area, under chin)**

## Last to Store (First to Lose)

These lean out quickly:

- Arms
- Upper chest
- Calves

---

## What This Means

Your face is often one of the **LAST** places to lean out.

This is why guys at 18% think *"I'm not even that fat"* while their jaw is still buried.

## The Face Tax

If you carry fat in your face (many people do), you might need to get leaner than average to see facial definition.

Someone might have a visible 6-pack at 14%, but their face doesn't pop until 11%.

It's not fair. It's genetics. Work with it.`,
      media: [
        {
          id: 'fat-distribution',
          type: 'image',
          url: 'https://images.unsplash.com/photo-1571019614242-c5c5dee9f50b?w=800&q=80',
          alt: 'Athlete with lean physique',
          caption: 'Common fat storage patterns - face fat is often the last to go',
          placement: 'inline',
        },
      ],
    },
    {
      id: 'measuring',
      title: 'How to Actually Measure Body Fat',
      humorLevel: 'medium',
      content: `Most methods are garbage. Here's the hierarchy:

---

## Tier 1: DEXA Scan (Most Accurate)

- $50-150 at clinics
- Tells you exactly where fat is distributed
- Worth getting once to establish baseline

## Tier 2: Calipers (Decent If Done Right)

- $15 for calipers
- 7-site measurement protocol
- Requires practice and consistency
- Â±3% error margin

## Tier 3: Navy Method (Free, Okay)

- Uses neck and waist measurements
- Formula-based estimate
- Better than nothing

## Tier 4: Bioelectrical Impedance (Mostly Useless)

- Those scales and gym machines
- Varies wildly based on hydration
- Can be off by 5-10%
- Only useful for tracking trends, not absolute numbers

## Tier 5: Mirror + Photos (Subjective But Real)

- Compare to reference photos at known body fat %
- Track progress over time
- Lighting consistent, same time of day

---

**Recommendation:** Get a DEXA scan once, then track via photos and waist measurement.`,
      products: ['food_scale'],
    },
    {
      id: 'the-math',
      title: 'The Fat Loss Equation',
      humorLevel: 'medium',
      content: `This is simple math. Not easy, but simple.

---

## The Formula

> **Calories In < Calories Out = Fat Loss**

That's it. There's no metabolic magic. No foods that "burn fat." No supplements that override physics.

---

## Setting Your Deficit

1. Calculate maintenance calories (TDEE)
2. Subtract 300-500 calories
3. Adjust based on results

## Rate of Loss

| Goal | Rate | Weekly Deficit |
|------|------|----------------|
| **Sustainable** | 0.5-1% of bodyweight/week | 300-500 cal/day |
| **Aggressive** | 1-1.5% of bodyweight/week | 500-750 cal/day |
| **Too Fast** | >1.5% of bodyweight/week | Muscle loss risk |

---

## For a 180lb guy:

- **Target:** 0.9-1.8 lbs per week
- **Deficit:** 450-900 calories daily
- **Timeline:** 10 lbs of fat takes 5-10 weeks minimum

**The Reality:** Most guys try to cut too fast, lose muscle, feel like death, and rebound. Don't be that guy.`,
      tips: [
        '500 calorie deficit = ~1 lb fat loss per week',
        'Weigh daily, average weekly (weight fluctuates)',
        "If you're not losing, you're eating more than you think",
      ],
    },
    {
      id: 'protein-priority',
      title: 'Protein: The Non-Negotiable',
      humorLevel: 'medium-high',
      content: `When cutting, protein is king. Everything else is secondary.

---

## Why Protein Matters

- **Preserves muscle mass** during deficit
- **Most satiating** macronutrient (keeps you full)
- **Highest thermic effect** (burns calories to digest)
- **Prevents** the "skinny fat" look

## How Much

| Bodyweight | Daily Protein Target |
|------------|---------------------|
| 150 lbs | 120-150g |
| 180 lbs | 144-180g |
| 200 lbs | 160-200g |
| 220 lbs | 176-220g |

Yes, this seems like a lot. Yes, it's necessary.

---

## Example Day (180g protein)

| Meal | Foods | Protein |
|------|-------|---------|
| **Breakfast** | 4 eggs + greek yogurt | 40g |
| **Lunch** | 8oz chicken breast + cottage cheese | 60g |
| **Dinner** | 8oz salmon + protein shake | 60g |
| **Snack** | Protein bar | 20g |
| **TOTAL** | | **180g** |

If you're consistently under on protein, you're going to lose muscle and end up looking worse at the same weight.`,
      products: ['creatine_mono'],
    },
    {
      id: 'water-and-bloat',
      title: 'Water Weight and Facial Bloat',
      humorLevel: 'high',
      content: `You're not drinking enough water. Yes, you.

Your face is literally retaining fluid to compensate.

---

## The Paradox

> Drink **MORE** water to hold **LESS** water.

Your body retains fluid when dehydrated.

## The Protocol

| Bodyweight | Daily Water Target |
|------------|-------------------|
| 150 lbs | 75 oz (2.2L) |
| 180 lbs | 90 oz (2.7L) |
| 200 lbs | 100 oz (3L) |
| 220 lbs | 110 oz (3.3L) |

Add more if training or sweating.

---

## What Causes Facial Bloat

| Cause | Effect | Fix |
|-------|--------|-----|
| **Sodium** | High salt = water retention | Keep moderate, not zero |
| **Alcohol** | Dehydrates, then overcompensates | Limit or eliminate |
| **Carbs** | Each gram stores 3-4g of water | Expected, not bad |
| **Sleep deprivation** | Cortisol = water retention | Get 7-8 hours |
| **Dehydration** | Counter-intuitive but true | Drink more water |

---

## The Morning Difference

Ever notice you look leaner in the morning?

You're slightly dehydrated after 8 hours without water. This is why fighters cut water weightâ€”it makes a visible difference.

For consistent leanness, stay consistently hydrated and keep sodium moderate.`,
      products: ['water_jug'],
      tips: [
        'Drink a full glass of water immediately upon waking',
        'Cut sodium 24-48 hours before photos for temporary tightness',
        "Alcohol is the worst for next-day face bloat",
      ],
      media: [
        {
          id: 'bloat-comparison',
          type: 'image',
          url: 'https://images.unsplash.com/photo-1548690312-e3b507d8c110?w=800&q=80',
          alt: 'Healthy hydration and fitness',
          caption: 'Same person: bloated vs properly hydrated',
          placement: 'inline',
        },
      ],
    },
    {
      id: 'timeline',
      title: 'Realistic Cutting Timeline',
      humorLevel: 'medium',
      content: `Let's set realistic expectations:

---

## Starting Point: 20% Body Fat (180lb guy)

- **Goal:** 12% body fat
- **Fat to lose:** ~15 lbs
- **Timeline:** 10-15 weeks (doing it right)

---

## Week by Week Progress

| Weeks | What Happens | What You See |
|-------|--------------|--------------|
| **1-2** | Water weight drops | Scale moves fast, exciting |
| **3-6** | Steady fat loss | Starting to see changes |
| **7-10** | Face starts tightening | Jaw appearing, cheekbones hint |
| **11-15** | Final stubborn fat burns | Face pops, transformation complete |

---

## The Trap

Weeks 6-10 are where most guys quit.

Scale slows, you don't see daily changes, and pizza sounds really good.

## The Reality

> Fat loss in the face often happens in the **final phase**.

You might look the same for weeks, then suddenly *"damn, there's my jawline."*

Be patient. Trust the deficit. Don't quit in the middle of the transformation.`,
      warnings: [
        "Don't cut harder because the scale slowedâ€”you'll lose muscle",
        'Take weekly photos in the same conditions for accurate comparison',
      ],
      media: [
        {
          id: 'timeline-progress',
          type: 'image',
          url: 'https://images.unsplash.com/photo-1517836357463-d25dfeac3438?w=800&q=80',
          alt: 'Visual timeline of fitness progress',
          caption: '12-week transformation: patience is key',
          placement: 'inline',
        },
      ],
    },
    {
      id: 'maintaining',
      title: 'Maintaining Lean (The Hard Part)',
      humorLevel: 'medium',
      content: `Getting lean is one thing. Staying lean is another.

---

## Why Maintenance Is Hard

- Hunger hormones increase after cutting
- Metabolism adapts (slightly) to lower calories
- One vacation can undo weeks of progress
- Life happens

## The Strategy

1. **Reverse diet** â€” Slowly increase calories after cutting
2. **Stay active** â€” NEAT (daily movement) matters as much as gym
3. **Keep tracking** â€” At least loosely, forever
4. **Set a ceiling** â€” "I never go above 15%" as a rule

---

## The Buffer Zone

Cutting to 11% then maintaining at 13% is easier than trying to stay at 11% year-round.

Give yourself a 2-3% buffer for life fluctuations.

## The Long Game

> Most guys yo-yo because they treat cutting as temporary.

Make leanness part of your identity, not a phase.`,
    },
    {
      id: 'face-fat-timeline',
      title: 'Face Fat Timeline by Body Fat %',
      humorLevel: 'medium-high',
      content: `When does the face actually lean out? Here's the brutal truth by body fat percentage:

**The Face Fat Timeline:**

| Body Fat % | Face Status | What You See |
|------------|-------------|--------------|
| **25%+** | Maximum bloat | Round face, double chin likely, jaw completely hidden |
| **22-25%** | Soft face | Face is round, no definition, chipmunk mode |
| **18-22%** | Still soft | Jaw exists but is soft, some face fat visible |
| **15-18%** | Improving | Jaw becoming defined, some cheek fat remaining |
| **12-15%** | Good definition | Jaw pops, cheekbones starting to show, face leaning out |
| **10-12%** | Excellent | Hollow cheeks appearing, strong jaw, model tier face |
| **8-10%** | Maximum definition | Chiseled, veins in face possible, not sustainable |

**The Critical Threshold:**
For most men, facial definition really kicks in between **12-15%**. If you're 18% and wondering why your face still looks soft despite visible abs in good lightingâ€”this is why.

**Why Your Face Is Last:**
Your body prioritizes fat storage in the face and midsection for protection and hormone regulation. These are the "safe" areas to store reserves. When cutting, your body pulls from "easy" areas first (arms, calves) and face fat last.

**The Individual Factor:**
Some guys have lean faces at 16%. Others need to hit 11% before the jaw pops. This is geneticsâ€”work with what you have, not against it.

**The Math:**
If your face doesn't lean out until 12%, and you're currently 20%, that's roughly **16 weeks of cutting** at 0.5% body fat loss per week. Set your expectations accordingly.`,
      media: [
        {
          id: 'bf-face-progression',
          type: 'image',
          url: 'https://images.unsplash.com/photo-1597223557154-721c1cecc4b0?w=800&q=80',
          alt: 'Lean face definition example',
          caption: 'The same bone structure reveals itself at lower body fat',
          placement: 'inline',
        },
      ],
    },
    {
      id: 'fat-loss-order',
      title: 'Where Fat Disappears First (Gender Differences)',
      humorLevel: 'medium',
      content: `Fat loss order is largely genetic, but there are predictable patterns by gender:

**Men's Fat Loss Order:**

| Order | Area | When It Goes |
|-------|------|--------------|
| 1st | Arms, shoulders | First few weeks |
| 2nd | Upper back | Early cut |
| 3rd | Chest | Mid cut |
| 4th | Upper abdomen | Mid-late cut |
| 5th | Lower abdomen | Late cut |
| 6th | Love handles | Very late |
| 7th | **Face, chin** | Often LAST |

Men typically store fat in the midsection (visceral) and face. The lower belly and face are usually the final bastions.

**Women's Fat Loss Order:**

| Order | Area | When It Goes |
|-------|------|--------------|
| 1st | Upper body, arms | Early |
| 2nd | Back | Early-mid |
| 3rd | Face | Often earlier than men |
| 4th | Upper legs | Mid cut |
| 5th | Hips, butt | Late |
| 6th | Lower belly | Very late |
| 7th | Inner thighs | Often LAST |

Women store fat in hips, thighs, and butt for reproductive reasons. These areas are hormonally protected and go last.

**The Implications:**
- **Men:** Your face may stay soft until you're quite lean overall. Keep going.
- **Women:** Your face often leans out faster, but lower body holds on longer.

**Stubborn Fat Science:**
"Stubborn" fat areas have more alpha-2 receptors, which resist fat release. These areas also have poor blood flow. This is why targeted fat loss ("spot reduction") doesn't workâ€”you can't force fat cells to release based on where you exercise.

The only solution is overall fat loss until you reach your stubborn areas.`,
    },
    {
      id: 'stubborn-fat-solutions',
      title: 'Stubborn Fat Solutions (When Diet Isn\'t Enough)',
      humorLevel: 'medium',
      content: `What if you're lean everywhere except one problem area? Here are the options:

**First: Are You Actually Lean?**
Be honest. Most people who think they have "stubborn fat" are just not lean enough yet. Get to 10-12% body fat (men) or 18-20% (women) before considering other options.

**If You're Genuinely Lean but Have Stubborn Areas:**

**Option 1: Fasted Cardio + Yohimbine (Budget)**
- Fasted morning cardio can preferentially target stubborn fat
- Yohimbine HCL blocks alpha-2 receptors
- Take 0.2mg/kg bodyweight before fasted cardio
- Must be in a fasted state (no insulin present)
- Stimulantâ€”not for everyone

**Option 2: CoolSculpting / Cryolipolysis ($$$)**
- Freezes and kills fat cells
- 20-25% fat reduction per session
- Multiple sessions needed
- Cost: $600-1,200 per area
- Results in 2-3 months
- Non-invasive

**Option 3: Kybella (Chin Fat Specifically) ($$)**
- Injectable for submental fat (double chin)
- Dissolves fat cells permanently
- 2-4 sessions needed
- Cost: $600-1,200 per session
- Swelling for 1-2 weeks post-treatment

**Option 4: Liposuction (Permanent, $$$$)**

The nuclear option for stubborn fat. Here's what you need to know:

| Factor | Details |
|--------|---------|
| **Best For** | Localized fat deposits that don't respond to diet |
| **Common Areas** | Chin, love handles, lower abs, inner thighs |
| **Cost** | $3,000-$10,000+ per area (USA) |
| **Recovery** | 1-2 weeks off work, 4-6 weeks to see results |
| **Results** | Permanent fat cell removal (cells can't return) |
| **Caveat** | You can still gain fat in remaining cells |

**Types of Liposuction:**
- **Traditional:** Suction through cannula
- **VASER:** Ultrasound-assisted, less bruising
- **SmartLipo:** Laser-assisted, tighter skin
- **AirSculpt:** Minimal downtime, premium cost

**Critical Point:**
Liposuction is NOT a weight loss procedure. It's for body contouring when you're already lean. If you're 20%+ body fat, diet first.

**Medical Tourism:**
Many people get lipo abroad at 30-60% lower cost. Popular destinations: Mexico, Turkey, Colombia. Research your surgeon thoroughly.`,

    {
      id: 'common-mistakes',
      title: 'Common Cutting Mistakes',
      humorLevel: 'high',
      content: `Don't be this guy:

---

## Mistake 1: Cutting Too Fast

*"I'll just eat 1200 calories and do 2 hours of cardio."*

**Result:** Lose muscle, crash metabolism, binge, end up fatter than before.

---

## Mistake 2: Ignoring Protein

*"I'm just not going to eat much."*

**Result:** Skinny-fat physique, lost the muscle, kept the face fat.

---

## Mistake 3: Weekend Cheats

*"I was good all week!"*

**Result:** 3500 calorie surplus Saturday-Sunday wipes out the weekly deficit.

---

## Mistake 4: Drinking Calories

*"But it's just juice/beer/coffee drinks."*

**Result:** 500+ invisible calories daily, no satiety, confused why scale won't move.

---

## Mistake 5: No Resistance Training

*"I just need to do cardio to lose weight."*

**Result:** Lost 20 lbsâ€”15 of muscle. Now you're a smaller, softer version of yourself.

---

## Mistake 6: Obsessing Over the Scale

*"I gained 2 lbs overnight, I'm done!"*

**Result:** Water fluctuation caused a mental breakdown. Real progress lost in the noise.

---

Avoid these and you're ahead of 90% of people trying to cut.`,

      humorLevel: 'medium',
      content: `Here's exactly what to do:

---

## Step 1: Establish Baseline

- Get a DEXA scan or estimate body fat from photos
- Calculate TDEE (plenty of calculators online)
- Take photos in consistent lighting

## Step 2: Set Up Tracking

- Download a calorie tracking app
- Get a food scale (non-negotiable for accuracy)
- Set protein and calorie targets

## Step 3: Start the Cut

- 300-500 calorie deficit
- Hit protein daily (0.8-1g/lb)
- Lift weights 3-4x per week (don't just do cardio)

## Step 4: Monitor and Adjust

- Weigh daily, average weekly
- If not losing after 2 weeks, reduce by 100-200 calories
- Take weekly photos in same conditions

## Step 5: Be Patient

- Expect 10-15 weeks for a significant cut
- Facial changes come lastâ€”don't quit early
- Adjust timeline based on actual progress

---

## Your face will thank you. Lock in.`,
      products: ['food_scale'],

  ],

   308â†’      content: `Tretinoin (prescription retinoid) is the most evidence-backed skincare ingredient for both acne and anti-aging.

   310â†’**What It Does:**
   311â†’- Increases cell turnover
   312â†’- Unclogs pores
   313â†’- Reduces acne
   314â†’- Fades dark spots
   315â†’- Reduces fine lines
   316â†’- Improves skin texture
   317â†’
   318â†’**How to Get It:**
   319â†’- Dermatologist prescription
   320â†’- Online telemedicine (Curology, Apostrophe)
   321â†’- Some countries: OTC
   322â†’
   323â†’**Starting Protocol (Critical):**
   324â†’
   325â†’**Week 1-2:** 2x per week only
   326â†’**Week 3-4:** Every other night
   327â†’**Week 5-6:** Every night (if tolerated)

   330â†’**The Retinization Period:**

   382â†’      content: `Your skin type determines product selection.

   425â†’      title: 'Acne Scars: What Actually Works',
   426â†’      humorLevel: 'medium',
   427â†’      content: `Once acne is controlled, scars may remain. Here's what helps:
   428â†’
   429â†’**Types of Acne Scars:**

   431â†’- **Boxcar:** Wide, box-like depressions
   432â†’- **Rolling:** Wave-like, uneven surface
   433â†’- **Hyperpigmentation:** Dark marks (not true scars)
   434â†’

   459â†’**Priority:**

   461â†’2. Wait for active breakouts to clear
   462â†’3. Then address scarring`,
   463â†’    },

   468â†’      content: `Your routine matters, but so does everything else:

   502â†’- But UV damage is worse long-term
   503â†’- Use sunscreen anyway`,
   504â†’    },
   505â†’    {

   507â†’      title: 'Routines by Goal',
   508â†’      humorLevel: 'medium',
   509â†’      content: `Customize based on your primary concern:

   532â†’**Remember:**

   534â†’    },
   535â†’    {

   537â†’      title: 'The Nuclear Option: Accutane',
   538â†’      humorLevel: 'medium',
   539â†’      content: `When everything else fails, there's isotretinoin (Accutane). This is the only true "cure" for severe acne.

   545â†’- Significant psychological impact from acne

   558â†’
   559â†’**The iPledge Program (USA):**
   560â†’If you're in the US, you'll need to enroll in iPledge. This means monthly appointments, blood tests, and pregnancy prevention requirements. It's a hassle, but it's why Accutane is so safe today.
   561â†’

   569â†’**When NOT to Take It:**

   573â†’- Active liver disease
   574â†’
   575â†’This guide covers the basicsâ€”if you're serious about Accutane, consult a dermatologist. We'll have a full Accutane guide coming soon with month-by-month protocols.`,
   576â†’      products: ['aquaphor_lip', 'cerave_moisturizer', 'sunscreen_elta'],
   577â†’      warnings: [

   579â†’        'The purge is realâ€”expect month 1-2 to look worse before better',

   581â†’      ],
   582â†’    },
   583â†’    {

   585â†’      title: 'Prescription vs OTC Retinoids',
   586â†’      humorLevel: 'medium',
   587â†’      content: `Not all retinoids are created equal. Here's the hierarchy:
   588â†’
   589â†’**The Retinoid Ladder:**
   590â†’

   594â†’| **Tretinoin 0.05%** | Strong | Rx only | Standard treatment strength |

   596â†’| **Adapalene 0.3%** | Medium | Rx only | Acne-focused treatment |
   597â†’| **Adapalene 0.1%** | Medium-Low | OTC (Differin) | OTC acne treatment |
   598â†’| **Retinol 1%** | Low-Medium | OTC | Gentle anti-aging |
   599â†’| **Retinol 0.5%** | Low | OTC | Beginner OTC option |

   602â†’
   603â†’**The Conversion Problem:**
   604â†’Your skin needs to convert OTC retinol â†’ retinaldehyde â†’ retinoic acid (what tretinoin already is). Each step loses potency. That's why tretinoin works faster and more effectively.
   605â†’
   606â†’**OTC Path (No Prescription):**

   610â†’4. Use for 6-12 months before considering Rx
   611â†’
   612â†’**Prescription Path (Faster Results):**
   613â†’1. Get tretinoin 0.025% from dermatologist or telehealth
   614â†’2. Build tolerance over 6-12 weeks
   615â†’3. Increase to 0.05% when tolerated
   616â†’4. Optional: move to 0.1% for maximum efficacy
   617â†’
   618â†’**Telehealth Options:**
   619â†’- Curology (custom formulations, $20-30/month)
   620â†’- Apostrophe (tretinoin available)
   621â†’- Dermatica (UK)
   622â†’
   623â†’These services offer tretinoin without an in-person dermatologist visit.`,
   624â†’    },
   625â†’    {
   626â†’      id: 'dermatologist-decision',
   627â†’      title: 'When to See a Dermatologist',
   628â†’      humorLevel: 'medium',
   629â†’      content: `Some things you can handle at home. Others need a professional. Here's the decision tree:
   630â†’
   631â†’**See a Dermatologist If:**
   632â†’
   633â†’âœ… **Acne Issues:**
   634â†’- Cystic/nodular acne (deep, painful, under-skin)
   635â†’- Acne that scars (you're running out of time)
   636â†’- No improvement after 3 months of OTC treatment
   637â†’- Acne covering large areas (back, chest, face)
   638â†’
   639â†’âœ… **Prescription Needs:**
   640â†’- Want tretinoin but can't access telehealth
   641â†’- Need isotretinoin (Accutane)
   642â†’- Hormonal acne (women: may need spironolactone)
   643â†’- Need antibiotics (short-term)
   644â†’
   645â†’âœ… **Suspicious Spots:**
   646â†’- Any mole that changes in size, shape, or color
   647â†’- New spots that don't heal in 3 weeks
   648â†’- Anything that bleeds, itches, or crusts repeatedly
   649â†’
   650â†’âœ… **Chronic Conditions:**
   651â†’- Rosacea (flushing, visible blood vessels)
   652â†’- Eczema/dermatitis (persistent dry, itchy patches)
   653â†’- Psoriasis (thick, scaly patches)
   654â†’- Melasma (hormonal dark patches)
   655â†’
   656â†’**Handle at Home:**
   657â†’- Mild acne (occasional pimples, blackheads)
   658â†’- General skincare routine building
   659â†’- Hyperpigmentation (dark spots from healed acne)
   660â†’- Dry skin issues
   661â†’- Sun damage prevention
   662â†’
   663â†’**Cost-Effective Options:**
   664â†’1. **Telehealth first** â€” Curology, Apostrophe ($20-40/month)
   665â†’2. **Walk-in clinic** â€” Can prescribe basic Rx ($50-150)
   666â†’3. **Full dermatologist** â€” For complex cases ($150-300)
   667â†’
   668â†’**Pro Tip:** Take photos of your skin over time. Show them to your dermatologist. They can only see your skin in that momentâ€”photos show the full picture.`,
   669â†’    },
   670â†’    {
   671â†’      id: 'action-plan',
   672â†’      title: 'Your Action Plan',
   673â†’      humorLevel: 'medium',
   674â†’      content: `Here's your step-by-step skincare implementation:
   675â†’

   686â†’

   697â†’**Ongoing: Consistency**

   702â†’**Product Recommendations:**
   703â†’- Cleanser: CeraVe Foaming or Hydrating

   707â†’
   708â†’This is the evidence-based, no-BS approach. Simple, effective, sustainable.`,
   709â†’      products: ['cerave_cleanser', 'cerave_moisturizer', 'sunscreen_elta', 'tretinoin_guide'],
