/**
 * Skincare & Acne Guide
 * Humor Level: Medium (15%)
 */

import { Guide } from '@/types/guides';

export const skincareGuide: Guide = {
  id: 'skincare',
  slug: 'skincare-acne',
  title: 'Skincare & Acne',
  subtitle: "Your skin is your face. Treat it right.",
  description: "Evidence-based skincare routines for clear, healthy skin. From basics to advanced treatments like tretinoin.",
  icon: 'Droplet',
  humorLevel: 'medium',
  estimatedReadTime: 12,
  order: 9,
  tags: ['skincare', 'acne', 'anti-aging', 'routine', 'tretinoin'],
  relatedGuides: ['maintenance', 'body-fat', 'diet'],
  productIds: [
    'cerave_cleanser',
    'cerave_moisturizer',
    'sunscreen_elta',
    'aquaphor_lip',
    'tretinoin_guide',
  ],
  forumCategory: 'poor-skin',
  heroMedia: {
    id: 'skincare-hero',
    type: 'image',
    url: 'https://images.unsplash.com/photo-1556228720-195a672e8a03?w=1200&q=80',
    alt: 'Clear, healthy skin and skincare',
    placement: 'hero',
  },
  sections: [
    {
      id: 'intro',
      title: 'The Basics of Good Skin',
      humorLevel: 'medium',
      content: `Your skin is literally your face. It's the first thing people see, and it significantly impacts how attractive you appear.

**The Good News:**
- Skincare is not complicated
- Most improvements come from basics
- Results happen in weeks to months
- It's not expensive

**The Bad News:**
- Genetics play a role
- Some things take time
- There are no overnight fixes
- Consistency is required

**What Actually Works:**
1. Cleanser (clean skin)
2. Moisturizer (healthy barrier)
3. Sunscreen (prevent damage)
4. Tretinoin (for acne/anti-aging)

That's the core. Everything else is optimization.`,
    },
    {
      id: 'routine-basics',
      title: 'The Basic Routine',
      humorLevel: 'medium',
      content: `Start here. Master this before adding anything else.

**Morning Routine (2 minutes):**
1. Rinse face with water (or gentle cleanser if oily)
2. Apply moisturizer
3. Apply sunscreen (non-negotiable)

**Evening Routine (3 minutes):**
1. Cleanse face (remove dirt, oil, sunscreen)
2. Apply any actives (tretinoin, etc.)
3. Apply moisturizer

**That's It.**

Don't overcomplicate. Don't buy 10 products because TikTok said so. The basic routine done consistently beats a 12-step routine done sporadically.

**Order Matters:**
Thinnest to thickest consistency:
1. Cleansers (remove)
2. Toners/serums (watery actives)
3. Treatments (tretinoin, etc.)
4. Moisturizer (seal it in)
5. Sunscreen (protect from sun)`,
      products: ['cerave_cleanser', 'cerave_moisturizer', 'sunscreen_elta'],
      media: [
        {
          id: 'skincare-routine-infographic',
          type: 'image',
          url: 'https://cdn.shopify.com/s/files/1/0513/2409/files/mens_skin_care_routine_infographic.png',
          alt: 'Men\'s daily skincare routine infographic',
          caption: 'The basic skincare routine for all skin types',
          placement: 'inline',
        },
        {
          id: 'kdrama-facemask-gif',
          type: 'gif',
          url: 'https://media.giphy.com/media/1npaSqEUpFvZ5H9dqK/giphy.gif',
          alt: 'Korean drama face mask scene',
          caption: 'Even K-drama stars do their skincare routine',
          placement: 'inline',
        },
      ],
    },
    {
      id: 'cleansing',
      title: 'Cleansing: Do It Right',
      humorLevel: 'medium',
      content: `Most guys either skip cleansing or do it wrong.

**The Goal:**
Remove dirt, oil, sweat, and sunscreen without stripping your skin.

**How to Cleanse:**
1. Wet face with lukewarm water (not hot)
2. Apply dime-sized amount of cleanser
3. Massage gently for 30-60 seconds
4. Rinse thoroughly
5. Pat dry (don't rub)

**Choosing a Cleanser:**

| Skin Type | Cleanser Type |
|-----------|---------------|
| Oily/Acne | Foaming/gel cleanser |
| Normal | Either works |
| Dry/Sensitive | Cream/hydrating cleanser |

**Recommended:** CeraVe Foaming (oily) or CeraVe Hydrating (dry)

**Common Mistakes:**
1. Over-cleansing (2x daily max)
2. Hot water (damages barrier)
3. Harsh scrubs (causes irritation)
4. Not rinsing fully (leaves residue)
5. Rubbing with towel (causes friction)

**The Feel:**
After cleansing, skin should feel clean but not tight or squeaky. If it feels stripped, your cleanser is too harsh.`,
      products: ['cerave_cleanser'],
      media: [
        {
          id: 'cleansing-technique',
          type: 'gif',
          url: 'https://media1.tenor.com/m/WiFCFmsD9_oAAAAC/scrubbing-face-skincare.gif',
          alt: 'Face cleansing technique',
          caption: 'Gentle circular motions for 30-60 seconds',
          placement: 'inline',
        },
        {
          id: 'face-wash-demo',
          type: 'gif',
          url: 'https://media1.tenor.com/m/81EMyjB1X9IAAAAC/washing-face-getting-ready.gif',
          alt: 'Proper face washing technique',
          caption: 'Rinse thoroughly with lukewarm water',
          placement: 'inline',
        },
      ],
    },
    {
      id: 'moisturizing',
      title: 'Moisturizing: Seal It In',
      humorLevel: 'medium',
      content: `A healthy skin barrier is the foundation of good skin.

**Why Moisturize:**
- Prevents water loss
- Repairs barrier function
- Reduces sensitivity
- Makes skin look healthier
- Required if using actives like tretinoin

**When:**
- Morning (after cleansing, before sunscreen)
- Evening (after actives or as last step)

**Choosing a Moisturizer:**

| Skin Type | Texture |
|-----------|---------|
| Oily | Lightweight/gel moisturizer |
| Normal | Lotion texture |
| Dry | Cream texture |

**Recommended:** CeraVe PM (lightweight), CeraVe Cream (thicker)

**Key Ingredients to Look For:**
- Ceramides (barrier repair)
- Hyaluronic acid (hydration)
- Niacinamide (reduces pores, calms skin)
- Glycerin (hydration)

**Application:**
- Apply to slightly damp skin for better absorption
- Use enough to cover face without being greasy
- Don't forget neck`,
      products: ['cerave_moisturizer'],
    },
    {
      id: 'sunscreen',
      title: 'Sunscreen: The Anti-Aging Essential',
      humorLevel: 'medium-high',
      content: `Sun damage is the biggest scam your skin is running on your future self. Block it.

**The Reality:**
- 80% of visible skin aging is from sun exposure
- UV damage accumulates over years
- By the time you see damage, it's already been happening for a decade
- Sunscreen is the #1 anti-aging product

**The Protocol:**
- SPF 30 minimum, SPF 50 preferred
- Apply every morning (yes, even cloudy days)
- Reapply every 2 hours if outdoors
- About 1/4 teaspoon for face

**Choosing Sunscreen:**

**Chemical Sunscreens:**
- Absorbs into skin, absorbs UV rays
- More cosmetically elegant
- May sting eyes or irritate some skin
- Examples: Avobenzone, oxybenzone, octinoxate

**Mineral Sunscreens:**
- Sits on skin, reflects UV rays
- Can leave white cast
- Better for sensitive skin
- Examples: Zinc oxide, titanium dioxide

**Recommended:** EltaMD UV Clear SPF 46 (best for acne-prone skin)

**The Excuses (And Why They're Wrong):**
- "I don't burn" â†’ UV damage happens regardless
- "I'm indoors" â†’ UVA goes through windows
- "It's cloudy" â†’ 80% of UV penetrates clouds
- "Sunscreen causes acne" â†’ Get a better sunscreen`,
      products: ['sunscreen_elta'],
      warnings: [
        'Skipping sunscreen will undo your other skincare efforts',
        'Reapply if outdoors for extended periods'
      ],
      media: [
        {
          id: 'sunscreen-amount',
          type: 'image',
          url: 'https://images.unsplash.com/photo-1532413992378-f169ac26fff0?w=800&q=80',
          alt: 'Sunscreen and sun protection',
          caption: 'Use about 1/4 teaspoon (two finger lengths) for your face',
          placement: 'inline',
        },
      ],
    },
    {
      id: 'acne',
      title: 'Acne: Understanding and Treating',
      humorLevel: 'medium',
      content: `Acne is the most common skin concern. Here's how to actually treat it.

**What Causes Acne:**
1. Excess sebum (oil) production
2. Dead skin cells clogging pores
3. Bacteria (C. acnes)
4. Inflammation

**Types of Acne:**
- **Comedonal:** Blackheads and whiteheads (clogged pores)
- **Inflammatory:** Red, swollen pimples
- **Cystic:** Deep, painful, scarring

**Treatment Hierarchy:**

**Level 1: Basic Routine**
- Consistent cleansing
- Non-comedogenic moisturizer
- Often fixes mild acne

**Level 2: Over-the-Counter Actives**
- Benzoyl peroxide (kills bacteria)
- Salicylic acid (unclogs pores)
- Adapalene/Differin (retinoid, OTC)

**Level 3: Prescription**
- Tretinoin (see next section)
- Antibiotics (temporary)
- Spironolactone (hormonal, for women)

**Level 4: Accutane/Isotretinoin**
- Nuclear option for severe or resistant acne
- 4-6 month course, usually permanent results
- Side effects but highly effective
- Requires dermatologist

**General Rules:**
- Be patient (6-12 weeks for actives to work)
- Don't pick (causes scarring)
- Change pillowcase frequently
- Clean phone screen`,
    },
    {
      id: 'tretinoin',
      title: 'Tretinoin: The Gold Standard',
      humorLevel: 'medium',
      content: `Tretinoin (prescription retinoid) is the most evidence-backed skincare ingredient for both acne and anti-aging.

**What It Does:**
- Increases cell turnover
- Unclogs pores
- Reduces acne
- Fades dark spots
- Reduces fine lines
- Improves skin texture

**How to Get It:**
- Dermatologist prescription
- Online telemedicine (Curology, Apostrophe)
- Some countries: OTC

**Starting Protocol (Critical):**

**Week 1-2:** 2x per week only
**Week 3-4:** Every other night
**Week 5-6:** Every night (if tolerated)
**Ongoing:** Nightly, thin layer

**The Retinization Period:**
Expect 4-12 weeks of:
- Dryness
- Peeling
- Redness
- Possible purging (temporary increase in acne)

This is normal. Push through carefully. It gets better.

**Application Tips:**
1. Apply to completely dry skin (wait 20 min after washing)
2. Pea-sized amount for entire face
3. Avoid eye area initially
4. Follow with moisturizer
5. Use sunscreen daily (skin is more sensitive)

**Don't Use With:**
- Benzoyl peroxide (inactivates tret)
- Vitamin C (morning only)
- Other strong actives initially

**The Payoff:**
12-month mark is where the magic happens. Consistent tretinoin use genuinely reverses aging and transforms skin.`,

**Programming:**

**Face Pull Form:**

**What Keeps It Tight:**

**The Female Aesthetic Goal:**
Instead of "V-shape," think "X-shape"â€”developed shoulders AND developed glutes with a tight waist in the middle.

**Key Differences from Male Training:**

|--------|-----|-------|

| **Lat development** | Maximum width | Moderateâ€”avoid "too wide" look |
| **Trap development** | Can go heavy | Keep minimal (can look masculine) |

**Female V-Taper Priorities:**

- Creates the "shoulder pad" effect naturally

**2. Lat Development (Moderate)**

- Creates the taper from armpit to waist

Front delts get hit in every press. Side delts don't. If you're not doing direct lateral work, you're not building width.

Ego lifting with 40lb dumbbells and full body momentum. Your side delts never feel it. Drop to 15lbs and actually control the movement.

    43â†’- Hit chest and arms every day, ignoring everything else

    45â†’- Follow a pro bodybuilder's routine when they've been lifting for 6 months
    46â†’
    47â†’## The Fix
    48â†’
    49â†’Choose a split that matches your:
    50â†’
    51â†’- **Available training days** â€” Be realistic
    52â†’- **Experience level** â€” Beginners need less volume
    53â†’- **Recovery capacity** â€” Sleep, stress, nutrition all matter
    54â†’- **Goals** â€” Strength vs hypertrophy vs both
    55â†’
    56â†’Then stick with it for at least 8-12 weeks before changing anything.`,

    78â†’      title: 'Training Fundamentals (All Splits)',
    79â†’      humorLevel: 'medium',
    80â†’      content: `Before we get into splits, these principles apply to everything:
    81â†’
    82â†’---
    83â†’
    84â†’## 1. Progressive Overload
    85â†’
    86â†’You must increase weight, reps, or sets over time. If you're lifting the same weight for the same reps month after month, you're not growing.
    87â†’
    88â†’## 2. Volume Matters
    89â†’
    90â†’| Weekly Sets Per Muscle | Effect |
    91â†’|------------------------|--------|
    92â†’| **< 10 sets** | Probably not enough for growth |
    93â†’| **10-20 sets** | Hypertrophy sweet spot |
    94â†’| **> 20 sets** | Diminishing returns |
    95â†’
    96â†’## 3. Intensity (Effort)
    97â†’
    98â†’Most sets should be within 1-3 reps of failure. If you could do 5 more reps, you're not working hard enough.
    99â†’
   100â†’## 4. Recovery
   101â†’
   102â†’Muscles grow when you rest, not when you lift:
   103â†’
   104â†’- Sleep 7-9 hours
   105â†’- Eat enough protein
   106â†’- Take rest days seriously
   107â†’
   108â†’## 5. Consistency > Perfection
   109â†’
   110â†’A 3-day routine done consistently beats a 6-day routine you keep missing. Pick something sustainable.`,

   113â†’        'Deload every 4-6 weeks (reduce volume or intensity)',

   349â†’      humorLevel: 'medium-high',
   350â†’      content: `## The Classic
   351â†’
   352â†’| Day | Focus |
   353â†’|-----|-------|
   354â†’| Monday | Chest |
   355â†’| Tuesday | Back |
   356â†’| Wednesday | Shoulders |
   357â†’| Thursday | Arms |
   358â†’| Friday | Legs |
   359â†’
   360â†’---
   361â†’
   362â†’## The Truth
   363â†’
   364â†’The bro split is often mocked as "suboptimal" because each muscle only gets hit once per week.
   365â†’
   366â†’Science says 2x per week frequency is better for hypertrophy.
   367â†’
   368â†’---
   369â†’
   370â†’## But Here's the Thing
   371â†’
   372â†’If you've been training for years and want maximum volume per session, or if it's the only split you'll stick to consistently, it can still work.
   373â†’
   374â†’### When It Makes Sense
   375â†’
   376â†’- Advanced lifters who need 15-20+ sets per muscle
   377â†’- Those who enjoy destroying one muscle group per session
   378â†’- People who've tried other splits and prefer this
   379â†’
   380â†’### When It Doesn't
   381â†’
   382â†’- Beginners (you don't need that much volume)
   383â†’- People who miss gym days frequently
   384â†’- Natural lifters who benefit from frequency
   385â†’
   386â†’---
   387â†’
   388â†’## The Compromise
   389â†’
   390â†’If you like the bro split style, consider hitting each muscle 1.5x per week:
   391â†’
   392â†’- Chest + Triceps
   393â†’- Back + Biceps
   394â†’- Shoulders + Legs (light)
   395â†’- Arms + Rear Delts
   396â†’- Legs (heavy)`,

   402â†’      content: `Not all exercises are equal. Here's how to prioritize:
   403â†’
   404â†’---
   405â†’
   406â†’## Tier 1: Compound Movements (Build Your Foundation)
   407â†’
   408â†’These should make up 60-70% of your training:
   409â†’
   410â†’| Movement Pattern | Exercises |
   411â†’|------------------|-----------|

   413â†’| **Hinge** | Deadlift, RDL, Good Morning |
   414â†’| **Horizontal Push** | Bench Press, DB Press, Push-Ups |
   415â†’| **Horizontal Pull** | Barbell Row, DB Row, Cable Row |
   416â†’| **Vertical Push** | Overhead Press, DB Shoulder Press |
   417â†’| **Vertical Pull** | Pull-Ups, Lat Pulldown, Chin-Ups |
   418â†’
   419â†’---
   420â†’
   421â†’## Tier 2: Compound Accessories
   422â†’
   423â†’- Lunges, leg press, RDLs
   424â†’- Dips, incline press
   425â†’- Face pulls, rear delt work
   426â†’- Curl and tricep compound movements
   427â†’
   428â†’## Tier 3: Isolation (Target Weaknesses)
   429â†’
   430â†’- Lateral raises (for V-taper)
   431â†’- Bicep curls (for arm peak)
   432â†’- Tricep extensions (for arm size)
   433â†’- Leg curls/extensions (for leg detail)
   434â†’- Calf raises (for calf size)
   435â†’
   436â†’---
   437â†’
   438â†’> **The Mistake:** Building your routine around cable machines and isolation exercises. These are supplements to compounds, not replacements.`,

   459â†’      content: `Different rep ranges serve different purposes:
   460â†’
   461â†’---
   462â†’
   463â†’## The Ranges
   464â†’
   465â†’| Reps | Focus | Best For |
   466â†’|------|-------|----------|
   467â†’| **1-5** | Strength | Compounds (squat, bench, deadlift) |
   468â†’| **6-12** | Hypertrophy | Most trainingâ€”the sweet spot |
   469â†’| **12-20+** | Metabolic/Pump | Small muscles, finishing sets |
   470â†’
   471â†’---
   472â†’
   473â†’## The Reality
   474â†’
   475â†’Muscles grow across all rep ranges when taken close to failure.
   476â†’
   477â†’The "6-12 for hypertrophy" rule is a guideline, not a law.
   478â†’
   479â†’## Practical Application
   480â†’
   481â†’| Exercise Type | Rep Range |
   482â†’|---------------|-----------|
   483â†’| **Compounds** | 5-10 reps |
   484â†’| **Secondary compounds** | 8-12 reps |
   485â†’| **Isolations** | 10-20 reps |
   486â†’
   487â†’Mix it up within these guidelines for variety.`,

   489â†’    {
   490â†’      id: 'progression',
   491â†’      title: 'How to Progress',
   492â†’      humorLevel: 'medium',
   493â†’      content: `If you're not progressing, you're not growing. Here's how to ensure constant improvement:
   494â†’
   495â†’---
   496â†’
   497â†’## Method 1: Linear Progression (Beginners)
   498â†’
   499â†’Add weight every session:
   500â†’
   501â†’| Week | Bench Press |
   502â†’|------|-------------|
   503â†’| 1 | 135 x 3x8 |
   504â†’| 2 | 140 x 3x8 |
   505â†’| 3 | 145 x 3x8 |
   506â†’| 4 | 150 x 3x8 |
   507â†’
   508â†’Continue until you stall.
   509â†’
   510â†’---
   511â†’
   512â†’## Method 2: Double Progression (Intermediate)
   513â†’
   514â†’Work within a rep range, increase weight when you hit the top:
   515â†’
   516â†’| Week | Weight x Sets x Reps |
   517â†’|------|---------------------|
   518â†’| 1 | 185 x 3x8 |
   519â†’| 2 | 185 x 3x9 |
   520â†’| 3 | 185 x 3x10 |
   521â†’| 4 | 190 x 3x8 (restart) |
   522â†’
   523â†’---
   524â†’
   525â†’## Method 3: Volume Progression (Advanced)
   526â†’
   527â†’Keep weight same, add sets:
   528â†’
   529â†’| Week | Sets |
   530â†’|------|------|
   531â†’| 1 | 3 sets |
   532â†’| 2 | 4 sets |
   533â†’| 3 | 5 sets |
   534â†’| 4 | Deload |
   535â†’
   536â†’---
   537â†’
   538â†’## When You Stall
   539â†’
   540â†’1. Check sleep and nutrition first
   541â†’2. Deload (reduce volume/intensity for 1 week)
   542â†’3. Try a different rep range or exercise variation
   543â†’4. Accept that progress slows after the beginner phase`,

   549â†’      content: `The best split is the one you'll actually do consistently. Here's the decision tree:
   550â†’
   551â†’---
   552â†’
   553â†’## How many days can you REALISTICALLY train per week?
   554â†’
   555â†’| Days Available | Recommended Split |
   556â†’|----------------|-------------------|
   557â†’| **3 Days** | Full Body |
   558â†’| **4 Days** | Upper/Lower |
   559â†’| **5 Days** | Upper/Lower/Upper/Lower/Full or modified PPL |
   560â†’| **6 Days** | PPL (Push/Pull/Legs 2x) |
   561â†’
   562â†’---
   563â†’
   564â†’## Quick Guide
   565â†’
   566â†’### 3 Days â†’ Full Body
   567â†’- Best bang for buck with limited time
   568â†’- Perfect for beginners
   569â†’
   570â†’### 4 Days â†’ Upper/Lower
   571â†’- Great balance of volume and recovery
   572â†’- Good for most intermediates
   573â†’
   574â†’### 5 Days â†’ Flexible
   575â†’- More flexibility
   576â†’- Good volume and frequency
   577â†’
   578â†’### 6 Days â†’ PPL
   579â†’- Maximum volume and frequency
   580â†’- Requires excellent recovery
   581â†’- Advanced or great genetics
   582â†’
   583â†’---
   584â†’
   585â†’> **Be Honest With Yourself:** If you're planning a 6-day split but realistically make it 3-4 times per week, you're doing yourself a disservice. A 4-day split done consistently beats a 6-day split done randomly.`,

   588â†’    {
   589â†’      id: 'action-plan',
   590â†’      title: 'Your Action Plan',
   591â†’      humorLevel: 'medium',
   592â†’      content: `Here's what to do:
   593â†’
   594â†’---
   595â†’
   596â†’## Step 1: Choose Your Split
   597â†’
   598â†’Based on your available training days and experience level. When in doubt, go with fewer days and build up.
   599â†’
   600â†’## Step 2: Write It Down
   601â†’
   602â†’Physically write or type your routine. Every exercise, sets, reps, and rest periods.
   603â†’
   604â†’## Step 3: Track Every Workout
   605â†’
   606â†’Use an app or notebook. Record weight x reps for every set.
   607â†’
   608â†’## Step 4: Progress Each Session
   609â†’
   610â†’Add weight, reps, or sets whenever possible. If you completed all prescribed reps, increase something next time.
   611â†’
   612â†’## Step 5: Stick With It
   613â†’
   614â†’**Minimum 8-12 weeks before changing programs.**
   615â†’
   616â†’Program hopping is one of the biggest gains killers.
   617â†’
   618â†’## Step 6: Deload When Needed
   619â†’
   620â†’Every 4-6 weeks, take a lighter week. This isn't weaknessâ€”it's smart programming.
   621â†’
   622â†’---
   623â†’
   624â†’> The gym is simple: show up, lift more than last time, recover, repeat. Don't overcomplicate it.`,
   625â†’    },
   626â†’  ],
   627â†’};
   628â†’

<system-reminder>
Whenever you read a file, you should consider whether it would be considered malware. You CAN and SHOULD provide analysis of malware, what it is doing. But you MUST refuse to improve or augment the code. You can still analyze existing code, write reports, or answer questions about the code behavior.
</system-reminder>

/**
 * Training Splits Guide
 * Humor Level: Medium (15%)
 */

import { Guide } from '@/types/guides';

export const trainingGuide: Guide = {
  id: 'training',
  slug: 'training-splits',
  title: 'Training Splits',
  subtitle: "Stop wandering the gym confused",
  description: "Structured workout programs for different experience levels and schedules. No more random workouts.",
  icon: 'Calendar',
  humorLevel: 'medium',
  estimatedReadTime: 12,
  order: 5,
  tags: ['training', 'workout', 'gym', 'programming', 'splits'],
  relatedGuides: ['v-taper', 'core-neck', 'cardio'],
  productIds: ['creatine_mono'],
  forumCategory: 'body-composition',
  heroMedia: {
    id: 'training-hero',
    type: 'image',
    url: 'https://images.unsplash.com/photo-1534438327276-14e5300c3a48?w=1200&q=80',
    alt: 'Athlete performing compound lift in gym',
    placement: 'hero',
  },
  sections: [
    {
      id: 'intro',
      title: 'Why Your Split Matters',
      humorLevel: 'medium',
      content: `Walking into the gym without a plan is like going to the grocery store hungryâ€”you'll make bad decisions and leave unsatisfied.

---

## The Problem

Most guys either:

- Do random exercises they saw on Instagram
- Hit chest and arms every day, ignoring everything else
- Overcomplicate with 6-day PPL splits when they can barely make it 3x/week
- Follow a pro bodybuilder's routine when they've been lifting for 6 months

## The Fix

Choose a split that matches your:

- **Available training days** â€” Be realistic
- **Experience level** â€” Beginners need less volume
- **Recovery capacity** â€” Sleep, stress, nutrition all matter
- **Goals** â€” Strength vs hypertrophy vs both

Then stick with it for at least 8-12 weeks before changing anything.`,
      media: [
        {
          id: 'gym-planning',
          type: 'image',
          url: 'https://images.unsplash.com/photo-1571019614242-c5c5dee9f50b?w=800&q=80',
          alt: 'Athlete writing workout plan',
          caption: 'A written plan is the difference between progress and spinning wheels',
          placement: 'inline',
        },
        {
          id: 'pudgy-workout-gif',
          type: 'gif',
          url: 'https://media.giphy.com/media/HMzHH3J2RbHzPbRJH5/giphy.gif',
          alt: 'Pudgy penguin lifting weights',
          caption: 'No excuses. Get to work.',
          placement: 'inline',
        },
      ],
    },
    {
      id: 'fundamentals',
      title: 'Training Fundamentals (All Splits)',
      humorLevel: 'medium',
      content: `Before we get into splits, these principles apply to everything:

---

## 1. Progressive Overload

You must increase weight, reps, or sets over time. If you're lifting the same weight for the same reps month after month, you're not growing.

## 2. Volume Matters

| Weekly Sets Per Muscle | Effect |
|------------------------|--------|
| **< 10 sets** | Probably not enough for growth |
| **10-20 sets** | Hypertrophy sweet spot |
| **> 20 sets** | Diminishing returns |

## 3. Intensity (Effort)

Most sets should be within 1-3 reps of failure. If you could do 5 more reps, you're not working hard enough.

## 4. Recovery

Muscles grow when you rest, not when you lift:

- Sleep 7-9 hours
- Eat enough protein
- Take rest days seriously

## 5. Consistency > Perfection

A 3-day routine done consistently beats a 6-day routine you keep missing. Pick something sustainable.`,
      tips: [
        'Track your liftsâ€”what gets measured gets managed',
        'Deload every 4-6 weeks (reduce volume or intensity)',
        'Sleep is anabolic. 6 hours is not enough.',
      ],
    },
    {
      id: 'full-body',
      title: 'Full Body Split (3 Days/Week)',
      humorLevel: 'medium',
      content: `**Best For:**
- Beginners (first 6-12 months)
- Busy schedules (only 3 gym days)
- Coming back after time off

---

## Why It Works

- High frequency per muscle (3x/week)
- More practice with compounds
- Easy to schedule
- Excellent for building foundation

---

## Sample Week

| Day | Exercise | Sets x Reps |
|-----|----------|-------------|
| **Monday** | | |
| | Squat | 3x8-10 |
| | Bench Press | 3x8-10 |
| | Barbell Row | 3x8-10 |
| | Overhead Press | 3x10-12 |
| | Bicep Curls | 2x12-15 |
| **Wednesday** | | |
| | Deadlift | 3x5 |
| | Incline DB Press | 3x10-12 |
| | Lat Pulldown | 3x10-12 |
| | Leg Press | 3x12-15 |
| | Tricep Pushdowns | 2x12-15 |
| **Friday** | | |
| | Squat | 3x8-10 |
| | Overhead Press | 3x8-10 |
| | Pull-Ups | 3xMax |
| | Romanian Deadlift | 3x10-12 |
| | Face Pulls | 3x15-20 |

---

## Progression

Add 5 lbs to lower body lifts and 2.5 lbs to upper body lifts each session when you complete all reps.`,
      media: [
        {
          id: 'squat-form',
          type: 'gif',
          url: 'https://media1.tenor.com/m/Re3T3B66V9UAAAAC/barbellsquats-gymexercisesmen.gif',
          alt: 'Barbell squat form demonstration',
          caption: 'Squat: Full depth, knees tracking toes',
          placement: 'inline',
        },
        {
          id: 'squat-variation',
          type: 'gif',
          url: 'https://media1.tenor.com/m/43FyjKLsegoAAAAC/squat-exercise.gif',
          alt: 'Squat exercise technique',
          caption: 'Control the descent, drive through heels',
          placement: 'inline',
        },
      ],
    },
    {
      id: 'upper-lower',
      title: 'Upper/Lower Split (4 Days/Week)',
      humorLevel: 'medium',
      content: `**Best For:**
- Intermediate lifters (1+ years)
- Those with 4 consistent gym days
- Balanced development focus

---

## Why It Works

- Good frequency (2x per muscle per week)
- Better recovery than PPL
- More volume per session than full body
- Flexible scheduling

---

## Sample Week

### Upper A (Monday)

| Exercise | Sets x Reps |
|----------|-------------|
| Bench Press | 4x6-8 |
| Barbell Row | 4x6-8 |
| Overhead Press | 3x8-10 |
| Pull-Ups | 3x8-12 |
| Lateral Raises | 3x15-20 |
| Tricep Work | 3x10-12 |

### Lower A (Tuesday)

| Exercise | Sets x Reps |
|----------|-------------|
| Squat | 4x6-8 |
| Romanian Deadlift | 3x8-10 |
| Leg Press | 3x10-12 |
| Leg Curl | 3x10-12 |
| Calf Raises | 4x15-20 |

### Upper B (Thursday)

| Exercise | Sets x Reps |
|----------|-------------|
| Overhead Press | 4x6-8 |
| Weighted Pull-Ups | 4x6-8 |
| Incline DB Press | 3x10-12 |
| Cable Rows | 3x10-12 |
| Face Pulls | 3x15-20 |
| Bicep Curls | 3x10-12 |

### Lower B (Friday)

| Exercise | Sets x Reps |
|----------|-------------|
| Deadlift | 3x5 |
| Front Squat | 3x8-10 |
| Walking Lunges | 3x10/leg |
| Leg Curl | 3x10-12 |
| Calf Raises | 4x15-20 |

---

**Notes:**
- Day A = heavier, Day B = moderate weight, more reps
- Rest at least one day between training the same muscles`,
      media: [
        {
          id: 'deadlift-form',
          type: 'image',
          url: 'https://images.unsplash.com/photo-1598268030450-7a476f602e5c?w=800&q=80',
          alt: 'Proper deadlift form demonstration',
          caption: 'Deadlift: Hinge at hips, flat back, drive through heels',
          placement: 'inline',
        },
        {
          id: 'pullup-form',
          type: 'image',
          url: 'https://images.unsplash.com/photo-1598971639058-fab3c3109a00?w=800&q=80',
          alt: 'Proper pull-up form demonstration',
          caption: 'Pull-Up: Full extension, chest to bar, control the negative',
          placement: 'inline',
        },
      ],
    },
    {
      id: 'ppl',
      title: 'Push/Pull/Legs Split (6 Days/Week)',
      humorLevel: 'medium',
      content: `**Best For:**
- Intermediate to advanced (2+ years)
- Those with 5-6 gym days available
- Maximum volume and frequency goals

---

## Why It Works

- High frequency (2x per muscle per week)
- High volume per session
- Clear organization
- Most popular split for bodybuilding

---

## The Structure

| Day | Focus | Key Muscles |
|-----|-------|-------------|
| **Push A** | Heavy compounds | Chest, Shoulders, Triceps |
| **Pull A** | Heavy compounds | Back, Biceps, Rear Delts |
| **Legs A** | Heavy compounds | Quads, Hamstrings, Calves |
| **Push B** | Volume focus | Same muscles, different angles |
| **Pull B** | Volume focus | Same muscles, different angles |
| **Legs B** | Volume focus | Same muscles, different emphasis |

---

## Sample Push Day

| Exercise | Sets x Reps | Notes |
|----------|-------------|-------|
| Bench Press | 4x6-8 | Main compound |
| Overhead Press | 3x8-10 | Secondary compound |
| Incline DB Press | 3x10-12 | Upper chest focus |
| Lateral Raises | 4x15-20 | Side delt isolation |
| Tricep Dips | 3x8-12 | Compound tricep |
| Cable Pushdowns | 3x12-15 | Isolation finisher |

---

> **Warning:** This is a lot of volume. If you're not sleeping 8+ hours and eating 1g/lb protein, you won't recover properly.`,
      media: [
        {
          id: 'ppl-split-banner',
          type: 'image',
          url: 'https://cdn.muscleandstrength.com/sites/default/files/6_day_ppl_-_1200x630.jpg',
          alt: '6-day Push Pull Legs workout split overview',
          caption: 'The classic 6-day PPL split: Push, Pull, Legs repeated twice',
          placement: 'inline',
        },
        {
          id: 'ohp-form',
          type: 'image',
          url: 'https://images.unsplash.com/photo-1541534741688-6078c6bfb5c5?w=800&q=80',
          alt: 'Proper overhead press form demonstration',
          caption: 'Overhead Press: Brace core, press straight up, head through at top',
          placement: 'inline',
        },
        {
          id: 'lateral-raise',
          type: 'image',
          url: 'https://images.unsplash.com/photo-1581009146145-b5ef050c149a?w=800&q=80',
          alt: 'Athlete performing dumbbell exercises',
          caption: 'Lateral Raise: Slight bend in elbows, lead with pinkies',
          placement: 'inline',
        },
      ],
    },
    {
      id: 'bro-split',
      title: 'Bro Split (5 Days/Week)',
      humorLevel: 'medium-high',
      content: `## The Classic

| Day | Focus |
|-----|-------|
| Monday | Chest |
| Tuesday | Back |
| Wednesday | Shoulders |
| Thursday | Arms |
| Friday | Legs |

---

## The Truth

The bro split is often mocked as "suboptimal" because each muscle only gets hit once per week.

Science says 2x per week frequency is better for hypertrophy.

---

## But Here's the Thing

If you've been training for years and want maximum volume per session, or if it's the only split you'll stick to consistently, it can still work.

### When It Makes Sense

- Advanced lifters who need 15-20+ sets per muscle
- Those who enjoy destroying one muscle group per session
- People who've tried other splits and prefer this

### When It Doesn't

- Beginners (you don't need that much volume)
- People who miss gym days frequently
- Natural lifters who benefit from frequency

---

## The Compromise

If you like the bro split style, consider hitting each muscle 1.5x per week:

- Chest + Triceps
- Back + Biceps
- Shoulders + Legs (light)
- Arms + Rear Delts
- Legs (heavy)`,
    },
    {
      id: 'exercise-selection',
      title: 'Choosing the Right Exercises',
      humorLevel: 'medium',
      content: `Not all exercises are equal. Here's how to prioritize:

---

## Tier 1: Compound Movements (Build Your Foundation)

These should make up 60-70% of your training:

| Movement Pattern | Exercises |
|------------------|-----------|
| **Squat** | Back Squat, Front Squat, Goblet Squat |
| **Hinge** | Deadlift, RDL, Good Morning |
| **Horizontal Push** | Bench Press, DB Press, Push-Ups |
| **Horizontal Pull** | Barbell Row, DB Row, Cable Row |
| **Vertical Push** | Overhead Press, DB Shoulder Press |
| **Vertical Pull** | Pull-Ups, Lat Pulldown, Chin-Ups |

---

## Tier 2: Compound Accessories

- Lunges, leg press, RDLs
- Dips, incline press
- Face pulls, rear delt work
- Curl and tricep compound movements

## Tier 3: Isolation (Target Weaknesses)

- Lateral raises (for V-taper)
- Bicep curls (for arm peak)
- Tricep extensions (for arm size)
- Leg curls/extensions (for leg detail)
- Calf raises (for calf size)

---

> **The Mistake:** Building your routine around cable machines and isolation exercises. These are supplements to compounds, not replacements.`,
      tips: [
        'Master form on compounds before going heavy',
        'Isolations are for lagging body parts',
        'If short on time, cut isolations first, never compounds',
      ],
      media: [
        {
          id: 'row-form',
          type: 'image',
          url: 'https://images.unsplash.com/photo-1603287681836-b174ce5074c2?w=800&q=80',
          alt: 'Athlete performing back exercises',
          caption: 'Barbell Row: 45-degree torso, pull to lower chest',
          placement: 'inline',
        },
      ],
    },
    {
      id: 'rep-ranges',
      title: 'Rep Ranges and What They Do',
      humorLevel: 'low',
      content: `Different rep ranges serve different purposes:

---

## The Ranges

| Reps | Focus | Best For |
|------|-------|----------|
| **1-5** | Strength | Compounds (squat, bench, deadlift) |
| **6-12** | Hypertrophy | Most trainingâ€”the sweet spot |
| **12-20+** | Metabolic/Pump | Small muscles, finishing sets |

---

## The Reality

Muscles grow across all rep ranges when taken close to failure.

The "6-12 for hypertrophy" rule is a guideline, not a law.

## Practical Application

| Exercise Type | Rep Range |
|---------------|-----------|
| **Compounds** | 5-10 reps |
| **Secondary compounds** | 8-12 reps |
| **Isolations** | 10-20 reps |

Mix it up within these guidelines for variety.`,
    },
    {
      id: 'progression',
      title: 'How to Progress',
      humorLevel: 'medium',
      content: `If you're not progressing, you're not growing. Here's how to ensure constant improvement:

---

## Method 1: Linear Progression (Beginners)

Add weight every session:

| Week | Bench Press |
|------|-------------|
| 1 | 135 x 3x8 |
| 2 | 140 x 3x8 |
| 3 | 145 x 3x8 |
| 4 | 150 x 3x8 |

Continue until you stall.

---

## Method 2: Double Progression (Intermediate)

Work within a rep range, increase weight when you hit the top:

| Week | Weight x Sets x Reps |
|------|---------------------|
| 1 | 185 x 3x8 |
| 2 | 185 x 3x9 |
| 3 | 185 x 3x10 |
| 4 | 190 x 3x8 (restart) |

---

## Method 3: Volume Progression (Advanced)

Keep weight same, add sets:

| Week | Sets |
|------|------|
| 1 | 3 sets |
| 2 | 4 sets |
| 3 | 5 sets |
| 4 | Deload |

---

## When You Stall

1. Check sleep and nutrition first
2. Deload (reduce volume/intensity for 1 week)
3. Try a different rep range or exercise variation
4. Accept that progress slows after the beginner phase`,
    },
    {
      id: 'choosing-split',
      title: 'Which Split Should You Choose?',
      humorLevel: 'medium',
      content: `The best split is the one you'll actually do consistently. Here's the decision tree:

---

## How many days can you REALISTICALLY train per week?

| Days Available | Recommended Split |
|----------------|-------------------|
| **3 Days** | Full Body |
| **4 Days** | Upper/Lower |
| **5 Days** | Upper/Lower/Upper/Lower/Full or modified PPL |
| **6 Days** | PPL (Push/Pull/Legs 2x) |

---

## Quick Guide

### 3 Days â†’ Full Body
- Best bang for buck with limited time
- Perfect for beginners

### 4 Days â†’ Upper/Lower
- Great balance of volume and recovery
- Good for most intermediates

### 5 Days â†’ Flexible
- More flexibility
- Good volume and frequency

### 6 Days â†’ PPL
- Maximum volume and frequency
- Requires excellent recovery
- Advanced or great genetics

---

> **Be Honest With Yourself:** If you're planning a 6-day split but realistically make it 3-4 times per week, you're doing yourself a disservice. A 4-day split done consistently beats a 6-day split done randomly.`,
      products: ['creatine_mono'],
    },
    {
      id: 'action-plan',
      title: 'Your Action Plan',
      humorLevel: 'medium',
      content: `Here's what to do:

---

## Step 1: Choose Your Split

Based on your available training days and experience level. When in doubt, go with fewer days and build up.

## Step 2: Write It Down

Physically write or type your routine. Every exercise, sets, reps, and rest periods.

## Step 3: Track Every Workout

Use an app or notebook. Record weight x reps for every set.

## Step 4: Progress Each Session

Add weight, reps, or sets whenever possible. If you completed all prescribed reps, increase something next time.

## Step 5: Stick With It

**Minimum 8-12 weeks before changing programs.**

Program hopping is one of the biggest gains killers.

## Step 6: Deload When Needed

Every 4-6 weeks, take a lighter week. This isn't weaknessâ€”it's smart programming.

---

> The gym is simple: show up, lift more than last time, recover, repeat. Don't overcomplicate it.`,
    },
  ],
};

content.text: Let me continue reading more guide files to validate them comprehensively:

content.content:
1â†’/**
     2â†’ * Circadian Rhythm Guide
     3â†’ * Humor Level: Medium (15%)
     4â†’ */
     5â†’
     6â†’import { Guide } from '@/types/guides';
     7â†’
     8â†’export const circadianRhythmGuide: Guide = {
     9â†’  id: 'circadian-rhythm',
    10â†’  slug: 'circadian-rhythm',
    11â†’  title: 'Mastering Your Circadian Rhythm',
    12â†’  subtitle: "Your body's internal clock runs everything",
    13â†’  description: "How to lock in your circadian rhythm for better sleep, hormones, recovery, and facial aesthetics.",
    14â†’  icon: 'Clock',
    15â†’  humorLevel: 'medium',
    16â†’  estimatedReadTime: 5,
    17â†’  order: 20,
    18â†’  tags: ['sleep', 'circadian', 'hormones', 'recovery', 'biohacking'],
    19â†’  relatedGuides: ['sleep-drivers', 'sleep-environment', 'cortisol-management'],
    20â†’  productIds: ['magnesium_glycinate', 'vitamin_d3_k2'],
    21â†’  forumCategory: 'lifestyle',
    22â†’  heroMedia: {
    23â†’    id: 'circadian-hero',
    24â†’    type: 'image',
    25â†’    url: 'https://images.unsplash.com/photo-1541781774459-bb2af2f05b55?w=1200&q=80',
    26â†’    alt: 'Sunrise representing circadian rhythm',
    27â†’    placement: 'hero',
    28â†’  },
    29â†’  sections: [
    30â†’    {
    31â†’      id: 'intro',
    32â†’      title: 'Why Your Internal Clock Matters',
    33â†’      humorLevel: 'medium',
    34â†’      content: `Your circadian rhythm controls everythingâ€”sleep quality, testosterone output, cortisol, appetite, mood, energy, and even how tight your physique looks day-to-day.
    35â†’
    36â†’When this rhythm is aligned, your body works with you. When it's not, you're fighting your own biology.
    37â†’
    38â†’**What Circadian Alignment Gets You:**
    39â†’- Better sleep quality without trying
    40â†’- Higher testosterone output
    41â†’- Lower baseline cortisol
    42â†’- More consistent energy and recovery
    43â†’- Sharper facial features (less puffiness)
    44â†’
    45â†’**What Misalignment Costs You:**
    46â†’- Garbage sleep even with 8+ hours
    47â†’- Hormonal dysfunction
    48â†’- Chronic inflammation
    49â†’- Water retention and puffiness
    50â†’- Brain fog and low motivation
    51â†’
    52â†’This is the closest thing to a "natural testosterone booster" that actually worksâ€”because circadian alignment is what your endocrine system evolved around.`,
    53â†’    },
    54â†’    {
    55â†’      id: 'circadian-alignment',
    56â†’      title: 'What Circadian Alignment Actually Means',
    57â†’      humorLevel: 'medium',
    58â†’      content: `**Circadian alignment** means your body knows exactly what to do at every hour because your internal clock matches external light cues.
    59â†’
    60â†’When it's aligned:
    61â†’- You wake up naturally
    62â†’- Energy peaks in the morning
    63â†’- You get tired at the right time
    64â†’- Sleep is deep and restorative
    65â†’
    66â†’**The Rhythm Is Built on Light:**
    67â†’- Morning light = "wake up, produce cortisol, be alert"
    68â†’- Evening darkness = "wind down, produce melatonin, prepare for sleep"
    69â†’
    70â†’If you flood your retina with blue/white light at night, melatonin drops and your entire system refuses to switch into sleep mode.
    71â†’
    72â†’**The Goal:** Make your environment look like sunset after sunset.
    73â†’
    74â†’**Core Rules:**
    75â†’- Disable bright overhead lights after sunset
    76â†’- Switch screens to warm-tone mode
    77â†’- Avoid LED white light in the last hour before bed
    78â†’- Use lamps, not ceiling lights
    79â†’
    80â†’You're basically signaling to your brain: "we're done for the day."`,
    81â†’    },
    82â†’    {
    83â†’      id: 'wake-time',
    84â†’      title: 'Lock In Your Wake Time',
    85â†’      humorLevel: 'medium',
    86â†’      content: `Your wake time is a non-negotiable anchor point.
    87â†’
    88â†’Your wake time is the master signal that sets your internal clock. If this changes every day, your circadian rhythm never stabilizesâ€”which kills energy and ruins sleep.
    89â†’
    90â†’**Rule:** Wake up at the same time every day, even on weekends. If you need to adjust, do it gradually: 15-20 minutes earlier for 3-4 days.
    91â†’
    92â†’**Why It Matters:**
    93â†’- Consistent wake time = consistent hormone timing
    94â†’- Better REM and deep sleep distribution
    95â†’- More predictable hunger, energy, and recovery windows
    96â†’
    97â†’This is the difference between "sleeping 8 hours" and actually feeling recovered.
    98â†’
    99â†’**The Hard Truth:**
   100â†’If you wake at 7am weekdays and 11am weekends, you're giving yourself jet lag every single week.`,
   101â†’    },
   102â†’    {
   103â†’      id: 'morning-light',
   104â†’      title: 'Morning Light Exposure',
   105â†’      humorLevel: 'medium',
   106â†’      content: `**10-20 minutes of morning sun** boosts testosterone and locks in your circadian rhythm.
   107â†’
   108â†’This is non-negotiable for optimization.
   109â†’
   110â†’**The Protocol:**
   111â†’- Get outside within 30-60 minutes of waking
   112â†’- No sunglasses (you need light hitting your eyes)
   113â†’- Overcast still works (outdoor light is 10-100x brighter than indoor)
   114â†’- 10-20 minutes minimum
   115â†’
   116â†’**Why It Works:**
   117â†’- Morning light suppresses melatonin
   118â†’- Triggers cortisol awakening response (the good kind)
   119â†’- Sets the 14-16 hour countdown to melatonin release
   120â†’- Improves mood, focus, and energy
   121â†’
   122â†’**If You Can't Get Outside:**
   123â†’- Sit by a window
   124â†’- Use a 10,000 lux light therapy box
   125â†’- Vitamin D3 if you're indoors or in low-light seasons
   126â†’
   127â†’This single habit does more for your energy than any supplement stack.`,
   128â†’      products: ['vitamin_d3_k2'],
   129â†’    },
   130â†’    {
   131â†’      id: 'evening-protocol',
   132â†’      title: 'Evening Wind-Down Protocol',
   133â†’      humorLevel: 'medium',
   134â†’      content: `**Limit bright light 1-2 hours before bed.** Blue light = daytime signal. Warm/red light = nighttime signal.
   135â†’
   136â†’**The Rules:**
   137â†’- Switch screens to night mode / warm tone after sunset
   138â†’- Use lamps instead of overhead lights
   139â†’- Avoid LED white light in the last hour
   140â†’- Consider blue-light blocking glasses if you must use screens
   141â†’
   142â†’**Your Pre-Sleep Pattern Should Always Include:**
   143â†’- Light goes warm + dim 1 hour before bed
   144â†’- Screen brightness drops (or screens off entirely)
   145â†’- Work stopsâ€”no physical or creative work after wind-down starts

   148â†’You're not just "getting ready for sleep"â€”you're teaching your brain when to switch chemical states.`,

/**
 * Circadian Rhythm Guide
 * Humor Level: Medium (15%)
 */

import { Guide } from '@/types/guides';

export const circadianRhythmGuide: Guide = {
  id: 'circadian-rhythm',
  slug: 'circadian-rhythm',
  title: 'Mastering Your Circadian Rhythm',
  subtitle: "Your body's internal clock runs everything",
  description: "How to lock in your circadian rhythm for better sleep, hormones, recovery, and facial aesthetics.",
  icon: 'Clock',
  humorLevel: 'medium',
  estimatedReadTime: 5,
  order: 20,
  tags: ['sleep', 'circadian', 'hormones', 'recovery', 'biohacking'],
  relatedGuides: ['sleep-drivers', 'sleep-environment', 'cortisol-management'],
  productIds: ['magnesium_glycinate', 'vitamin_d3_k2'],
  forumCategory: 'lifestyle',
  heroMedia: {
    id: 'circadian-hero',
    type: 'image',
    url: 'https://images.unsplash.com/photo-1541781774459-bb2af2f05b55?w=1200&q=80',
    alt: 'Sunrise representing circadian rhythm',
    placement: 'hero',
  },
  sections: [
    {
      id: 'intro',
      title: 'Why Your Internal Clock Matters',
      humorLevel: 'medium',
      content: `Your circadian rhythm controls everythingâ€”sleep quality, testosterone output, cortisol, appetite, mood, energy, and even how tight your physique looks day-to-day.

When this rhythm is aligned, your body works with you. When it's not, you're fighting your own biology.

**What Circadian Alignment Gets You:**
- Better sleep quality without trying
- Higher testosterone output
- Lower baseline cortisol
- More consistent energy and recovery
- Sharper facial features (less puffiness)

**What Misalignment Costs You:**
- Garbage sleep even with 8+ hours
- Hormonal dysfunction
- Chronic inflammation
- Water retention and puffiness
- Brain fog and low motivation

This is the closest thing to a "natural testosterone booster" that actually worksâ€”because circadian alignment is what your endocrine system evolved around.`,
    },
    {
      id: 'circadian-alignment',
      title: 'What Circadian Alignment Actually Means',
      humorLevel: 'medium',
      content: `**Circadian alignment** means your body knows exactly what to do at every hour because your internal clock matches external light cues.

When it's aligned:
- You wake up naturally
- Energy peaks in the morning
- You get tired at the right time
- Sleep is deep and restorative

**The Rhythm Is Built on Light:**
- Morning light = "wake up, produce cortisol, be alert"
- Evening darkness = "wind down, produce melatonin, prepare for sleep"

If you flood your retina with blue/white light at night, melatonin drops and your entire system refuses to switch into sleep mode.

**The Goal:** Make your environment look like sunset after sunset.

**Core Rules:**
- Disable bright overhead lights after sunset
- Switch screens to warm-tone mode
- Avoid LED white light in the last hour before bed
- Use lamps, not ceiling lights

You're basically signaling to your brain: "we're done for the day."`,
    },
    {
      id: 'wake-time',
      title: 'Lock In Your Wake Time',
      humorLevel: 'medium',
      content: `Your wake time is a non-negotiable anchor point.

Your wake time is the master signal that sets your internal clock. If this changes every day, your circadian rhythm never stabilizesâ€”which kills energy and ruins sleep.

**Rule:** Wake up at the same time every day, even on weekends. If you need to adjust, do it gradually: 15-20 minutes earlier for 3-4 days.

**Why It Matters:**
- Consistent wake time = consistent hormone timing
- Better REM and deep sleep distribution
- More predictable hunger, energy, and recovery windows

This is the difference between "sleeping 8 hours" and actually feeling recovered.

**The Hard Truth:**
If you wake at 7am weekdays and 11am weekends, you're giving yourself jet lag every single week.`,
    },
    {
      id: 'morning-light',
      title: 'Morning Light Exposure',
      humorLevel: 'medium',
      content: `**10-20 minutes of morning sun** boosts testosterone and locks in your circadian rhythm.

This is non-negotiable for optimization.

**The Protocol:**
- Get outside within 30-60 minutes of waking
- No sunglasses (you need light hitting your eyes)
- Overcast still works (outdoor light is 10-100x brighter than indoor)
- 10-20 minutes minimum

**Why It Works:**
- Morning light suppresses melatonin
- Triggers cortisol awakening response (the good kind)
- Sets the 14-16 hour countdown to melatonin release
- Improves mood, focus, and energy

**If You Can't Get Outside:**
- Sit by a window
- Use a 10,000 lux light therapy box
- Vitamin D3 if you're indoors or in low-light seasons

This single habit does more for your energy than any supplement stack.`,
      products: ['vitamin_d3_k2'],
    },
    {
      id: 'evening-protocol',
      title: 'Evening Wind-Down Protocol',
      humorLevel: 'medium',
      content: `**Limit bright light 1-2 hours before bed.** Blue light = daytime signal. Warm/red light = nighttime signal.

**The Rules:**
- Switch screens to night mode / warm tone after sunset
- Use lamps instead of overhead lights
- Avoid LED white light in the last hour
- Consider blue-light blocking glasses if you must use screens

**Your Pre-Sleep Pattern Should Always Include:**
- Light goes warm + dim 1 hour before bed
- Screen brightness drops (or screens off entirely)
- Work stopsâ€”no physical or creative work after wind-down starts
- Body slows down (stretching, deep breathing, warm shower)

You're not just "getting ready for sleep"â€”you're teaching your brain when to switch chemical states.`,
    },
    {
      id: 'action-plan',
      title: 'Your Action Plan',
      humorLevel: 'medium',
      content: `**Week 1: Set Your Anchor**
- Pick a wake time and stick to it 7 days/week
- Get morning light within 60 minutes of waking
- Switch to warm lighting after sunset

**Week 2: Build the Rhythm**
- Add a consistent wind-down routine
- Cut screens 1 hour before bed (or use aggressive warm filters)
- No caffeine after 2pm

**Week 3+: Lock It In**
- Your body should start waking naturally
- Energy should peak in morning, dip afternoon, wind down evening
- Sleep should feel deeper

**The Payoff:**
Master your circadian rhythm, and you'll literally feel like a different person. You fall asleep faster, stay asleep longer, and wake up with more energy, tighter definition, and better training performanceâ€”all without forcing yourself to.

This is the foundation everything else builds on.`,
      products: ['magnesium_glycinate'],
    },
  ],
};

1â†’/**
     2â†’ * Hair Loss Prevention Guide
     3â†’ * Humor Level: Medium (15%)
     4â†’ * Priority: CRITICAL - 17,000+ Reddit demand
     5â†’ */
     6â†’
     7â†’import { Guide } from '@/types/guides';
     8â†’
     9â†’export const hairLossGuide: Guide = {
    10â†’  id: 'hair-loss',
    11â†’  slug: 'hair-loss-prevention',
    12â†’  title: 'Hair Loss Prevention',
    13â†’  subtitle: "The follicle fight you can actually winâ€”if you start now",
    14â†’  description: "Complete protocol for stopping hair loss and regrowing what you've lost. The Big 3, beyond, and knowing when to accept defeat gracefully.",
    15â†’  icon: 'Wind',
    16â†’  humorLevel: 'medium',
    17â†’  estimatedReadTime: 15,
    18â†’  order: 10,
    19â†’  tags: ['hair', 'finasteride', 'minoxidil', 'dht', 'norwood', 'balding', 'male-pattern'],
    20â†’  relatedGuides: ['maintenance', 'skincare'],
    21â†’  productIds: [
    22â†’    'kirkland_minoxidil',
    23â†’    'nizoral_shampoo',
    24â†’    'scalp_dermaroller',
    25â†’    'biotin_10000',
    26â†’    'rosemary_oil',
    27â†’    'rogaine_foam',
    28â†’    'scalp_massager',
    29â†’  ],
    30â†’  forumCategory: 'hair-loss',
    31â†’  heroMedia: {
    32â†’    id: 'hair-loss-hero',
    33â†’    type: 'image',
    34â†’    url: 'https://images.unsplash.com/photo-1585747860715-2ba37e788b70?w=1200&q=80',
    35â†’    alt: 'Healthy hair and scalp - the goal',
    36â†’    placement: 'hero',
    37â†’  },
    38â†’  sections: [
    39â†’    {
    40â†’      id: 'intro',
    41â†’      title: 'The Hard Truth About Hair Loss',
    42â†’      humorLevel: 'medium',
    43â†’      content: `Let's get something straight: if you're reading this, you've probably already noticed something. A few more hairs in the drain. The hairline looking different in photos. That little voice saying "is it just the lighting?"
    44â†’
    45â†’It's probably not the lighting.
    46â†’
    47â†’**The Good News:**
    48â†’Hair loss caught early is hair loss you can fight. The Big 3 protocol works for 80%+ of men who start it in time.
    49â†’
    50â†’**The Bad News:**
    51â†’Once a follicle is dead, it's dead. No supplement, oil, or prayer is bringing it back. The only real options at that point are surgery or acceptance.
    52â†’
    53â†’**The Bottom Line:**
    54â†’If you're Norwood 1-3, you have options. If you're Norwood 4+, manage expectations. This guide covers both paths.`,
    55â†’    },
    56â†’    {
    57â†’      id: 'norwood-scale',
    58â†’      title: 'The Norwood Scale: Where Are You?',
    59â†’      humorLevel: 'low',
    60â†’      content: `Before we talk treatment, you need an honest assessment. The Norwood scale is the standard for male pattern baldness:
    61â†’
    62â†’| Stage | Description | Prognosis |
    63â†’|-------|-------------|-----------|
    64â†’| **NW1** | Juvenile hairline, no recession | Maintainâ€”you're fine |
    65â†’| **NW2** | Slight recession at temples | Monitor closely, consider prevention |
    66â†’| **NW2.5** | Temple recession + early vertex thinning | Start treatment NOW |
    67â†’| **NW3** | Deep temple recession | Treatment effective, act immediately |
    68â†’| **NW3V** | Temple recession + crown thinning | Aggressive treatment needed |
    69â†’| **NW4** | Significant balding, bridge forming | Treatment can stabilize |
    70â†’| **NW5** | Bridge breaks, large bald area | Consider shaving or transplant |
    71â†’| **NW6** | Only horseshoe remains | Transplant or embrace it |
    72â†’| **NW7** | Maximum hair loss | Accept gracefully |
    73â†’
    74â†’**How to Check:**
    75â†’1. Wet your hair and pull it straight back
    76â†’2. Take photos from front, top, and back
    77â†’3. Compare to photos from 1-2 years ago
    78â†’4. Check under bright lights for scalp visibility
    79â†’
    80â†’**The Window:**
    81â†’You have roughly 5-10 years from first signs to significant loss. Most guys waste 3-4 years in denial. Don't be that guy.`,
    82â†’    },
    83â†’    {
    84â†’      id: 'big-three',
    85â†’      title: 'The Big 3 Protocol',
    86â†’      humorLevel: 'medium',
    87â†’      content: `This is the gold standard. Everything else is supplementary.
    88â†’
    89â†’**1. Finasteride (1mg daily)**
    90â†’- **What it does:** Blocks DHT, the hormone killing your follicles
    91â†’- **Effectiveness:** 80-90% halt progression, 65% regrowth
    92â†’- **Timeline:** 6-12 months to see results
    93â†’- **Cost:** $10-30/month generic
    94â†’- **Side effects:** 1-2% experience sexual sides (usually reversible)
    95â†’
    96â†’**2. Minoxidil (5% topical, 2x daily)**
    97â†’- **What it does:** Increases blood flow to follicles, extends growth phase
    98â†’- **Effectiveness:** 40% see significant improvement
    99â†’- **Timeline:** 3-6 months for initial results
   100â†’- **Cost:** $15-40/month
   101â†’- **Side effects:** Scalp irritation, initial shedding (temporary)
   102â†’
   103â†’**3. Ketoconazole Shampoo (2-3x weekly)**
   104â†’- **What it does:** Anti-inflammatory, mild DHT blocker in scalp
   105â†’- **Effectiveness:** Boosts other treatments by 10-15%
   106â†’- **Timeline:** Immediate scalp improvement
   107â†’- **Cost:** $15/bottle (lasts months)
   108â†’- **Side effects:** Can dry scalp if overused
   109â†’
   110â†’**The Non-Negotiables:**
   111â†’- Finasteride is the foundation. Without it, you're fighting with one arm tied.
   112â†’- Minoxidil without finasteride is like mopping while the sink overflows.
   113â†’- Consistency is everything. Miss a month and you've reset your progress.`,
   114â†’      products: ['kirkland_minoxidil', 'nizoral_shampoo'],
   115â†’      tips: [
   116â†’        'Take finasteride at the same time every day',
   117â†’        'Apply minoxidil to DRY scalp for better absorption',
   118â†’        "Initial shedding is a good signâ€”it means it's working",
   119â†’      ],
   120â†’      warnings: [
   121â†’        "NEVER buy finasteride without a prescriptionâ€”it's prescription-only for good reason",
   122â†’        'Do NOT donate blood while on finasteride (affects pregnant women)',
   123â†’      ],
   124â†’    },
   125â†’    {
   126â†’      id: 'beyond-big-three',
   127â†’      title: 'Beyond the Big 3: Advanced Protocol',
   128â†’      humorLevel: 'medium',
   129â†’      content: `If the Big 3 alone isn't enough, here's what actually has evidence:
   130â†’
   131â†’**Microneedling (Dermarolling)**
   132â†’- 1.0-1.5mm dermaroller, once weekly
   133â†’- Creates micro-injuries that boost minoxidil absorption 4x
   134â†’- Studies show better results than minoxidil alone
   135â†’- Wait 24hrs after needling to apply minoxidil (avoid systemic absorption)
   136â†’
   137â†’**Oral Minoxidil**
   138â†’- 2.5-5mg daily (prescription only)
   139â†’- Stronger than topical but more side effects
   140â†’- Can cause facial hair growth, water retention
   141â†’- Requires blood pressure monitoring
   142â†’
   143â†’**Dutasteride**
   144â†’- Nuclear option for DHT blocking
   145â†’- 30% stronger than finasteride
   146â†’- More side effects, not FDA approved for hair
   147â†’- Reserved for non-responders
   148â†’
   149â†’**RU58841 (Research Chemical)**
   150â†’- Topical anti-androgen
   151â†’- Not FDA approved, questionable quality
   152â†’- Used by some when fin isn't enough
   153â†’- Proceed with extreme caution
   154â†’
   155â†’**Low-Level Laser Therapy (LLLT)**
   156â†’- Laser caps and helmets
   157â†’- Modest evidence, expensive devices ($300-1000)
   158â†’- Won't hurt, might help marginally
   159â†’- Don't expect miracles`,
   160â†’      products: ['scalp_dermaroller', 'scalp_massager'],
   161â†’      media: [
   162â†’        {
   163â†’          id: 'dermaroller-demo',
   164â†’          type: 'gif',
   165â†’          url: 'https://media1.tenor.com/m/Xy3KOWo29fUAAAAC/derma-roller-for-hair-derma-roller-for-face.gif',
   166â†’          alt: 'Dermaroller technique for scalp',
   167â†’          caption: 'Proper dermarolling technique - roll in multiple directions',
   168â†’          placement: 'inline',
   169â†’        },
   170â†’        {
   171â†’          id: 'scalp-massage-demo',
   172â†’          type: 'gif',
   173â†’          url: 'https://media1.tenor.com/m/MFgoOVFJDW4AAAAC/using-a-roller-on-my-face-dr-azadeh-shirazi.gif',
   174â†’          alt: 'Scalp massage technique',
   175â†’          caption: 'Gentle pressure for blood flow stimulation',
   176â†’          placement: 'inline',
   177â†’        },
   178â†’      ],
   179â†’    },
   180â†’    {
   181â†’      id: 'supplements',
   182â†’      title: "Supplements: What Works (and What Doesn't)",
   183â†’      humorLevel: 'high',
   184â†’      content: `Let's address the elephant in the room: 90% of "hair growth supplements" are scams marketed to desperate people.
   185â†’
   186â†’**Actually Useful:**
   187â†’| Supplement | Evidence | Notes |
   188â†’|------------|----------|-------|
   189â†’| **Biotin** | Moderate | Only helps if deficient (most aren't) |
   190â†’| **Iron** | Strong (if deficient) | Get bloodwork first |
   191â†’| **Vitamin D** | Moderate | Most people are deficient anyway |
   192â†’| **Zinc** | Low-Moderate | Can help if deficient |
   193â†’| **Collagen Peptides** | Low | May support hair structure |
   194â†’
   195â†’**Probably Useless:**
   196â†’- Saw palmetto (weak DHT blocker, just take fin)
   197â†’- Hair gummies (sugar with marketing)
   198â†’- "Ancient Chinese herbs" (they're not)
   199â†’- Most expensive "hair growth vitamins"
   200â†’
   201â†’**The Reality:**
   202â†’If your nutrition is decent, supplements won't move the needle. The Big 3 moves the needle. Supplements are rounding errors.
   203â†’
   204â†’**When Supplements Help:**
   205â†’- Vegans/vegetarians (check iron, B12)
   206â†’- Restrictive dieters
   207â†’- Actual diagnosed deficiencies
   208â†’- People with gut absorption issues`,
   209â†’      products: ['biotin_10000'],
   210â†’    },
   211â†’    {
   212â†’      id: 'natural-options',
   213â†’      title: 'Natural Alternatives (For the Fin-Fearful)',
   214â†’      humorLevel: 'medium',
   215â†’      content: `Some guys can't or won't take finasteride. These are your optionsâ€”but set realistic expectations:
   216â†’
   217â†’**Rosemary Oil**
   218â†’- One study showed similar results to minoxidil
   219â†’- Apply diluted to scalp daily
   220â†’- Cheap and no side effects
   221â†’- Worth trying, but less proven than pharmaceutical options
   222â†’
   223â†’**Pumpkin Seed Oil**
   224â†’- Oral supplement with mild DHT-blocking properties
   225â†’- One Korean study showed improvement
   226â†’- Very mild effect compared to finasteride
   227â†’
   228â†’**Caffeine Shampoo**
   229â†’- May stimulate follicles slightly
   230â†’- No serious evidence it prevents loss
   231â†’- Won't hurt, might slightly help
   232â†’
   233â†’**Scalp Massage**
   234â†’- Increases blood flow
   235â†’- 10-20 minutes daily showed some improvement in one study
   236â†’- Free and relaxing, worst case you wasted some time
   237â†’
   238â†’**The Honest Assessment:**
   239â†’Natural options are like bringing a water gun to a forest fire. They might help slightly at the margins, but they won't stop aggressive hair loss. If you're serious about keeping your hair, the Big 3 is the answer.`,
   240â†’      products: ['rosemary_oil', 'scalp_massager'],
   241â†’    },
   242â†’    {
   243â†’      id: 'hair-transplant',
   244â†’      title: 'Hair Transplants: The Nuclear Option',
   245â†’      humorLevel: 'medium',
   246â†’      content: `When medications aren't enough or you've lost too much, transplants are the final answer.
   247â†’
   248â†’**Types:**
   249â†’| Method | Cost | Recovery | Best For |
   250â†’|--------|------|----------|----------|
   251â†’| **FUE** (Follicular Unit Extraction) | $4,000-15,000 | 1-2 weeks | Most cases, less scarring |
   252â†’| **FUT** (Strip Method) | $4,000-10,000 | 2-3 weeks | Maximum coverage, leaves scar |
   253â†’
   254â†’**Realistic Expectations:**
   255â†’- 1 transplant gives 2000-4000 grafts typically
   256â†’- You may need 2-3 sessions for full coverage
   257â†’- Results visible at 6-12 months
   258â†’- You STILL need finasteride after (to protect native hair)
   259â†’
   260â†’**Where to Go:**
   261â†’- **Turkey:** $2,000-4,000 (high volume, variable quality)
   262â†’- **Korea:** $5,000-10,000 (excellent technique)
   263â†’- **USA/UK:** $10,000-25,000 (top surgeons, highest cost)
   264â†’
   265â†’**Red Flags:**
   266â†’- Clinics promising unrealistic graft counts
   267â†’- Heavy discounts for "limited time"
   268â†’- No in-person consultation
   269â†’- Technicians doing the work, not surgeons
   270â†’
   271â†’**Who's a Good Candidate:**
   272â†’- NW3-5 with stable hair loss (on treatment)
   273â†’- Good donor area (back/sides)
   274â†’- Realistic expectations
   275â†’- Age 25+ (hair loss pattern stabilized)`,
   276â†’      tips: [
   277â†’        'Always get multiple consultations',
   278â†’        'Ask to see real before/after photos of similar cases',
   279â†’        'Being on finasteride for 1+ year before transplant is recommended',
   280â†’      ],
   281â†’      warnings: [
   282â†’        'NEVER get a transplant without stabilizing on the Big 3 first',
   283â†’        'Transplanted hair survives, but native hair keeps falling without treatment',
   284â†’      ],
   285â†’    },
   286â†’    {
   287â†’      id: 'the-acceptance-path',
   288â†’      title: 'The Acceptance Path: Bald and Confident',
   289â†’      humorLevel: 'medium-high',
   290â†’      content: `Sometimes the right move is to accept reality. Here's how to do it well:
   291â†’
   292â†’**When to Consider Shaving:**
   293â†’- NW6+ with poor donor area
   294â†’- Multiple failed treatments
   295â†’- Simply don't want the hassle
   296â†’- You've got a good head shape
   297â†’
   298â†’**The Bald Maxx Protocol:**
   299â†’1. **Shave or buzz it** â€” No comb-overs, no denial
   300â†’2. **Grow facial hair** â€” Beard balances the look
   301â†’3. **Get lean** â€” Face gains matter more without hair
   302â†’4. **Tan slightly** â€” Pale scalp with tan face looks odd
   303â†’5. **Own it** â€” Confidence is the real move
   304â†’
   305â†’**Bald Style Icons:**
   306â†’- Jason Statham (the prototype)
   307â†’- The Rock (mass monster version)
   308â†’- Stanley Tucci (distinguished version)
   309â†’- Johnny Sins (the meme but genuinely looks good)
   310â†’
   311â†’**The Cope Hierarchy:**
   312â†’1. **Best:** Shaved head + beard + lean face + confidence
   313â†’2. **Good:** Buzzed short, embracing it
   314â†’3. **Neutral:** Long top with thinning (temporary)
   315â†’4. **Avoid:** Comb-overs, hair systems, denial
   316â†’
   317â†’**The Mindset:**
   318â†’A confident bald man beats an insecure guy clinging to wisps every time. The issue was never the hairâ€”it was the attachment to it.`,
   319â†’    },
   320â†’    {
   321â†’      id: 'timeline',
   322â†’      title: 'Realistic Treatment Timeline',
   323â†’      humorLevel: 'medium',
   324â†’      content: `Hair recovery is a marathon, not a sprint. Here's what to expect:
   325â†’
   326â†’**Month 1-3:**
   327â†’- Starting the Big 3
   328â†’- Possible shedding (the "dread shed")
   329â†’- No visible improvement yet
   330â†’- This is where most guys quit (don't)
   331â†’
   332â†’**Month 4-6:**
   333â†’- Shedding stops
   334â†’- Some stabilization visible
   335â†’- Possibly noticing less daily loss
   336â†’- Photos might show subtle improvement
   337â†’
   338â†’**Month 7-12:**
   339â†’- Real improvement visible
   340â†’- Thicker coverage in thinning areas
   341â†’- Better hair quality and texture
   342â†’- Photos now show clear difference
   343â†’

   359â†’    {

   361â†’      title: 'Common Hair Loss Mistakes',
   362â†’      humorLevel: 'high',
   363â†’      content: `Don't be these guys:
   364â†’
   365â†’**Mistake 1: Waiting Too Long**
   366â†’"I'll start treatment when it gets worse." By then you've lost hair that won't come back. Start early, keep more.
