/**
 * Core & Neck Training Guide
 * Humor Level: Medium (15%)
 */

import { Guide } from '@/types/guides';

export const coreNeckGuide: Guide = {
  id: 'core-neck',
  slug: 'core-neck-training',
  title: 'Core & Neck Training',
  subtitle: "The overlooked muscles that change everything",
  description: "Build a solid core for posture and a thick neck for masculine presence. Both are underrated game-changers.",
  icon: 'Target',
  humorLevel: 'medium',
  estimatedReadTime: 8,
  order: 6,
  tags: ['core', 'neck', 'posture', 'training', 'aesthetics'],
  relatedGuides: ['training', 'v-taper', 'body-fat'],
  productIds: ['creatine_mono'],
  forumCategory: 'height-frame',
  sections: [
    {
      id: 'intro',
      title: 'Why Core and Neck Matter',
      humorLevel: 'medium',
      content: `Two of the most overlooked muscle groups that have outsized impact on your appearance:

**The Neck:**
A thick neck makes your head look proportionate, adds masculinity, and completely changes how you're perceived. Think about the difference between a pencil neck and a football player neck. Night and day.

**The Core:**
Beyond aesthetics, a strong core improves posture, supports lifting heavy, and defines that V-taper from waist. Weak core = weak everything else.

Most guys skip both because:
- Neck training seems weird or unsafe
- Core work is boring (crunches in the corner)
- Neither is a "mirror muscle"

This is a mistake. Both are trainable, and both pay massive dividends.`,
    },
    {
      id: 'neck-benefits',
      title: 'Neck: The Masculine Multiplier',
      humorLevel: 'medium-high',
      content: `A thick neck is one of the most underrated aesthetic upgrades you can make:

**Visual Benefits:**
- Head looks proportionate to body
- Jawline appears stronger
- More masculine/dominant presence
- Fills out shirt collars
- Better photos from every angle

**Functional Benefits:**
- Reduced neck pain
- Better posture support
- Injury prevention (sports, accidents)
- Improved head position for mewing

**The Reality:**
Compare a skinny neck to a thick neck on the same person. It's a completely different look. Yet almost nobody trains it.

The neck is one of the fastest-growing muscle groups because most people have never trained it. You can add an inch to your neck in 2-3 months with consistent training.`,
    },
    {
      id: 'neck-anatomy',
      title: 'Neck Muscles to Train',
      humorLevel: 'low',
      content: `Understanding what you're training helps you train it better:

**Sternocleidomastoid (SCM)**
- The muscles on the front/sides of your neck
- Creates that "thick neck" look from the front
- Trained with neck curls and lateral flexion

**Trapezius (Upper Traps)**
- The muscles connecting neck to shoulders
- Creates width and thickness from behind
- Trained with shrugs and neck extensions

**Splenius (Deep Neck Extensors)**
- Muscles on the back of the neck
- Important for head position and posture
- Trained with neck extensions

**Scalenes**
- Side of neck, often tight from desk work
- Important for balanced development
- Trained with lateral neck flexion

**Training All Directions:**
The neck moves in four directions:
1. Flexion (chin to chest)
2. Extension (looking up)
3. Lateral flexion (ear to shoulder)
4. Rotation (turning head)

Train all of them for balanced development.`,
    },
    {

   367â†’- Sport-specific conditioning
   368â†’- HIIT: 2-3x/week
   369â†’- LISS: Active recovery days
   370â†’- Total: 3-5 hours
   371â†’
   372â†’**Adjusting:**
   373â†’- Scale slowing? Add 1 session or 2,000 steps
   374â†’- Feeling overtrained? Remove HIIT first
   375â†’- Recovery suffering? Reduce intensity before frequency`,
   376â†’    },
   377â†’    {
   378â†’      id: 'action-plan',
   379â†’      title: 'Your Action Plan',
   380â†’      humorLevel: 'medium',
   381â†’      content: `Here's how to implement cardio effectively:
   382â†’
   383â†’**Step 1: Track Current Activity**
   384â†’Wear a tracker for a week. See your baseline steps and activity.
   385â†’
   386â†’**Step 2: Set Your Target**
   387â†’Based on your goal (see previous section). Start conservative and build.
   388â†’
   389â†’**Step 3: Prioritize Walking**
   390â†’Get to 10,000 steps before adding formal cardio. This is the foundation.
   391â†’
   392â†’**Step 4: Add Formal Cardio If Needed**
   393â†’Only if steps + diet isn't creating enough deficit, add:
   394â†’- LISS first (2-3x/week, 20-30 min)
   395â†’- HIIT second (1x/week, 15-20 min)
   396â†’
   397â†’**Step 5: Protect Your Lifting**
   398â†’- Never do cardio before lifting
   399â†’- Keep HIIT away from leg days
   400â†’- Eat adequately (don't stack deficit + excess cardio)
   401â†’
   402â†’**Step 6: Adjust Based on Results**
   403â†’- Losing too fast? Reduce cardio, add food
   404â†’- Not losing? Add steps or one session
   405â†’- Feeling exhausted? More LISS, less HIIT
   406â†’
   407â†’**Remember:**
   408â†’Cardio is a tool, not the goal. Use it strategically. More is not always better. Diet is the primary driver of fat lossâ€”cardio is the accelerator, not the engine.`,
   409â†’    },
   410â†’  ],
   411â†’};
   412â†’

/**
 * Cardio Guide
 * Humor Level: Medium (15%)
 */

import { Guide } from '@/types/guides';

export const cardioGuide: Guide = {
  id: 'cardio',
  slug: 'cardio-training',
  title: 'Cardio Training',
  subtitle: "Not just for losing fatâ€”but also for losing fat",
  description: "Strategic cardio for fat loss, conditioning, and health without killing your gains. Find the right balance.",
  icon: 'Heart',
  humorLevel: 'medium',
  estimatedReadTime: 8,
  order: 7,
  tags: ['cardio', 'fat-loss', 'conditioning', 'heart-health'],
  relatedGuides: ['body-fat', 'training', 'diet'],
  productIds: ['magnesium_glycinate', 'omega3_fish_oil'],
  forumCategory: 'body-composition',
  heroMedia: {
    id: 'cardio-hero',
    type: 'image',
    url: 'https://images.unsplash.com/photo-1571008887538-b36bb32f4571?w=1200&q=80',
    alt: 'Cardio training and running',
    placement: 'hero',
  },
  sections: [
    {
      id: 'intro',
      title: 'The Cardio Debate',
      humorLevel: 'medium',
      content: `There are two extreme camps on cardio:

**Camp 1: "Cardio kills gains"**
- Never steps on a treadmill
- Gets winded walking up stairs
- Can bench 300 but can't jog a mile

**Camp 2: "Cardio is everything"**
- Runs marathons
- Skinny-fat physique
- No muscle to show for their efforts

**The Truth:**
Both are wrong. Cardio is a tool. Like any tool, it's about how you use it.

Used correctly, cardio:
- Accelerates fat loss
- Improves heart health
- Increases work capacity
- Enhances recovery between sets
- Doesn't destroy muscle gains

The key is knowing when, how much, and what type.`,
      media: [
        {
          id: 'cardio-intro',
          type: 'image',
          url: 'https://images.unsplash.com/photo-1538805060514-97d9cc17730c?w=800&q=80',
          alt: 'Running and cardio training',
          caption: 'Cardio is a toolâ€”use it strategically',
          placement: 'inline',
        },
      ],
    },
    {
      id: 'fat-loss-math',
      title: 'Cardio and Fat Loss: The Math',
      humorLevel: 'medium',
      content: `Let's get the fundamentals clear:

**The Equation:**
Fat Loss = Calories Out > Calories In

Cardio increases "calories out." That's it. No magic.

**The Numbers:**
- 30 min walking (3.5 mph): ~150 calories
- 30 min jogging (5 mph): ~300 calories
- 30 min cycling (moderate): ~250 calories
- 30 min HIIT: ~300-400 calories

**The Reality Check:**
A single Snickers bar is 250 calories. You'd need 30 minutes of jogging to burn that off. This is why diet is the primary lever for fat loss, not cardio.

**Where Cardio Helps:**
1. Creating a bigger deficit without eating less
2. Allowing more food flexibility while still losing
3. Breaking plateaus when diet is already dialed in
4. General health benefits beyond fat loss

**The Mistake:**
Using cardio to "earn" food. This creates an unhealthy relationship and usually results in eating more than you burned.`,
    },
    {
      id: 'liss',
      title: 'LISS: Low Intensity Steady State',
      humorLevel: 'medium',
      content: `LISS is exactly what it sounds like: low intensity, sustained duration.

**Examples:**
- Walking (incline or flat)
- Light cycling
- Elliptical at conversational pace
- Swimming easy laps

**Heart Rate Zone:**
Zone 2 cardio: 60-70% of max heart rate
(Roughly: 220 - your age = max, then multiply by 0.6-0.7)

**Benefits:**
- Minimal interference with lifting
- Easy to recover from
- Can do fasted without issues
- Burns primarily fat for fuel
- Low impact on joints
- Can do daily if needed

**Protocol:**
- Duration: 20-45 minutes
- Frequency: 2-5x per week depending on goals
- When: Morning fasted, post-workout, or separate session

**The Walking Hack:**
10,000 steps per day burns an extra 300-500 calories. This is NEAT (non-exercise activity thermogenesis) and is often more effective than formal cardio because it's sustainable and doesn't feel like "exercise."`,
      tips: [
        'Walking is underratedâ€”10K steps/day is a game changer',
        'Incline walking burns more than flat without adding impact',
        'Can do LISS daily without recovery issues'
      ],
      media: [
        {
          id: 'liss-walking',
          type: 'image',
          url: 'https://images.unsplash.com/photo-1476480862126-209bfaa8edc8?w=800&q=80',
          alt: 'Walking for cardio and fat loss',
          caption: 'Walking: The most sustainable cardio',
          placement: 'inline',
        },
      ],
    },
    {
      id: 'hiit',
      title: 'HIIT: High Intensity Interval Training',
      humorLevel: 'medium',
      content: `HIIT alternates between intense effort and rest periods.

**Examples:**
- Sprints (track, bike, rower)
- Battle ropes
- Burpees/jump squats intervals
- Cycling sprints

**Structure:**
- 20-30 seconds max effort
- 60-90 seconds recovery
- Repeat 6-10 rounds
- Total: 15-25 minutes

**Benefits:**
- Time efficient (done in 20 minutes)
- Burns more calories per minute than LISS
- EPOC effect (elevated metabolism post-workout)
- Improves anaerobic conditioning
- More engaging than steady state

**Drawbacks:**
- Harder to recover from
- Can interfere with leg days
- Higher injury risk if form breaks down
- Not sustainable daily
- Actually requires max effort (most people don't go hard enough)

**Frequency:**
- 1-3 sessions per week max
- Not on leg day or day before
- Requires 48+ hours recovery

**The Truth About HIIT:**
Most people's "HIIT" is really "medium intensity interval training." True HIIT is incredibly demandingâ€”you should feel like dying after the work intervals. If you can do more than 20-25 minutes, you're not going hard enough.`,
      warnings: [
        'True HIIT is brutalâ€”most people do it wrong',
        'Limit to 2-3x/week to allow recovery',
        'Not recommended for complete beginners'
      ],
      media: [
        {
          id: 'hiit-training',
          type: 'image',
          url: 'https://images.unsplash.com/photo-1549060279-7e168fcee0c2?w=800&q=80',
          alt: 'High intensity interval training',
          caption: 'HIIT: Maximum effort, minimum time',
          placement: 'inline',
        },
      ],
    },
    {
      id: 'liss-vs-hiit',
      title: 'LISS vs HIIT: Which Is Better?',
      humorLevel: 'medium',
      content: `The eternal debate. Here's the breakdown:

**LISS Wins When:**
- You're already doing intense lifting 4-6x/week
- Recovery is limited (sleep, stress, nutrition issues)
- Joint health is a concern
- You need daily cardio for deficit
- You're a beginner to cardio

**HIIT Wins When:**
- You're short on time
- You only need 1-2 cardio sessions per week
- Your lifting program is less demanding
- You want conditioning benefits beyond fat loss
- You're already fit and recover well

**The Optimal Approach:**
Combine both:
- 2-4x LISS per week (walking, incline, cycling)
- 1-2x HIIT per week (if recovery allows)
- Adjust based on how you feel and progress

**The Research:**
For pure fat loss, total calories burned matters mostâ€”not the type of cardio. LISS and HIIT are roughly equivalent when total calorie expenditure is matched.

Choose based on:
1. What you'll actually do consistently
2. What you can recover from
3. What fits your schedule`,
    },
    {
      id: 'preserving-muscle',
      title: 'Cardio Without Killing Gains',
      humorLevel: 'medium-high',
      content: `The fear of "losing gains" to cardio is overblown. But there are real considerations:

**What Actually Hurts Gains:**
1. Too much cardio volume (hours per week)
2. Running long distances (marathon training)
3. HIIT on leg days or day before
4. Cardio in a severe calorie deficit without adequate protein
5. Prioritizing cardio over lifting

**What Doesn't Hurt Gains:**
1. Walking (any amount)
2. 20-30 min LISS 3-5x/week
3. Cycling (often even complements leg training)
4. 1-2 HIIT sessions per week with recovery
5. General activity throughout the day

**The Protocol for Muscle Preservation:**
1. Lift first, cardio second (always)
2. Separate lifting and cardio by 6+ hours if possible
3. Keep HIIT away from leg training
4. Eat adequate protein (1g/lb)
5. Keep cardio modestâ€”enough for goals, not more

**The Truth:**
Moderate cardio (3-5 hours per week) does not meaningfully impair muscle growth when nutrition and lifting are on point. The guys who lose muscle to cardio are usually:
- Doing way too much cardio
- Not eating enough
- Not lifting with enough intensity`,
    },
    {
      id: 'fasted-cardio',
      title: 'Fasted Cardio: Does It Work?',
      humorLevel: 'medium',
      content: `The idea: do cardio before eating to burn more fat.

**The Theory:**
- Glycogen is low after sleeping
- Body will use fat for fuel
- More fat burned during the session

**The Research:**
- Yes, more fat is burned DURING fasted cardio
- BUT total 24-hour fat oxidation is the same
- Your body compensates later in the day
- Overall fat loss is determined by total deficit, not timing

**When Fasted Cardio Makes Sense:**
1. You prefer it (some people have more energy fasted)
2. Scheduling (morning before work is your only option)
3. You don't like eating before exercise
4. LISS specifically (HIIT fasted can be rough)

**When It Doesn't:**
1. You feel weak or dizzy fasted
2. You're doing HIIT or intense training
3. Performance matters (fed = better performance)
4. You have blood sugar issues

**The Bottom Line:**
Fasted vs fed cardio is personal preference. Total calorie balance matters more than timing. Do whatever helps you stay consistent.`,
    },
    {
      id: 'step-count',
      title: 'The Daily Step Count Approach',
      humorLevel: 'medium',
      content: `Forget formal cardio sessions. Here's a simpler approach:

**The Concept:**
Track daily steps instead of scheduled cardio. Walking is the most sustainable, lowest-impact form of movement.

**The Target:**
- Minimum: 7,000 steps/day
- Good: 10,000 steps/day
- Optimal: 12,000-15,000 steps/day

**The Math:**
- 10,000 steps â‰ˆ 5 miles â‰ˆ 400-500 calories
- That's 2,800-3,500 extra calories per week
- Roughly 0.5-1 lb of fat loss potential

**How to Get Steps:**
1. Walk during phone calls
2. Park farther away
3. Take stairs always
4. Walking meetings
5. Post-meal walks (also helps blood sugar)
6. Dedicated 30-45 min walk daily
7. Walking desk/treadmill desk

**Why This Works:**
- Doesn't feel like exercise
- Easy to recover from
- Fits into daily life
- Sustainable long-term
- Burns significant calories over time

**For Cutting:**
Many people find step count + lifting more sustainable than formal cardio. Walking is the secret weapon.`,
      tips: [
        'Get a step-tracking watch or use your phone',
        'Morning walks start the day with momentum',
        'Post-dinner walks improve digestion and sleep'
      ],
    },
    {
      id: 'programming',
      title: 'Cardio Programming by Goal',
      humorLevel: 'medium',
      content: `Here's how to structure cardio based on your current goal:

**Goal: Fat Loss (Primary)**
- Steps: 10,000-12,000 daily
- LISS: 20-30 min, 3-4x/week
- HIIT: 1x/week optional
- Total: 3-5 hours including walking

**Goal: Maintenance/Health**
- Steps: 8,000-10,000 daily
- LISS: 20-30 min, 2-3x/week
- HIIT: 1x/week
- Total: 2-3 hours

**Goal: Building Muscle (Minimize Cardio)**
- Steps: 7,000-10,000 daily
- LISS: 15-20 min, 2x/week
- HIIT: 0-1x/week
- Total: 1-2 hours

**Goal: Athletic Performance**
- Steps: As needed
- Sport-specific conditioning
- HIIT: 2-3x/week
- LISS: Active recovery days
- Total: 3-5 hours

**Adjusting:**
- Scale slowing? Add 1 session or 2,000 steps
- Feeling overtrained? Remove HIIT first
- Recovery suffering? Reduce intensity before frequency`,
    },
    {
      id: 'action-plan',
      title: 'Your Action Plan',
      humorLevel: 'medium',
      content: `Here's how to implement cardio effectively:

**Step 1: Track Current Activity**
Wear a tracker for a week. See your baseline steps and activity.

**Step 2: Set Your Target**
Based on your goal (see previous section). Start conservative and build.

**Step 3: Prioritize Walking**
Get to 10,000 steps before adding formal cardio. This is the foundation.

**Step 4: Add Formal Cardio If Needed**
Only if steps + diet isn't creating enough deficit, add:
- LISS first (2-3x/week, 20-30 min)
- HIIT second (1x/week, 15-20 min)

**Step 5: Protect Your Lifting**
- Never do cardio before lifting
- Keep HIIT away from leg days
- Eat adequately (don't stack deficit + excess cardio)

**Step 6: Adjust Based on Results**
- Losing too fast? Reduce cardio, add food
- Not losing? Add steps or one session
- Feeling exhausted? More LISS, less HIIT

**Remember:**
Cardio is a tool, not the goal. Use it strategically. More is not always better. Diet is the primary driver of fat lossâ€”cardio is the accelerator, not the engine.`,
    },
  ],
};

content.content:
1â†’/**
     2â†’ * Diet & Nutrition Guide
     3â†’ * Humor Level: Medium (15%)
     4â†’ */
     5â†’
     6â†’import { Guide } from '@/types/guides';
     7â†’
     8â†’export const dietGuide: Guide = {
     9â†’  id: 'diet',
    10â†’  slug: 'diet-nutrition',
    11â†’  title: 'Diet & Nutrition',
    12â†’  subtitle: "You can't out-train a bad diet",
    13â†’  description: "The fundamentals of eating for aesthetics. Protein, calories, and what actually matters vs what doesn't.",
    14â†’  icon: 'Utensils',
    15â†’  humorLevel: 'medium',
    16â†’  estimatedReadTime: 15,
    17â†’  order: 8,
    18â†’  tags: ['nutrition', 'diet', 'protein', 'calories', 'macros'],
    19â†’  relatedGuides: ['body-fat', 'training', 'v-taper'],
    20â†’  productIds: ['food_scale', 'creatine_mono', 'omega3_fish_oil', 'collagen_peptides', 'vitamin_d3_k2', 'magnesium_glycinate'],
    21â†’  forumCategory: 'body-composition',
    22â†’  heroMedia: {
    23â†’    id: 'diet-hero',
    24â†’    type: 'image',
    25â†’    url: 'https://images.unsplash.com/photo-1490645935967-10de6ba17061?w=1200&q=80',
    26â†’    alt: 'Healthy meal prep and nutrition',
    27â†’    placement: 'hero',
    28â†’  },
    29â†’  sections: [
    30â†’    {
    31â†’      id: 'intro',
    32â†’      title: 'The Foundation of Everything',
    33â†’      humorLevel: 'medium',
    34â†’      content: `Your physique is built in the kitchen, revealed in the gym.
    35â†’
    36â†’You can train perfectly, but if your nutrition is garbage:
    37â†’- You won't build muscle efficiently
    38â†’- You won't lose fat predictably
    39â†’- You'll look the same in 6 months
    40â†’
    41â†’**The Good News:**
    42â†’Nutrition is simpler than the internet makes it seem. Most of the complexity is unnecessary.
    43â†’
    44â†’**What Actually Matters (80% of results):**
    45â†’1. Total calories (energy balance)
    46â†’2. Protein intake
    47â†’3. Food quality (mostly)
    48â†’4. Consistency
    49â†’
    50â†’**What Barely Matters (20% optimization):**
    51â†’- Meal timing
    52â†’- Specific food choices within reason
    53â†’- Supplement stacks beyond basics
    54â†’- Nutrient timing around workouts
    55â†’
    56â†’Let's cover the 80% first.`,
    57â†’      media: [
    58â†’        {
    59â†’          id: 'diet-intro',
    60â†’          type: 'image',
    61â†’          url: 'https://images.unsplash.com/photo-1498837167922-ddd27525d352?w=800&q=80',
    62â†’          alt: 'Healthy food and nutrition',
    63â†’          caption: 'Your physique is built in the kitchen',
    64â†’          placement: 'inline',
    65â†’        },
    66â†’        {
    67â†’          id: 'sigma-diet-gif',
    68â†’          type: 'gif',
    69â†’          url: 'https://media.giphy.com/media/guNXesWtLfqOfnWwmx/giphy.gif',
    70â†’          alt: 'Patrick Bateman sigma mindset',
    71â†’          caption: 'The sigma diet grindset',
    72â†’          placement: 'inline',
    73â†’        },
    74â†’      ],
    75â†’    },
    76â†’    {
    77â†’      id: 'calories',
    78â†’      title: 'Calories: The Master Variable',
    79â†’      humorLevel: 'medium',
    80â†’      content: `Everything else is secondary to energy balance.
    81â†’
    82â†’**The Basic Math:**
    83â†’- Calories In > Calories Out = Weight Gain
    84â†’- Calories In < Calories Out = Weight Loss
    85â†’- Calories In = Calories Out = Maintenance
    86â†’
    87â†’**Finding Your Maintenance:**
    88â†’Method 1: Calculator estimate
    89â†’- TDEE calculator gives starting point
    90â†’- Typically 14-17 x bodyweight (in lbs)
    91â†’- Active people higher, sedentary lower
    92â†’
    93â†’Method 2: Track and observe
    94â†’- Eat the same for 2 weeks
    95â†’- Track weight daily, average weekly
    96â†’- Stable = maintenance. Rising = surplus. Dropping = deficit.
    97â†’
    98â†’**Setting Your Target:**
    99â†’
   100â†’| Goal | Calorie Target |
   101â†’|------|---------------|
   102â†’| Fat Loss | Maintenance - 300-500 |
   103â†’| Maintenance | TDEE |
   104â†’| Lean Bulk | Maintenance + 200-300 |
   105â†’| Standard Bulk | Maintenance + 400-500 |
   106â†’
   107â†’**The Mistake:**
   108â†’Going too aggressive. A 1000 calorie deficit sounds fast but leads to muscle loss, metabolic adaptation, and binges. Slow and steady wins.`,
   109â†’      products: ['food_scale'],
   110â†’      tips: [
   111â†’        'Use a food scale for accuracyâ€”eyeballing is notoriously wrong',
   112â†’        'Track for 2-4 weeks to learn your foods, then you can estimate',
   113â†’        'Weekly average matters more than daily fluctuations'
   114â†’      ],
   115â†’    },
   116â†’    {
   117â†’      id: 'protein',
   118â†’      title: 'Protein: The King of Macros',
   119â†’      humorLevel: 'medium',
   120â†’      content: `If you remember one thing from this guide: hit your protein.
   121â†’
   122â†’**Why Protein Is King:**
   123â†’- Builds and preserves muscle
   124â†’- Most satiating macro (keeps you full)
   125â†’- Highest thermic effect (burns calories to digest)
   126â†’- Hardest to store as fat
   127â†’
   128â†’**How Much:**
   129â†’- Minimum: 0.7g per pound of bodyweight
   130â†’- Optimal: 0.8-1g per pound of bodyweight
   131â†’- Upper limit: More than 1.2g/lb has no additional benefit
   132â†’
   133â†’**For a 180lb Guy:**
   134â†’- Minimum: 126g daily
   135â†’- Optimal: 144-180g daily
   136â†’
   137â†’**Best Protein Sources:**
   138â†’
   139â†’| Source | Protein per 100g |
   140â†’|--------|-----------------|
   141â†’| Chicken breast | 31g |
   142â†’| Lean beef | 26g |
   143â†’| Salmon | 25g |
   144â†’| Greek yogurt | 10g |
   145â†’| Eggs | 13g |
   146â†’| Cottage cheese | 11g |
   147â†’| Whey protein | 80g |
   148â†’
   149â†’**Hitting It Daily:**
   150â†’- Each meal should have a protein source
   151â†’- 30-50g per meal, 3-4 meals
   152â†’- Fill gaps with protein shakes if needed
   153â†’- Front-load protein earlier in day for satiety`,
   154â†’      media: [
   155â†’        {
   156â†’          id: 'protein-chart',
   157â†’          type: 'image',
   158â†’          url: 'https://thenutritionjunky.com/wp-content/uploads/2023/08/High-protein-foods-chart-with-printable-PDF-blog-images-1200-x-700-px.jpg',
   159â†’          alt: 'High protein foods chart showing protein content per serving',
   160â†’          caption: 'Visual guide: Protein content in common foods',
   161â†’          placement: 'inline',
   162â†’        },
   163â†’      ],
   164â†’    },
   165â†’    {
   166â†’      id: 'carbs-fats',
   167â†’      title: 'Carbs and Fats: The Flexible Macros',
   168â†’      humorLevel: 'medium',
   169â†’      content: `After calories and protein, carbs and fats are flexible. Here's how to think about them:
   170â†’
   171â†’**Fats: The Minimum**
   172â†’- Never go below 0.3g/lb bodyweight
   173â†’- Fats are essential for hormones (testosterone)
   174â†’- Too low = hormone problems, brain fog, bad skin
   175â†’- For 180lb: minimum 54g fat daily
   176â†’
   177â†’**Carbs: The Performance Fuel**
   178â†’- Not "essential" but highly beneficial for training
   179â†’- Fill remaining calories after protein and fat
   180â†’- More carbs = better gym performance
   181â†’- Lower carbs = some people do better for fat loss
   182â†’
   183â†’**Setting Macros (Example: 180lb guy, 2500 calories)**
   184â†’
   185â†’Option 1: Moderate carb (recommended)
   186â†’- Protein: 180g (720 cal)
   187â†’- Fat: 80g (720 cal)
   188â†’- Carbs: 265g (1060 cal)
   189â†’
   190â†’Option 2: Lower carb
   191â†’- Protein: 180g (720 cal)
   192â†’- Fat: 100g (900 cal)
   193â†’- Carbs: 220g (880 cal)
   194â†’
   195â†’Option 3: Higher carb (athletic)
   196â†’- Protein: 180g (720 cal)
   197â†’- Fat: 60g (540 cal)
   198â†’- Carbs: 310g (1240 cal)
   199â†’
   200â†’**The Truth:**
   201â†’For most people, the exact ratio doesn't matter much. Hit protein, stay in your calorie range, and adjust carbs/fats based on preference and how you feel.`,
   202â†’    },
   203â†’    {
   204â†’      id: 'food-quality',
   205â†’      title: 'Food Quality: What to Actually Eat',
   206â†’      humorLevel: 'medium-high',
   207â†’      content: `Here's where things get simpler than the internet suggests:
   208â†’
   209â†’**The 80/20 Rule:**
   210â†’- 80% whole, minimally processed foods
   211â†’- 20% whatever you want
   212â†’
   213â†’This keeps you sane while getting results.
   214â†’
   215â†’**Whole Foods (Prioritize These):**
   216â†’
   217â†’**Proteins:**
   218â†’- Chicken, turkey, lean beef, fish
   219â†’- Eggs, Greek yogurt, cottage cheese
   220â†’- Whey/casein protein powder
   221â†’
   222â†’**Carbs:**
   223â†’- Rice, potatoes, oats
   224â†’- Fruits, vegetables
   225â†’- Whole grain bread/pasta
   226â†’
   227â†’**Fats:**
   228â†’- Olive oil, avocados
   229â†’- Nuts, seeds
   230â†’- Fatty fish (salmon)
   231â†’- Eggs
   232â†’
   233â†’**Minimize (Not Eliminate):**
   234â†’- Fried foods
   235â†’- Sugary snacks and drinks
   236â†’- Processed meats regularly
   237â†’- Alcohol (empty calories + lowers testosterone + disrupts sleep)
   238â†’
   239â†’**The Why:**
   240â†’Whole foods are more filling per calorie, have more micronutrients, and are harder to overeat. You can lose weight on junk food (calories are calories), but you'll be hungrier and less healthy.`,
   241â†’      media: [
   242â†’        {
   243â†’          id: 'whole-foods',
   244â†’          type: 'image',
   245â†’          url: 'https://images.unsplash.com/photo-1512621776951-a57141f2eefd?w=800&q=80',
   246â†’          alt: 'Whole foods and vegetables',
   247â†’          caption: '80% whole foods, 20% whatever you want',
   248â†’          placement: 'inline',
   249â†’        },
   250â†’      ],
   251â†’    },
   252â†’    {
   253â†’      id: 'meal-structure',
   254â†’      title: 'Meal Structure and Timing',
   255â†’      humorLevel: 'medium',
   256â†’      content: `Meal timing is overrated for results but matters for adherence and performance.
   257â†’
   258â†’**The Basics:**
   259â†’- Total daily intake matters more than timing
   260â†’- 3-5 meals per day works for most people
   261â†’- Don't overthink it
   262â†’
   263â†’**What Slightly Matters:**
   264â†’
   265â†’1. **Pre-Workout (1-2 hours before)**
   266â†’   - Carbs + protein = better performance
   267â†’   - Don't train completely fasted if you can help it
   268â†’   - Something > nothing
   269â†’
   270â†’2. **Post-Workout (within 2-3 hours)**
   271â†’   - Protein helps start recovery
   272â†’   - The "anabolic window" is way longer than old bro-science claimed
   273â†’   - Just eat normally, don't stress
   274â†’
   275â†’3. **Before Bed**
   276â†’   - Casein or slow protein can help overnight recovery
   277â†’   - Not essential, just nice
   278â†’
   279â†’**A Simple Day Structure:**
   280â†’
   281â†’- Breakfast: Protein + carbs + fats
   282â†’- Lunch: Protein + carbs + vegetables
   283â†’- Pre-workout: Light carbs + protein if needed
   284â†’- Dinner: Protein + carbs + vegetables
   285â†’- Optional snack: Protein if needed to hit target
   286â†’
   287â†’**Intermittent Fasting:**
   288â†’Some people like it. It doesn't burn more fat, but it can help control calories if you're bad at small meals. Personal preference.`,
   289â†’    },
   290â†’    {
   291â†’      id: 'cutting',
   292â†’      title: 'Eating for Fat Loss',
   293â†’      humorLevel: 'medium',
   294â†’      content: `When cutting, everything matters a bit more:
   295â†’
   296â†’**The Setup:**
   297â†’1. Calculate maintenance calories
   298â†’2. Subtract 300-500 calories
   299â†’3. Set protein at 1g/lb (higher end when cutting)
   300â†’4. Fill remaining with carbs and fats
   301â†’
   302â†’**Maximizing Satiety:**
   303â†’- High volume, low calorie foods (vegetables, lean proteins)
   304â†’- More protein = more fullness
   305â†’- High fiber foods
   306â†’- Drink water before meals
   307â†’- Eat slowly
   308â†’
   309â†’**Volume Eating Foods:**
   310â†’| Food | Calories per 100g |
   311â†’|------|------------------|
   312â†’| Lettuce | 5 |
   313â†’| Cucumber | 16 |
   314â†’| Egg whites | 52 |
   315â†’| Chicken breast | 165 |
   316â†’| Potatoes (boiled) | 77 |
   317â†’| Greek yogurt (0%) | 59 |
   318â†’
   319â†’You can eat 500g of potatoes for the same calories as 50g of chips. Volume matters.
   320â†’
   321â†’**Cutting Mistakes:**
   322â†’1. Going too aggressive (muscle loss, rebound)
   323â†’2. Cutting protein (preserves muscle)
   324â†’3. Eliminating carbs entirely (tanks performance)
   325â†’4. Weekend binges (erases weekly deficit)
   326â†’5. Not tracking (guessing incorrectly)`,
   327â†’      tips: [
   328â†’        'Weigh daily, average weeklyâ€”weight fluctuates',
   329â†’        "0.5-1% of bodyweight loss per week is optimal",
   330â†’        'Hunger is normal but not unbearableâ€”adjust if miserable'
   331â†’      ],
   332â†’    },
   333â†’    {
   334â†’      id: 'bulking',
   335â†’      title: 'Eating for Muscle Gain',
   336â†’      humorLevel: 'medium',
   337â†’      content: `Bulking done right builds muscle. Bulking done wrong just makes you fat.
   338â†’
   339â†’**The Setup:**
   340â†’1. Calculate maintenance
   341â†’2. Add 200-300 calories (lean bulk) or 400-500 (standard bulk)
   342â†’3. Set protein at 0.8-1g/lb
   343â†’4. Distribute remaining to carbs and fats (favor carbs for training)
   344â†’
   345â†’**Lean Bulk vs Dirty Bulk:**
   346â†’
   347â†’| Approach | Surplus | Result |
   348â†’|----------|---------|--------|
   349â†’| Lean bulk | +200-300 | Slow muscle gain, minimal fat |
   350â†’| Standard bulk | +400-500 | Good muscle gain, some fat |
   351â†’| Dirty bulk | +1000+ | Some muscle, lots of fat |
   352â†’
   353â†’**Recommendation:**
   354â†’Lean bulk unless you're very underweight. Gaining fat doesn't build muscle faster, it just means a longer cut later.
   355â†’
   356â†’**Weight Gain Rate:**
   357â†’- Beginners: 2-4 lbs/month possible
   358â†’- Intermediate: 1-2 lbs/month realistic
   359â†’- Advanced: 0.5-1 lb/month if lucky
   360â†’
   361â†’**If weight isn't going up:**
   362â†’You're not eating enough. Track more accurately and add 100-200 calories.
   363â†’
   364â†’**Bulking Mistakes:**
   365â†’1. Gaining too fast ("I'll cut later" â†’ never cuts)
   366â†’2. Dirty bulking (just makes you fat)
   367â†’3. Not tracking (surplus might actually be deficit)
   368â†’4. Using bulk as excuse to eat garbage`,
   369â†’    },
   370â†’    {
   371â†’      id: 'supplements',
   372â†’      title: 'Supplements That Actually Work',
   373â†’      humorLevel: 'medium-high',
   374â†’      content: `Most supplements are garbage. Here's what's worth your money:
   375â†’
   376â†’**Tier 1: Actually Works**
   377â†’
   378â†’1. **Creatine Monohydrate**
   379â†’   - 5g daily, any time
   380â†’   - Strength, size, cognition
   381â†’   - Costs $0.10/day
   382â†’   - No loading needed
   383â†’
   384â†’2. **Protein Powder**
   385â†’   - Convenient protein source
   386â†’   - Whey, casein, or plant-based
   387â†’   - Not magic, just food in powder form
   388â†’
   389â†’3. **Vitamin D3**
   390â†’   - Most people are deficient
   391â†’   - 2000-5000 IU daily
   392â†’   - Get blood work to confirm
   393â†’
   394â†’4. **Omega-3 (Fish Oil)**
   395â†’   - Anti-inflammatory
   396â†’   - Brain and heart health
   397â†’   - 2-3g EPA/DHA daily
   398â†’
   399â†’**Tier 2: Situationally Useful**
   400â†’
   401â†’5. **Caffeine** â€” Performance boost (from coffee is fine)
   402â†’6. **Magnesium** â€” Most people are deficient, helps sleep
   403â†’7. **Collagen** â€” May help joints and skin
   404â†’8. **Zinc** â€” If deficient (many are)
   405â†’
   406â†’**Tier 3: Probably Wasting Money**
   407â†’
   408â†’- BCAAs (get protein instead)
   409â†’- Fat burners (mostly caffeine + fillers)
   410â†’- Testosterone boosters (don't work)
   411â†’- Most pre-workouts (caffeine + expensive pixie dust)
   412â†’
   413â†’**The Rule:**
   414â†’Get 95% of results from food. Use supplements to fill gaps, not replace meals.`,
   415â†’      products: ['creatine_mono', 'omega3_fish_oil', 'vitamin_d3_k2', 'magnesium_glycinate', 'collagen_peptides'],
   416â†’    },
   417â†’    {
   418â†’      id: 'practical',
   419â†’      title: 'Practical Meal Prep',
   420â†’      humorLevel: 'medium',
   421â†’      content: `Knowing what to eat is useless if you don't actually do it. Here's how:
   422â†’
   423â†’**The Basics of Meal Prep:**
   424â†’1. Pick 2-3 protein sources
   425â†’2. Pick 2-3 carb sources
   426â†’3. Pick vegetables
   427â†’4. Cook in bulk
   428â†’5. Store in containers
   429â†’6. Eat throughout week
   430â†’
   431â†’**Simple Prep (Sunday, 2 hours):**
   432â†’
   433â†’**Proteins:**
   434â†’- 2 lbs chicken breast (baked or grilled)
   435â†’- 1 lb ground turkey or lean beef
   436â†’- 1 dozen hard boiled eggs
   437â†’
   438â†’**Carbs:**
   439â†’- Big batch of rice (rice cooker)
   440â†’- Bag of potatoes (roasted or boiled)
   441â†’- Oats (just need measuring)
   442â†’
   443â†’**Vegetables:**
   444â†’- Pre-washed salad bags
   445â†’- Broccoli/green beans (steam or roast)
   446â†’- Frozen vegetables (microwave)
   447â†’
   448â†’**Assembly:**
   449â†’Each meal: 6-8oz protein + 1 cup carbs + vegetables
   450â†’
   451â†’**If You Hate Meal Prep:**
   452â†’- Buy pre-cooked rotisserie chicken
   453â†’- Microwave rice packets
   454â†’- Pre-cut vegetables
   455â†’- More expensive but still works
   456â†’
   457â†’**Eating Out:**
   458â†’- Prioritize protein (grilled chicken, fish, steak)
   459â†’- Ask for dressing on side
   460â†’- Skip the bread basket
   461â†’- Don't drink calories
   462â†’- It's not that complicated`,
   463â†’      media: [
   464â†’        {
   465â†’          id: 'meal-prep',
   466â†’          type: 'image',
   467â†’          url: 'https://images.unsplash.com/photo-1532768778661-1b2b2df1d79d?w=800&q=80',
   468â†’          alt: 'Meal prep containers',
   469â†’          caption: 'Meal prep: 2 hours saves you all week',
   470â†’          placement: 'inline',
   471â†’        },
   472â†’      ],
   473â†’    },
   474â†’    {
   475â†’      id: 'common-mistakes',
   476â†’      title: 'Common Nutrition Mistakes',
   477â†’      humorLevel: 'medium-high',
   478â†’      content: `Don't be this guy:
   479â†’
   480â†’**Mistake 1: Not Tracking**
   481â†’"I eat healthy but can't lose weight."
   482â†’You're eating more than you think. Track for 2 weeks. I promise.
   483â†’
   484â†’**Mistake 2: Drinking Calories**
   485â†’Soda, juice, alcohol, fancy coffee drinks. 500+ invisible calories daily. Switch to water, black coffee, diet drinks.
   486â†’
   487â†’**Mistake 3: Weekend Destruction**
   488â†’5 days of deficit, 2 days of surplus = maintenance. The weekend counts.
   489â†’
   490â†’**Mistake 4: All-or-Nothing**
   491â†’One bad meal doesn't ruin the week. Just get back on track. Don't spiral into "I already messed up so..."
   492â†’
   493â†’**Mistake 5: Avoiding Carbs**
   494â†’Carbs aren't the enemy. Excess calories are. Low carb works by reducing calories, not magic.
   495â†’
   496â†’**Mistake 6: Not Eating Enough Protein**
   497â†’"I think I get enough." You probably don't. Track it. 0.8-1g/lb is more than most people think.
   498â†’
   499â†’**Mistake 7: Relying on Supplements**
   500â†’No supplement will fix a bad diet. Food first, supplements for gaps.
   501â†’
   502â†’**Mistake 8: Overcomplicating**
   503â†’Meal timing, food combining, "clean eating" obsession. Hit calories and protein. That's 80% of it.`,
   504â†’    },
   505â†’    {
   506â†’      id: 'action-plan',
   507â†’      title: 'Your Action Plan',
   508â†’      humorLevel: 'medium',
   509â†’      content: `Here's exactly what to do:
   510â†’
   511â†’**Week 1: Baseline**
   512â†’- Download a tracking app (MyFitnessPal, Cronometer)
   513â†’- Get a food scale
   514â†’- Track everything you eat for 7 days (no changes)
   515â†’- See where you actually are
   516â†’
   517â†’**Week 2: Adjust**
   518â†’- Calculate your calorie target based on goal
   519â†’- Set protein target (0.8-1g/lb)
   520â†’- Start hitting these targets
   521â†’
   522â†’**Week 3-4: Dial In**
   523â†’- Monitor weight trends
   524â†’- Adjust calories if needed (not losing? Reduce by 100-200)
   525â†’- Find meals that work for you
   526â†’- Build a rotation of go-to meals
   527â†’
   528â†’**Ongoing: Optimize**
   529â†’- Track until you can estimate accurately
   530â†’- Meal prep to stay consistent
   531â†’- Weigh weekly, adjust as needed
   532â†’- Don't overcomplicate
   533â†’
   534â†’**The Truth:**
   535â†’Most of your results come from:
   536â†’1. Eating in the right calorie range
   537â†’2. Hitting protein consistently
   538â†’3. Doing this for months/years
   539â†’
   540â†’Everything else is optimization. Master these three first.`,
   541â†’      products: ['food_scale'],
   542â†’    },
   543â†’  ],
   544â†’};
   545â†’

<system-reminder>

/**
 * Diet & Nutrition Guide
 * Humor Level: Medium (15%)
 */

import { Guide } from '@/types/guides';

export const dietGuide: Guide = {
  id: 'diet',
  slug: 'diet-nutrition',
  title: 'Diet & Nutrition',
  subtitle: "You can't out-train a bad diet",
  description: "The fundamentals of eating for aesthetics. Protein, calories, and what actually matters vs what doesn't.",
  icon: 'Utensils',
  humorLevel: 'medium',
  estimatedReadTime: 15,
  order: 8,
  tags: ['nutrition', 'diet', 'protein', 'calories', 'macros'],
  relatedGuides: ['body-fat', 'training', 'v-taper'],
  productIds: ['food_scale', 'creatine_mono', 'omega3_fish_oil', 'collagen_peptides', 'vitamin_d3_k2', 'magnesium_glycinate'],
  forumCategory: 'body-composition',
  heroMedia: {
    id: 'diet-hero',
    type: 'image',
    url: 'https://images.unsplash.com/photo-1490645935967-10de6ba17061?w=1200&q=80',
    alt: 'Healthy meal prep and nutrition',
    placement: 'hero',
  },
  sections: [
    {
      id: 'intro',
      title: 'The Foundation of Everything',
      humorLevel: 'medium',
      content: `Your physique is built in the kitchen, revealed in the gym.

You can train perfectly, but if your nutrition is garbage:
- You won't build muscle efficiently
- You won't lose fat predictably
- You'll look the same in 6 months

**The Good News:**
Nutrition is simpler than the internet makes it seem. Most of the complexity is unnecessary.

**What Actually Matters (80% of results):**
1. Total calories (energy balance)
2. Protein intake
3. Food quality (mostly)
4. Consistency

**What Barely Matters (20% optimization):**
- Meal timing
- Specific food choices within reason
- Supplement stacks beyond basics
- Nutrient timing around workouts

Let's cover the 80% first.`,
      media: [
        {
          id: 'diet-intro',
          type: 'image',
          url: 'https://images.unsplash.com/photo-1498837167922-ddd27525d352?w=800&q=80',
          alt: 'Healthy food and nutrition',
          caption: 'Your physique is built in the kitchen',
          placement: 'inline',
        },
        {
          id: 'sigma-diet-gif',
          type: 'gif',
          url: 'https://media.giphy.com/media/guNXesWtLfqOfnWwmx/giphy.gif',
          alt: 'Patrick Bateman sigma mindset',
          caption: 'The sigma diet grindset',
          placement: 'inline',
        },
      ],
    },
    {
      id: 'calories',
      title: 'Calories: The Master Variable',
      humorLevel: 'medium',
      content: `Everything else is secondary to energy balance.

**The Basic Math:**
- Calories In > Calories Out = Weight Gain
- Calories In < Calories Out = Weight Loss
- Calories In = Calories Out = Maintenance

**Finding Your Maintenance:**
Method 1: Calculator estimate
- TDEE calculator gives starting point
- Typically 14-17 x bodyweight (in lbs)
- Active people higher, sedentary lower

Method 2: Track and observe
- Eat the same for 2 weeks
- Track weight daily, average weekly
- Stable = maintenance. Rising = surplus. Dropping = deficit.

**Setting Your Target:**

| Goal | Calorie Target |
|------|---------------|
| Fat Loss | Maintenance - 300-500 |
| Maintenance | TDEE |
| Lean Bulk | Maintenance + 200-300 |
| Standard Bulk | Maintenance + 400-500 |

**The Mistake:**
Going too aggressive. A 1000 calorie deficit sounds fast but leads to muscle loss, metabolic adaptation, and binges. Slow and steady wins.`,
      products: ['food_scale'],
      tips: [
        'Use a food scale for accuracyâ€”eyeballing is notoriously wrong',
        'Track for 2-4 weeks to learn your foods, then you can estimate',
        'Weekly average matters more than daily fluctuations'
      ],
    },
    {
      id: 'protein',
      title: 'Protein: The King of Macros',
      humorLevel: 'medium',
      content: `If you remember one thing from this guide: hit your protein.

**Why Protein Is King:**
- Builds and preserves muscle
- Most satiating macro (keeps you full)
- Highest thermic effect (burns calories to digest)
- Hardest to store as fat

**How Much:**
- Minimum: 0.7g per pound of bodyweight
- Optimal: 0.8-1g per pound of bodyweight
- Upper limit: More than 1.2g/lb has no additional benefit

**For a 180lb Guy:**
- Minimum: 126g daily
- Optimal: 144-180g daily

**Best Protein Sources:**

| Source | Protein per 100g |
|--------|-----------------|
| Chicken breast | 31g |
| Lean beef | 26g |
| Salmon | 25g |
| Greek yogurt | 10g |
| Eggs | 13g |
| Cottage cheese | 11g |
| Whey protein | 80g |

**Hitting It Daily:**
- Each meal should have a protein source
- 30-50g per meal, 3-4 meals
- Fill gaps with protein shakes if needed
- Front-load protein earlier in day for satiety`,
      media: [
        {
          id: 'protein-chart',
          type: 'image',
          url: 'https://thenutritionjunky.com/wp-content/uploads/2023/08/High-protein-foods-chart-with-printable-PDF-blog-images-1200-x-700-px.jpg',
          alt: 'High protein foods chart showing protein content per serving',
          caption: 'Visual guide: Protein content in common foods',
          placement: 'inline',
        },
      ],
    },
    {
      id: 'carbs-fats',
      title: 'Carbs and Fats: The Flexible Macros',
      humorLevel: 'medium',
      content: `After calories and protein, carbs and fats are flexible. Here's how to think about them:

**Fats: The Minimum**
- Never go below 0.3g/lb bodyweight
- Fats are essential for hormones (testosterone)
- Too low = hormone problems, brain fog, bad skin
- For 180lb: minimum 54g fat daily

**Carbs: The Performance Fuel**
- Not "essential" but highly beneficial for training
- Fill remaining calories after protein and fat
- More carbs = better gym performance
- Lower carbs = some people do better for fat loss

**Setting Macros (Example: 180lb guy, 2500 calories)**

Option 1: Moderate carb (recommended)
- Protein: 180g (720 cal)
- Fat: 80g (720 cal)
- Carbs: 265g (1060 cal)

Option 2: Lower carb
- Protein: 180g (720 cal)
- Fat: 100g (900 cal)
- Carbs: 220g (880 cal)

Option 3: Higher carb (athletic)
- Protein: 180g (720 cal)
- Fat: 60g (540 cal)
- Carbs: 310g (1240 cal)

**The Truth:**
For most people, the exact ratio doesn't matter much. Hit protein, stay in your calorie range, and adjust carbs/fats based on preference and how you feel.`,
    },
    {
      id: 'food-quality',
      title: 'Food Quality: What to Actually Eat',
      humorLevel: 'medium-high',
      content: `Here's where things get simpler than the internet suggests:

**The 80/20 Rule:**
- 80% whole, minimally processed foods
- 20% whatever you want

This keeps you sane while getting results.

**Whole Foods (Prioritize These):**

**Proteins:**
- Chicken, turkey, lean beef, fish
- Eggs, Greek yogurt, cottage cheese
- Whey/casein protein powder

**Carbs:**
- Rice, potatoes, oats
- Fruits, vegetables
- Whole grain bread/pasta

**Fats:**
- Olive oil, avocados
- Nuts, seeds
- Fatty fish (salmon)
- Eggs

**Minimize (Not Eliminate):**
- Fried foods
- Sugary snacks and drinks
- Processed meats regularly
- Alcohol (empty calories + lowers testosterone + disrupts sleep)

**The Why:**
Whole foods are more filling per calorie, have more micronutrients, and are harder to overeat. You can lose weight on junk food (calories are calories), but you'll be hungrier and less healthy.`,
      media: [
        {
          id: 'whole-foods',
          type: 'image',
          url: 'https://images.unsplash.com/photo-1512621776951-a57141f2eefd?w=800&q=80',
          alt: 'Whole foods and vegetables',
          caption: '80% whole foods, 20% whatever you want',
          placement: 'inline',
        },
      ],
    },
    {
      id: 'meal-structure',
      title: 'Meal Structure and Timing',
      humorLevel: 'medium',
      content: `Meal timing is overrated for results but matters for adherence and performance.

**The Basics:**
- Total daily intake matters more than timing
- 3-5 meals per day works for most people
- Don't overthink it

**What Slightly Matters:**

1. **Pre-Workout (1-2 hours before)**
   - Carbs + protein = better performance
   - Don't train completely fasted if you can help it
   - Something > nothing

2. **Post-Workout (within 2-3 hours)**
   - Protein helps start recovery
   - The "anabolic window" is way longer than old bro-science claimed
   - Just eat normally, don't stress

3. **Before Bed**
   - Casein or slow protein can help overnight recovery
   - Not essential, just nice

**A Simple Day Structure:**

- Breakfast: Protein + carbs + fats
- Lunch: Protein + carbs + vegetables
- Pre-workout: Light carbs + protein if needed
- Dinner: Protein + carbs + vegetables
- Optional snack: Protein if needed to hit target

**Intermittent Fasting:**
Some people like it. It doesn't burn more fat, but it can help control calories if you're bad at small meals. Personal preference.`,
    },
    {
      id: 'cutting',
      title: 'Eating for Fat Loss',
      humorLevel: 'medium',
      content: `When cutting, everything matters a bit more:

**The Setup:**
1. Calculate maintenance calories
2. Subtract 300-500 calories
3. Set protein at 1g/lb (higher end when cutting)
4. Fill remaining with carbs and fats

**Maximizing Satiety:**
- High volume, low calorie foods (vegetables, lean proteins)
- More protein = more fullness
- High fiber foods
- Drink water before meals
- Eat slowly

**Volume Eating Foods:**
| Food | Calories per 100g |
|------|------------------|
| Lettuce | 5 |
| Cucumber | 16 |
| Egg whites | 52 |
| Chicken breast | 165 |
| Potatoes (boiled) | 77 |
| Greek yogurt (0%) | 59 |

You can eat 500g of potatoes for the same calories as 50g of chips. Volume matters.

**Cutting Mistakes:**
1. Going too aggressive (muscle loss, rebound)
2. Cutting protein (preserves muscle)
3. Eliminating carbs entirely (tanks performance)
4. Weekend binges (erases weekly deficit)
5. Not tracking (guessing incorrectly)`,
      tips: [
        'Weigh daily, average weeklyâ€”weight fluctuates',
        "0.5-1% of bodyweight loss per week is optimal",
        'Hunger is normal but not unbearableâ€”adjust if miserable'
      ],

    {
      id: 'bulking',
      title: 'Eating for Muscle Gain',
      humorLevel: 'medium',
      content: `Bulking done right builds muscle. Bulking done wrong just makes you fat.

**The Setup:**
1. Calculate maintenance
2. Add 200-300 calories (lean bulk) or 400-500 (standard bulk)
3. Set protein at 0.8-1g/lb
4. Distribute remaining to carbs and fats (favor carbs for training)

**Lean Bulk vs Dirty Bulk:**

| Approach | Surplus | Result |
|----------|---------|--------|
| Lean bulk | +200-300 | Slow muscle gain, minimal fat |
| Standard bulk | +400-500 | Good muscle gain, some fat |
| Dirty bulk | +1000+ | Some muscle, lots of fat |

**Recommendation:**
Lean bulk unless you're very underweight. Gaining fat doesn't build muscle faster, it just means a longer cut later.

**Weight Gain Rate:**
- Beginners: 2-4 lbs/month possible
- Intermediate: 1-2 lbs/month realistic
- Advanced: 0.5-1 lb/month if lucky

**If weight isn't going up:**
You're not eating enough. Track more accurately and add 100-200 calories.

**Bulking Mistakes:**
1. Gaining too fast ("I'll cut later" â†’ never cuts)
2. Dirty bulking (just makes you fat)
3. Not tracking (surplus might actually be deficit)
4. Using bulk as excuse to eat garbage`,
    },
    {
      id: 'supplements',
      title: 'Supplements That Actually Work',
      humorLevel: 'medium-high',
      content: `Most supplements are garbage. Here's what's worth your money:

**Tier 1: Actually Works**

1. **Creatine Monohydrate**
   - 5g daily, any time
   - Strength, size, cognition
   - Costs $0.10/day
   - No loading needed

2. **Protein Powder**
   - Convenient protein source
   - Whey, casein, or plant-based
   - Not magic, just food in powder form

3. **Vitamin D3**
   - Most people are deficient
   - 2000-5000 IU daily
   - Get blood work to confirm

4. **Omega-3 (Fish Oil)**
   - Anti-inflammatory
   - Brain and heart health
   - 2-3g EPA/DHA daily

**Tier 2: Situationally Useful**

5. **Caffeine** â€” Performance boost (from coffee is fine)
6. **Magnesium** â€” Most people are deficient, helps sleep
7. **Collagen** â€” May help joints and skin
8. **Zinc** â€” If deficient (many are)

**Tier 3: Probably Wasting Money**

- BCAAs (get protein instead)
- Fat burners (mostly caffeine + fillers)
- Testosterone boosters (don't work)
- Most pre-workouts (caffeine + expensive pixie dust)

**The Rule:**
Get 95% of results from food. Use supplements to fill gaps, not replace meals.`,

      id: 'practical',
      title: 'Practical Meal Prep',
      humorLevel: 'medium',
      content: `Knowing what to eat is useless if you don't actually do it. Here's how:

**The Basics of Meal Prep:**
1. Pick 2-3 protein sources
2. Pick 2-3 carb sources
3. Pick vegetables
4. Cook in bulk
5. Store in containers
6. Eat throughout week

**Simple Prep (Sunday, 2 hours):**

**Proteins:**
- 2 lbs chicken breast (baked or grilled)
- 1 lb ground turkey or lean beef
- 1 dozen hard boiled eggs

**Carbs:**
- Big batch of rice (rice cooker)
- Bag of potatoes (roasted or boiled)
- Oats (just need measuring)

**Vegetables:**
- Pre-washed salad bags
- Broccoli/green beans (steam or roast)
- Frozen vegetables (microwave)

**Assembly:**
Each meal: 6-8oz protein + 1 cup carbs + vegetables

**If You Hate Meal Prep:**
- Buy pre-cooked rotisserie chicken
- Microwave rice packets
- Pre-cut vegetables
- More expensive but still works

**Eating Out:**
- Prioritize protein (grilled chicken, fish, steak)
- Ask for dressing on side
- Skip the bread basket
- Don't drink calories
- It's not that complicated`,
      media: [
        {

        },
      ],
    },
    {
      id: 'common-mistakes',
      title: 'Common Nutrition Mistakes',
      humorLevel: 'medium-high',
      content: `Don't be this guy:

**Mistake 1: Not Tracking**
"I eat healthy but can't lose weight."
You're eating more than you think. Track for 2 weeks. I promise.

**Mistake 2: Drinking Calories**
Soda, juice, alcohol, fancy coffee drinks. 500+ invisible calories daily. Switch to water, black coffee, diet drinks.

**Mistake 3: Weekend Destruction**
5 days of deficit, 2 days of surplus = maintenance. The weekend counts.

**Mistake 4: All-or-Nothing**
One bad meal doesn't ruin the week. Just get back on track. Don't spiral into "I already messed up so..."

**Mistake 5: Avoiding Carbs**
Carbs aren't the enemy. Excess calories are. Low carb works by reducing calories, not magic.

**Mistake 6: Not Eating Enough Protein**
"I think I get enough." You probably don't. Track it. 0.8-1g/lb is more than most people think.

**Mistake 7: Relying on Supplements**
No supplement will fix a bad diet. Food first, supplements for gaps.

**Mistake 8: Overcomplicating**
Meal timing, food combining, "clean eating" obsession. Hit calories and protein. That's 80% of it.`,

    {
      id: 'action-plan',

      humorLevel: 'medium',
      content: `Here's exactly what to do:

**Week 1: Baseline**
- Download a tracking app (MyFitnessPal, Cronometer)
- Get a food scale
- Track everything you eat for 7 days (no changes)
- See where you actually are

**Week 2: Adjust**
- Calculate your calorie target based on goal
- Set protein target (0.8-1g/lb)
- Start hitting these targets

**Week 3-4: Dial In**
- Monitor weight trends
- Adjust calories if needed (not losing? Reduce by 100-200)
- Find meals that work for you
- Build a rotation of go-to meals

**Ongoing: Optimize**
- Track until you can estimate accurately
- Meal prep to stay consistent
- Weigh weekly, adjust as needed
- Don't overcomplicate

**The Truth:**
Most of your results come from:
1. Eating in the right calorie range
2. Hitting protein consistently
3. Doing this for months/years

Everything else is optimization. Master these three first.`,

    83â†’- Gentle, consistent care
    84â†’- Layer multiple hydrating products

    86â†’- Skin is meant to be nourished, not punished
    87â†’
    88â†’**Core K-Beauty Principles:**

    90â†’**1. Double Cleansing**
    91â†’Oil-based cleanser first (dissolves makeup, sunscreen, sebum), then water-based cleanser. Clean slate without stripping.

    93â†’**2. Layers of Hydration**

   351â†’      title: 'Common Glass Skin Mistakes',
   352â†’      humorLevel: 'high',
   353â†’      content: `Avoid these glass skin fails:
   354â†’
   355â†’**Mistake 1: Too Many Steps, Wrong Products**
   356â†’A 12-step routine with mediocre products beats nothing, but a 5-step routine with great products is more effective. Quality over quantity.

   358â†’**Mistake 2: Skipping Sunscreen**

/**

import { Guide } from '@/types/guides';

export const glassSkinGuide: Guide = {

  slug: 'glass-skin',
  title: 'K-Beauty Glass Skin',
  subtitle: "That dewy, translucent glow straight from Seoul",
  description: "Complete Korean skincare protocol for achieving glass skin. The 7-step routine, product layering, and ingredient breakdown.",
  icon: 'Sparkle',
  humorLevel: 'medium',
  estimatedReadTime: 14,
  order: 14,
  tags: ['kbeauty', 'glass-skin', 'korean', 'skincare', 'hydration', 'dewy', 'snail-mucin'],
  relatedGuides: ['skincare', 'anti-aging-women'],
  productIds: [
    'cosrx_snail_mucin',
    'klairs_toner',
    'hada_labo_premium',
    'banila_cleansing_balm',
    'cosrx_aha_bha_toner',
    'boj_glow_serum',
    'laneige_cream_skin',

  ],
  forumCategory: 'skincare',

  sections: [
    {
      id: 'intro',
      title: 'What Is Glass Skin?',
      humorLevel: 'medium',
      content: `Glass skin (ìœ ë¦¬ í”¼ë¶€) is the Korean beauty ideal of skin so hydrated, clear, and luminous that it looks like glassâ€”smooth, poreless, and almost translucent.

**The Characteristics:**
- Intensely hydrated, not oily
- Even tone with no visible discoloration
- Smooth texture, minimal visible pores
- Natural luminosity (not shimmer or glitter)
- Plump, bouncy appearance

**What It's NOT:**
- Shiny/greasy skin
- Makeup-based glow
- Filters and facetune
- Genetics-only (though it helps)

**Can Anyone Achieve It?**
Realistically, genetics play a role. But most people can get 80% of the way there with the right routine. The key is hydration, barrier health, and texture refinement.

**This Guide Covers:**
1. The Korean skincare philosophy
2. The 7-step glass skin routine
3. Key K-beauty ingredients
4. Product layering order
5. Common mistakes to avoid`,
    },
    {
      id: 'philosophy',
      title: 'The Korean Skincare Philosophy',
      humorLevel: 'medium',
      content: `K-beauty is fundamentally different from Western skincare:

**Western Approach:**
- Fix problems as they arise
- Aggressive actives (retinol, acids)
- Minimal steps, maximum strength
- "No pain, no gain" mentality

**Korean Approach:**
- Prevention over treatment
- Gentle, consistent care
- Layer multiple hydrating products
- Barrier health is everything
- Skin is meant to be nourished, not punished

**Core K-Beauty Principles:**

**1. Double Cleansing**
Oil-based cleanser first (dissolves makeup, sunscreen, sebum), then water-based cleanser. Clean slate without stripping.

**2. Layers of Hydration**
Instead of one heavy moisturizer, multiple lightweight layers that absorb better and hydrate deeper.

**3. Essences and Toners**
Not the astringent "toners" of the West. Hydrating, fermented first layers that prep skin to absorb everything after.

**4. Pat, Don't Rub**
Pressing products into skin increases absorption and prevents tugging.

**5. Sunscreen Always**
Even indoors. Even on cloudy days. Non-negotiable.`,
    },
    {
      id: 'routine',
      title: 'The 7-Step Glass Skin Routine',
      humorLevel: 'medium',
      content: `The full routine, morning and evening:

**EVENING ROUTINE:**

**Step 1: Oil Cleanser**
- Removes makeup, sunscreen, pollution
- Massage on dry face, then emulsify with water
- Product: Banila Co Clean It Zero, DHC Deep Cleansing Oil

**Step 2: Water-Based Cleanser**
- Removes remaining residue
- Low pH (5.0-6.0) to maintain barrier
- Product: COSRX Low pH Good Morning Gel, Cerave Foaming

**Step 3: Exfoliate (2-3x weekly)**
- Chemical over physical
- AHA for surface texture, BHA for pores
- Product: COSRX AHA/BHA Toner, Paula's Choice 2% BHA

**Step 4: Toner/First Essence**
- Hydrating, not stripping
- Preps skin for absorption
- Product: Klairs Supple Preparation, Missha Time Revolution

**Step 5: Serum/Ampoule**
- Targeted treatment
- For glass skin: hydration + brightening
- Product: COSRX Snail Mucin, Boj Glow Deep Serum

**Step 6: Moisturizer**
- Seals everything in
- Can be lighter than Western versions
- Product: Soon Jung 2x Barrier, Illiyoon Ceramide Ato

**Step 7: Sleeping Mask (optional)**
- Extra occlusive layer
- 2-3x weekly or as needed
- Product: Laneige Water Sleeping Mask, COSRX Rice Mask

**MORNING ROUTINE:**

1. Water-only cleanse (or gentle cleanser if oily)
2. Toner
3. Serum (Vitamin C optional)
4. Moisturizer
5. Sunscreen SPF 30-50 (CRUCIAL)`,
      products: ['banila_cleansing_balm', 'cosrx_aha_bha_toner', 'klairs_toner', 'cosrx_snail_mucin'],
      media: [
        {
          id: 'skincare-layering',
          type: 'gif',
          url: 'https://media1.tenor.com/m/i7DGJM5QwHkAAAAC/skincare-splash-face.gif',

          caption: 'Pat, dont rub - increases absorption',
          placement: 'inline',

      ],
      tips: [
        'Apply each layer while skin is still damp for better absorption',
        'Pat products in, never rub or drag',
        'Wait 30 seconds between layers if not absorbing quickly',
      ],
    },
    {
      id: 'key-ingredients',
      title: 'Key K-Beauty Ingredients',
      humorLevel: 'medium',
      content: `What makes K-beauty products effective:

**Hydration Heroes:**
| Ingredient | What It Does | Found In |
|------------|--------------|----------|
| **Hyaluronic Acid** | Holds 1000x weight in water | Most toners, essences |
| **Snail Mucin** | Hydration, healing, texture | COSRX 96 Essence |
| **Ceramides** | Barrier repair, moisture lock | Soon Jung, Illiyoon |
| **Centella Asiatica** | Soothing, healing | PURITO, Cosrx |
| **Propolis** | Antibacterial, hydrating | COSRX, Benton |

**Brightening Stars:**
| Ingredient | What It Does | Found In |
|------------|--------------|----------|
| **Niacinamide** | Brightening, pores, barrier | Most Korean serums |
| **Vitamin C** | Antioxidant, brightening | Klairs, Melano CC |
| **Rice Ferment** | Brightening, softening | COSRX Rice Mask, SK-II |
| **Licorice Root** | Fades hyperpigmentation | Many brightening products |
| **Arbutin** | Gentler alternative to hydroquinone | Hada Labo, many serums |

**Texture Refiners:**
| Ingredient | What It Does | Found In |
|------------|--------------|----------|
| **AHA (Glycolic, Lactic)** | Surface exfoliation | COSRX Whitehead Power |
| **BHA (Salicylic)** | Pore clearing | COSRX Blackhead Power |
| **PHA** | Gentle exfoliation for sensitive | Some By Mi |
| **Fermented Ingredients** | Enhanced absorption, glow | Missha, SK-II essence |

**What K-Beauty Avoids:**
- Harsh sulfates
- Drying alcohols
- Heavy fragrances (mostly)
- Aggressive physical scrubs`,
      products: ['cosrx_snail_mucin', 'hada_labo_premium', 'klairs_toner'],
    },
    {
      id: 'layering',
      title: 'The Art of Layering',
      humorLevel: 'medium',
      content: `The order matters. Layering incorrectly = wasted product and poor results.

**The Golden Rule:**
Thinnest â†’ Thickest consistency

**The Complete Order:**
1. Oil cleanser (PM only)
2. Water cleanser
3. Toner/First essence (watery)
4. Essence (slightly thicker)
5. Serum/Ampoule (targeted)
6. Emulsion (light moisturizer)
7. Cream (heavier moisturizer)
8. Facial oil (if used)
9. Sleeping pack (PM) or Sunscreen (AM)

**Layering Tips:**

**The 7-Skin Method:**
Apply 7 layers of the same hydrating toner. Sounds excessive, works incredibly. Each thin layer absorbs fully before the next.

**Wait Times:**
| Product | Wait Time |
|---------|-----------|
| After cleansing | Immediately apply toner |
| After AHA/BHA | 20 minutes (pH-dependent) |
| After Vitamin C | 10-15 minutes |
| After retinol | 20 minutes before next steps |
| Other layers | Until absorbed (usually 30-60 sec) |

**How to Know It's Absorbed:**
- Skin feels slightly tacky but not wet
- Product is no longer visible
- Skin feels plump, not greasy`,
      tips: [
        'Apply products to damp skin for better absorption',
        "If something pills, you're applying too much or not waiting",
        'Not every step is needed every dayâ€”adapt to your skin',
      ],
    },
    {
      id: 'skin-types',
      title: 'Glass Skin for Different Skin Types',
      humorLevel: 'medium',
      content: `Adapt the routine to your needs:

**Oily Skin:**
- Skip heavy creams, use gel moisturizers
- Double cleanse is essential
- Focus on BHA for pores
- Mattifying sunscreen
- Avoid: Over-moisturizing, heavy occlusives

**Dry Skin:**
- Add more hydrating layers
- Facial oils are your friend
- Cream over gel products
- Sleeping masks regularly
- Avoid: Over-exfoliating, drying cleansers

**Combination:**
- Multi-masking (different products per zone)
- Lighter on T-zone, richer on cheeks
- Balance is key
- Avoid: Treating whole face the same

**Sensitive:**
- Patch test everything
- Fragrance-free products
- Skip actives initially
- Centella and ceramides are safe bets
- Avoid: Too many new products at once

**Acne-Prone:**
- Non-comedogenic products
- BHA is your friend
- Tea tree, propolis, centella
- Don't over-dry with actives
- Avoid: Heavy occlusives that trap bacteria`,

    {

      humorLevel: 'medium',
      content: `The K-beauty products that earned their reputation:

**Cleansers:**
| Product | Type | Best For |
|---------|------|----------|

| Klairs Gentle Black Deep | Oil | Sensitive |

**Toners/Essences:**
| Product | Best For |
|---------|----------|

| Pyunkang Yul Essence Toner | Hydration, minimal ingredients |
| Hada Labo Premium Lotion | Intense hydration |

**Serums/Ampoules:**
| Product | Best For |
|---------|----------|
| COSRX Snail 96 Mucin Power Essence | Hydration, healing, texture |
| Beauty of Joseon Glow Serum | Brightening, nourishing |
| PURITO Centella Unscented Serum | Calming, sensitive |
| iUNIK Propolis Vitamin Synergy | Brightening, hydration |

**Moisturizers:**
| Product | Best For |
|---------|----------|
| Soon Jung 2x Barrier Cream | Sensitive, barrier repair |
| Illiyoon Ceramide Ato Cream | Dry, eczema-prone |
| COSRX Oil-Free Moisturizing Lotion | Oily, acne-prone |
| Laneige Cream Skin | Lazy girl moisturizing toner hybrid |

**Sunscreens:**
| Product | Finish |
|---------|--------|
| Beauty of Joseon Relief Sun | Dewy, no white cast |
| Isntree Hyaluronic Acid Sun Gel | Hydrating, lightweight |
| Purito Daily Go-To Sunscreen | Dewy, moisturizing |`,
      products: ['banila_cleansing_balm', 'klairs_toner', 'cosrx_snail_mucin', 'boj_glow_serum', 'laneige_cream_skin', 'hada_labo_premium'],
    },
    {
      id: 'common-mistakes',
      title: 'Common Glass Skin Mistakes',
      humorLevel: 'high',
      content: `Avoid these glass skin fails:

**Mistake 1: Too Many Steps, Wrong Products**
A 12-step routine with mediocre products beats nothing, but a 5-step routine with great products is more effective. Quality over quantity.

**Mistake 2: Skipping Sunscreen**
You're hydrating and brightening at night, then letting UV undo it during the day. SPF is part of glass skin.

**Mistake 3: Over-Exfoliating**
Using AHA, BHA, and retinol every day because you want faster results. Your barrier is destroyed. Now you have red, irritated, definitely-not-glass skin.

**Mistake 4: Applying Products Wrong**
Rubbing instead of patting. Applying to dry skin instead of damp. Not waiting between layers.

**Mistake 5: Expecting Overnight Results**
Korean women have done this since childhood. Your two weeks won't match their two decades. Be patient.

**Mistake 6: Ignoring Diet and Sleep**
No skincare routine overcomes chronic dehydration, poor sleep, and junk food. Internal health shows externally.

**Mistake 7: Copying Someone Else's Routine**
Your skin type is different. What works for oily Korean skin may not work for dry Western skin. Adapt.

**Mistake 8: Product Hoarding Without Consistency**
Buying 47 products and using each twice isn't a routine. Pick a core set and stick with it.`,
    },
    {
      id: 'lifestyle',
      title: 'The Korean Lifestyle Factor',
      humorLevel: 'medium',
      content: `Products are only part of the equation:

**Diet:**
- High water intake (skin is 64% water)
- Fermented foods (kimchi, etc.) for gut-skin connection
- Low sugar, low dairy (controversial but many see improvements)
- Collagen-rich foods (bone broth, fish)
- Green tea antioxidants

**Sleep:**
- "Beauty sleep" is real
- Silk pillowcases to reduce friction
- Back sleeping to prevent sleep lines
- 7-9 hours for proper skin repair

**Stress:**
- Cortisol = inflammation = poor skin
- Korean beauty rituals double as self-care
- The routine itself is meditative

**Environment:**
- Humidifiers in dry climates
- Air purifiers for pollution
- Changing pillowcases frequently
- Clean phone screens

**What Korean Women Do Differently:**
- Start skincare early (taught as children)
- Consistent daily routine without skipping
- Prevention mindset over treatment
- Skin health = overall health philosophy
- Regular dermatologist visits are normalized`,
    },
    {
      id: 'budget-guide',
      title: 'Glass Skin by Budget',
      humorLevel: 'medium',
      content: `Achieve the glow at any price point:

**Under $30/month (Drugstore K-Beauty):**
- COSRX Good Morning Cleanser: $10

- COSRX Snail Mucin Essence: $12

**$30-60/month (Mid-Range):**

- *Result:* Comprehensive Korean routine

**$100+/month (Luxury):**

- Professional treatments (hydrafacials)
- High-end Korean brands (Sulwhasoo, Amorepacific)
- *Result:* Maximum results

**Best ROI Products:**
1. COSRX Snail Mucin Essence ($12)
2. Hada Labo Premium Lotion ($13)
3. Sunscreen (any good one, $10-20)
4. Klairs Supple Preparation Toner ($22)

These four products alone can transform most skin.`,
      products: ['cosrx_snail_mucin', 'hada_labo_premium', 'klairs_toner'],
    },
    {
      id: 'action-plan',
      title: 'Your Glass Skin Action Plan',
      humorLevel: 'medium',
      content: `Here's how to start:

**Week 1: The Basics**
- Get a gentle cleanser (oil + water-based)
- Get a hydrating toner
- Get a moisturizer
- GET SUNSCREEN
- Routine: Cleanse â†’ Toner â†’ Moisturizer â†’ SPF (AM)

**Week 2-3: Add Hydration Layers**
- Add snail mucin or hyaluronic acid essence
- Practice the "pat don't rub" technique
- Start seeing improvement in hydration

**Week 4-6: Introduce Actives (Slowly)**
- Add AHA or BHA 2x weekly
- Add brightening serum if needed
- Don't introduce everything at once

**Month 2-3: Refine**
- Adjust routine for your skin's response
- Try the 7-skin method if more hydration needed
- Consider sleeping masks

**Ongoing: Maintain**
- Consistency is everything

**Timeline Expectations:**

Glass skin isn't achieved; it's maintained. This is a lifestyle, not a quick fix.`,

    25â†’    url: 'https://images.unsplash.com/photo-1541781774459-bb2af2f05b55?w=1200&q=80',

    34â†’      content: `Most guys think sleep hygiene is candles and lavender sprays. In reality, it's about eliminating the physiological friction that ruins sleep quality without you even noticing.

/**
 * Core Sleep Drivers Guide
 * Humor Level: Medium (15%)
 */

import { Guide } from '@/types/guides';

export const sleepDriversGuide: Guide = {
  id: 'sleep-drivers',
  slug: 'sleep-drivers',
  title: 'Core Sleep Drivers',
  subtitle: "It's not about candles and lavender",
  description: "The actual physiological factors that determine whether you sleep deeply or wake up feeling like garbage.",
  icon: 'Moon',
  humorLevel: 'medium',
  estimatedReadTime: 5,
  order: 21,
  tags: ['sleep', 'recovery', 'hormones', 'cortisol', 'melatonin'],
  relatedGuides: ['circadian-rhythm', 'sleep-environment', 'cortisol-management'],
  productIds: ['magnesium_glycinate', 'melatonin_lowdose', 'blue_light_glasses'],
  forumCategory: 'lifestyle',
  heroMedia: {
    id: 'sleep-drivers-hero',
    type: 'image',
    url: 'https://images.unsplash.com/photo-1541781774459-bb2af2f05b55?w=1200&q=80',
    alt: 'Quality sleep environment',
    placement: 'hero',
  },
  sections: [
    {
      id: 'intro',
      title: 'What Actually Controls Sleep Quality',
      humorLevel: 'medium',
      content: `Most guys think sleep hygiene is candles and lavender sprays. In reality, it's about eliminating the physiological friction that ruins sleep quality without you even noticing.

**The Real Sleep Drivers:**
1. Light discipline (your brain's chemical signals)
2. Nervous system state (sympathetic vs parasympathetic)
3. Core body temperature
4. Sleep pressure (adenosine buildup)

Get these right, and sleep becomes effortless. Ignore them, and no amount of melatonin will save you.`,
    },
    {
      id: 'light-discipline',
      title: '1. Light Discipline (Night Mode for Your Brain)',
      humorLevel: 'medium',
      content: `Your eyes dictate your brain's chemical signals. If you flood your retina with blue/white light at night, melatonin drops and your entire system refuses to switch into sleep mode.

What you want is warm, low-intensity lighting and zero bright screens 1 hour before bed.

**The Goal:** Make your environment look like sunset.

**Core Rules:**
- Disable bright overhead lights after sunset
- Switch screens to warm-tone mode
- Avoid LED white light in the last hour before bed
- Use lamps, not ceiling lights

You're basically signaling to your brain: "we're done for the day."

**Blue Light = Daytime Signal**
Even a few minutes of bright screen exposure can delay melatonin release by 30-60 minutes.`,
    },
    {
      id: 'nervous-system',
      title: '2. Pre-Sleep Wind-Down (Nervous System Cooldown)',
      humorLevel: 'medium',
      content: `You cannot go from scrolling TikTok to "deep sleep." Your nervous system has gears. Most guys try to sleep while still in fight-or-flight mode.

A proper wind-down routine shifts you from **sympathetic (stress)** to **parasympathetic (recovery)**.

**High-ROI Protocol:**
- Drop stimulants after 2pm
- Stop work / mental stimulation 1 hour before bed
- Slow breathing (4-6 seconds exhale focus)
- Light stretching to release tension
- Switch into silence: no blue-light, no notifications

**The Entire Goal:** Reduce cortisol, increase melatonin, and calm the mind.

If you go to bed wired, you'll either not fall asleep or your sleep quality will be trash even if you're unconscious for 8 hours.`,
    },
    {
      id: 'hidden-sleep-killers',
      title: '3. Avoiding Hidden Sleep Killers',
      humorLevel: 'medium',
      content: `These are the things most guys don't realize are destroying their sleep:

**Doomscrolling Before Bed**
Keeps your brain in reactive mode. Content consumption = dopamine hits = alertness.

**Heavy Meals 1-2 Hours Before Sleeping**
Induces bloating, heartburn, and keeps your digestive system active when it should be resting.

**Alcohol**
Destroys REM sleep and testosterone. One drink can measurably reduce sleep quality.

**Porn**
Triggers dopamine and overstimulates before rest.

**Late-Night Cardio or Heavy Lifts**
Raises cortisol when you need it dropping.

**The Rule:**
Sleep is hormonal. If you trash your hormones before bed, no amount of "8 hours" will save you.`,
    },
    {
      id: 'core-temp',
      title: '4. Core Temperature Management',
      humorLevel: 'medium',
      content: `Your core temperature must drop to initiate and maintain deep sleep.

**The Science:**
- Body temp naturally drops 1-2Â°F during sleep
- If your bedroom is too hot, you can't initiate this drop
- This is why hot rooms cause fragmented sleep

**Optimal Setup:**
- Bedroom temperature: 65-68Â°F (18-20Â°C)
- Use breathable sheets (cotton, bamboo)
- Consider sleeping naked or with minimal clothing
- A warm shower 1-2 hours before bed actually helps (causes rebound cooling)

**Cold Room + Warm Blankets** = The ideal setup

This single variable fixes insomnia for 70%+ of people.`,
    },
    {
      id: 'action-plan',
      title: 'Your Action Plan',
      humorLevel: 'medium',
      content: `**Tonight:**
- Switch to warm lighting after sunset
- No screens in the last hour (or heavy warm filter)
- Drop bedroom temp to 65-68Â°F

**This Week:**
- No caffeine after 2pm
- No alcohol within 3 hours of bed
- Add 5-min breathing/stretching before bed

**Ongoing:**
- Protect your wind-down window religiously
- Track what disrupts your sleep and eliminate it
- Prioritize sleep over late-night productivity

**The Result:**
Dial in these drivers and you'll fall asleep faster, stay asleep longer, and wake up actually feeling recoveredâ€”without any supplements.`,
      products: ['magnesium_glycinate'],
    },
  ],
};
